div.p: THE APOLOGIE FOR THE CONFORMABLE MINISTERS OF ENGLAND, For their Subscription to the present Church Gouernement.

Where in is handled two things,
THE FIRST IS, ¶ That the setting vp of the Primitiue Church Gouernement, vnder a Christian King is not a matter of necessitie, and this is prooued by twentie substantiall reasons.
THE SECOND IS, ¶ That the Gouernement of the Church as now it standeth, differeth not from the Primitiue Gouernement, but onely in one materiall and necessarie circumstance.
Written by IOHN FREEMAN, Minister of the Gospel.
LONDON Printed by VV. Stansby for Nathaniel Butter, dwelling in Pauls Church-yard by Saint Austins Gate. 1609.

div.head: To the Right Reuerend Fathers in God, RICHARD, by the Grace of God Lord Archbishop of Canterbury, Metropolitane and Primate of all England And to THOMAS, by the same Grace of God, Lord Bishop of London, All grace and peace in Ies • s Christ.
div.p:
I Doubted with my selfe, Right Reuerend Fathers, very often, and long, whether I should euer publish, or bring into the open light, this long since written Apologie, and defence of mine. I saw that our brethren differing from vs in the opinion of Church-gouernment, were, with the Religious, and the worshippers of our time, the men of greatest esteeme. I saw that they were men of sincere liues, and of singular labour, and blessing in the Church of God. I feared, yea in a true cause, to open my mouth against them: least I should bee counted a temporizer, and an enemie to all righteousnesse, and to the Church of God. I feared mine owne defence, for feare of their offence. I feared least mine opinion, how s • und soeuer, would bee so ouerswayed by their authority, that it would be cleane condemned; or ouerwaighed by their estimation, that it would be vtterly contemned. If the light of the trueth by my poore labours preuailed, and that I were made an instrument to discouer their errour, I feared (though without reason) least I should adde affliction to their bonds: a thing which my soule neuer tooke pleasure in: or else, that whiles I ouerthrow their error, I should ouerthrow Religion it selfe, which was close couched, and as it seemed

inextricably combined, and conioyned therewith. For Sathan had so sowed this error, (a subtill tricke of that olde Nouatian, and Angel like Deuill,) in almost all the religious and professors of the lande, that religion it selfe seemed to liue, and to die therewith. Yea my selfe, before authority inforced mee with Lynceus eyes to looke into this opinion of theirs, was so farre carried with the regard thereof, that I rather chose to erre with such men, then to thinke the trueth with the present estate: the very reuerence of the men, made me to reuerence the verie error of the men, and then no meruaile if I did easily consent to ouerthrow that, which my selfe had once holpen to build vp: But when I saw that howsoeuer I ought to reuerence such men: yet that I ought to reuerence, incomparably more the trueth, and glory of God: When I saw that my long silence, did not redeeme their silence, that the holding of my peace, did not giue them peace: that to be silent did do them no good: but to speake might do them some good, for it might resolue them. When I saw that they were condemned for their error: and my selfe, and my brethren were condemned for the trueth, so that their sincerity could not vphold religion, because of their silenced error: nor our truth, because of mens blind and wilfull, and too too vncharitable erring. When I saw that their false opinion ouerthrew their ministery with the state: & mens false opinions concerning vs ouerthrew our ministerie with the contrary: so that in all places, and euery where, religion was like to fall to the ground: I thought it high time now, if euer (not weighing what once I thought, but what now, I plainely see, and knowe) religion it selfe, and the trueth of God so requiring to cleere our selues in the open hearing, and sight of the world, and to let all men know, that we that haue subscribed to the present Church gouerment, haue not done it of humane infirmitie, as they would seeme to thinke, that are the most charitable among them: much lesse haue we done it as temporizers, to raise our selues to worldly honor: or as Apostataes, and turne coates,
to enioy the riches, and the fat of the land: but from a full perswasion of knowledge, and from tried, and approoued grounds of the worde, which what they are, we offer by this Apology to the view of the world, and to be looked into both by our aduersaries, and by our friends: not now any longer standing in feare of the enuious man, if as Vlisses vnder Aiax shield: so I, religion, and the truth of God, (as in most humble wise I craue and most confidently hope,) may be hidden and safe kept, vnder your Lordships most able, and honorable protection. And since I haue ventured so far vpon your Lordships desired, but not deserued fauour, as to become troublesome to you, with the defence, of this my defence: Let it not I beseech you seem vnpleasing or vnseemely in your Lordships eies, if I intreate in the behalfe of our enemy-brethren, that they may haue free liberty to vse the presse, if they meane to make answere to this Apology and answere of ours. I feare not least these reasons of mine should proue like small wines, that please better in the tasting, then in the drinking. No my very hope is, that if they doe but reade them, they will relish them. But if they shall attempt to dissolue them: they will resolue them, and that they will not finde them to be hay, or straw, or stubble, builded vpon the foundation Christ, but pearle & pretious stone, & pure gold, which the more it is tried, the purer it wil be. And thus my hope is, that by me the weakest & vnablest man of the Church: the Church, and we the condemned men of the Church, may keep our innocency: and our brethren, if they be not obstinate may be resolued, and we with them inioy in the Church, our mutuall, and long wished: but too too long broken, and discontinued peace: which God, who onely is able, and is the Author of peace, by this of mine, or some other more effectuall work, effect and work, in his good, and speedy time, for Iesus Christ his sake, to whome be all honour giuen and euerlasting praise, both now and for euer, Amen.

div.head: To the Reader.
div.p:
CHristian Reader, change in gouernors & gouernm • nts, is a thing so vsuall with God and men, that euen the heauens and the earth often haue had experience thereof. For in the heauens hath the Lord set vp a new King to raigne ouer all the powers of heauen: ouer the principalities and the glorious thrones, ouer al the Angels of God, and ouer all the soules of the iust: yea ouer all the Kings and kingdomes of the earth: and ouer all the people of the world. Yea, this King hath the keyes of hell, • nd of death, and this new King whom God hath set a Lord and king ouer all, is the Lord Iesus, a man taken from among men, yea out of the dust of death, and out of the graue. Him hath God lifted vp (with showting, and the song of the Trumpet, with great honour and exceeding glorie and ioy) into the heauen, and set him vpon his right hand, and established him an euerlasting Lord and King: and this is hee whome now all the Angels and powers of heauen do worship, whom all the soules, and spirits of the dead that liue, do worshippe as the King, and prince of God: and this all kings of the earth worship, and fall downe before him, and licke the dust at his feete. And that the Church on earth might haue experience of this changeable estate, Christ that once dep • ted the Elders of the Church, to gouerne for him that part of his Kingdome on the earth, that wee call the Church, hath in steade of them, s • t vp the Kings, and the princes of the earth to rule, not onely the weale publike, but the Kingdom of Christ on the earth, which is the Church of God. If thou askest when this change was made, and when this ruling power was translated from the Church to the
King: this booke will answere thee, and tel thee, that when Kings became Christian, they gained a kingdom on earth, that they lost before euen a kingdom ouer the kingdom of Christ, and besides, a kingdom in heauen, where they that raigne well, being Kings on earth, shall raign also Kings in heauen with Iesus, that Lord and mightie King. If thou askest what word there is to warrant this change: it will shewe thee, that it is warranted by the spirit of Prophecie, that spake in Esay the Prophet, that foretold, that Kings should be nursing Fathers, and Queens nursing mothers to the Church, to feede vs not onely with the word, but the sword: that is, to rule and gouern prudently, as Dauid did the Church of God. If thou askest the reasons of the change this booke will yeelde thee twenty at the least, to resolue thee of this point: it wil let thee plainly see, that the power to rule, that once was in the Church when Kings were not yet Christians, is now, that Kings are become Christians, departed from the Church, & d • uolued to the Christian King • , as to the proper owners & right heires of so great a power. And here I must tell thee, that this doctrine, as it hath many enemies, that for want of eye-salue, cannot see into the end of the Primitiue gouernment abolished: so it hath many friends, men of a nimbler eye and quicke sight, that dare vphold it with the best member that they haue. And that in one view thou mightest see both the friends and the foes, I will in a word set them before thee. The principall enemy of this doctrine is the Pope, who hauing seazed vpon the Kingdome of Christ, holdeth fast the power, and exerciseth the gouernment of the Church ouer the Kings, and the princes of the earth, and holdeth opinion, that the power that Christ gaue to his Church to gouerne and to rule, is perpetuall, and that it may not be taken away from the Church by any of the kings of the earth. This opinion of his, is seconded by the Brownists, and by our brethren Ministers, that are silenced, because they claime this power as their right in the name of Iesus, and will not yeeld it to the King: as if Kings in this light of the Gospel could be hooded as they were in the dayes of darkenesse. or if Kings that shooke off but lately the yoke of the Pope, would againe put their neckes vnder the yoke of the Eldership • but so
our brethren beleeue, and so they had, as the Pope that the power to rule that was giuen to Peter and to the primitiue Church, is perpetuall: and that is may not be taken away the • e-from, nor bee with held there-from, by the k • nges of the earth without their greate sinne: and this opinion of theirs and of the Pope, is esteemed with the Christian professors of our time as the onely truth of god, as if popery, were the onely true and sound religion, and these are the enemies of this opinion of mine: the friendes of this opinion were Cranmer, Ridley, Latimer, and the rest of the Martyrs, and the whole Church of England in the daies of King Henry the eight, who with one voice did yeeld vnto the King the whole power and rule ouer the Church of England: yea the same power ouer the Church that was in Dauid Salomon, & the rest of the godly kings • uer the Church of Iuda, & to this they subscribed in the Article of the Kings supremacy, & this opiniō is that which is secōded by our Bish • ps, vpheld by our gratious Prince, subscribed vnto by vs, the peaceable, and orthodox Ministers, and now defended in this my booke: that derogateth the ruling power from the Pope, that he inioyeth t:hat derogateth the ruling power from the Church, that the Primitiue Church had: that doth not arrogate this power to any of the Ministers of the Church, but ascribeth it wholy vnto the King, as the vicegerent of Christ, for the gouerning of his earthly kingdome. Now Christian Reader whither it be better to erre with the Pope, and the abetters and friends of the Pope, • r to thinke the truth with the Church of God, Iudge thou, and Iudge as thou shalt haue cause, vvhen thou hast heard, or seene, what I haue said in this behalfe. and God giue thee a wise heart to see, and to Iudge aright.

div.head: THE APOLOGIE OF THE Conformable Ministers of England, for their Subscription to the present Church Gouernement.
div.p:
CHristian brethren, let it be lawfull for mee by your fauourable leaue, with the same words to speake vnto you, with the which the holy Apostle, once spak vnto the Christian Corinthians: saying, let a man so esteeme of vs, as of the Ministers of God, and the disposers of the manifold mysteries of Iesus Christ. And hows • euer some others esteeme of y • u & you esteeme of your selues, to be only cōscionable, and the friends of God; in that you haue offered vp your Liberties, and Liuings, for the discipline, and the ••• ertie of the Church: and doe iudge of vs that haue subscribed, to b • e but •• me seruers, and men pleasers: yet doe vs (we bese •• h you) this fauour, to th nke that we haue read, and in some part • o •
• now, the S • riptures as you doe: at the l • ast we know this, tha • i • man hath once • asted the good word of God, and the powers o • the life to come and h • th bene enlightened, and partaker of the holy Ghost: that if such a one fa • l away, it is impossible that euer he should be re •• ued by repentance. And the • ▪ i • knowing these things, wee should for filthy lucre sake, speake thing, that wee ought not, or against the open light of our consc • ence, subscribe to open, and manifest darkenesse then might you w • ll co • de • ne vs in deed: yea our owne consciences would cond • mne vs in the sight of God. But we hope to be approued of God, vnto wh •• e
iudgement seat we appeale, from so vniust iudgment of Christian men: & in the meane time, we haue labored by this our Apologie, to shew our selues approoued to your selues, and to the whole Church of God: and to let you see with how vniust iudgement, we are condemned for subscribing to the present Church Gouernment, and for entertaining the imposed ceremonies of this our English Church. And though loth, (because we would not be thought to speake for Baal,) yet from the bitternesse, and very griefe of our heart, as men weary of hearing, and bearing such things, we haue at last consented, to draw forth out of our secret bosomes, our hidden motiues, and to lay open our priuate reasons, which being secret, kept inward peace; but being not open, haue gotten no good report, And herein dealing plainely, as in the sight of God, we lay open, and vnfold our selues to the world, that our aduersaries sitting as iudge ouer this our cause, might giue sentence ouer vs, according as we shall cleare, or not cleare our selues, by this Apologie, and defence of ours: which that we might the better make, wee must remember according to their two fold accusation, to answere first, (which wee intend if God permit) for our subscription to the present Gouernment: and secondly, to answere for our taking vpon vs the vse, of the lawfull, and laudable ceremonies, that by authority a • e established in this our English Church. And first, to answere to the first, I plainely find, concerning our Church Gouernment, two diuerse sorts of people, differing in their iudgement, and man • festly opposed one against the other: the first sort whereof, are they that some call Nouelists, and some call Puritanes, but vpon what ground I know not: for mine owne part, I call them, and count them, our Christian brethren, though in this particular they differ from vs, and are men possessed with an other opinion, then we are: and the opinion of these men is, that in the Primitiue Church, there were set vp by God, as gouernours of the Church, neither Archbishops, nor Bishops: neither Archdeacons, nor Deacons: nei-Commissaries, nor Officials: neither Kings, nor Princes: for that they might haue added in like manner: but the whole sway of the Church Gouernment, was committed vnto the Minister in euery Church▪ and to certaine godly and choice men of the Church, which were called Elders, who iointly with the Ministers were to ouersee the flocke of Christ▪ to censure, and punish by excommunication, the notable, and the obstinate sinners: and to bee
custodes vtrius{que} tabulae, that is, to bee holy meanes to see, that either table of Gods law were diligently kept and obserued of the whole Church of God. Such a Gouernment (say they) was there set in the Church of God, by the spirit of God, and by the power of Iesus Christ: and such a Gouernement say they, now is to be set by the same power of God in euery particular Church of the world. And this is that godly shew, and that plausible reason of theirs, whereby we were carried very farre in our affections to imbrace, and incline to that opinion, and iudgement of theirs. Now in a contrary opinion to this, are our reuerent Bishops, the very Fathers of the Church, and the rest, which are the greatest part both of the Vniuersities, & the whole land beside: and these hold that no such Gouernment was in the Church, and yet that albeit such a Gouernement were established in the Primitiue Church, as hath by them beene spoken off: yet the same was not thereby necessarily imposed, vpon this our Church, and all other Churches of the world. Onely that it was for those times, and then necessary, when persecution oppressed the Church: but vnder a Christian prince, and in a publique we • le, imbracing from the King, to the Pesant, the Gospell of God, that it was arbitrary, and at the pleasure of the Prince to be held still, or to bee disanulled, as was most behouefull for the whole land: and this is that opinion of theirs, that (inforced better to consider) we haue looked into, and as we verily thinke vpon sounder iudgement, and vpon better, and weightier reasons we haue of late yeelded vnto: and as the truth of God together with them imbraced, and now come forth, in this our publike Apologie to answere for, against the gainesayers, and reprouers both of them, and vs. And heere (because we that desire not to be wronged by them, would in no case wrong them) we willingly yeeld vnto them this, that for the ouerthrow of this present Church Gouernement, they haue in some sort shewed, that this of ours, and the Primitiue Church Gouernment, doe not iumpe both together; nor in euery particular name, and circumstance agree: but whither the Primitiue Gouernment were perpetuall, and of necessitie to bee imposed vpon all Churches, & people of the world, as the Word and Sacraments were; in that point as we verily thinke they haue vtterly failed: and therefore we haue vtterly fallen away from them. And indeed brethren, they that will thrust vpon a land, a newe kind of Church Gouernement, and that in the name, and authority
of the Lord Iesus: They that by the authority of God, would cause the King to lay downe his power, and authority, and intertaine that which they say to be of the Lord, & to alter, and wholly to chaunge, all his pollicie Ecclesiasticall: They that will inforce the Lords, the Peeres, and the Princes of the land, which are otherwise aboue, and set ouer all, next vnder God, and the King, to submit thems • lues, not onely to be taught, but to be gouerned by their particular Ministers, & by Laymen of baser allay, though they haue the name of Elders put vpo • them: and so cause all men now to stoope to them, as once they vniustly and vnwisely did, vnto the Pope, vnder the name of Christs Vicar, and by the thunderbolt of excommunication: They that will constraine the Lord Bishops, & others interessed in the patrimony, & power of the Church, to lay down al their power, & present • ight, & that in the word of the liuing God, & by the cōmandement of the great, and euerlasting King: They that will haue all Ministers (as once Thomas of Becket foolishly did, for the vpholding of the Romish Church) together with them, for the vpholding and bringing in of the Primitiue Church Gouernment, striue against the commaundement of the King, and lay downe their liuings, their liberties, and their liues, (as once the Martyrs did, for the testimonie of the Gospell of Iesus Christ:) had neede to come mightily armed, by the two edged sword, which is the word of God, and is able indeede, and of power, to subdue all things: and from thence by demonstratiue, and vnanswerable arguments, to perswade thereunto: and to shew, that such a gouernment once there was, and that such a gouernment, being perpetually imposed vpon all people, by the liuing God, is vnder the paine, and curse of God, to be retained where it is, and intertained where it is not. For this wee hold, that wee are no • bound to refuse the present Gouernement wherein we haue beene called, and whereby wee haue beene richly blessed of God: nor necessarily to imb • ace that offered by you: nor for the imbracing thereof, nor bringing • f that in, to aduenture to open daunger, our Liues, Liberties, or Ministeries vntill you haue demonstratiuely proued, that this onely discipline, and besides it no other, is permitted, nor commanded of God, perpetually to be in vse, in all Churches, and ages for euer. Now this we must tell you brethren, that you haue not done, yea in steed of prouing this, which was your parts to haue done: hauing shewed that it was once in vse (whereupon you insist,
and wherein very eloquently, and copiously you dwell, to the possessing of the Reader, with a very full perswasion, that your assertions are grounded wholy on the word of God) hauing I say, shewed, that it was once in vse, you require vs to shew where it was first, or last, or at all abolished: which is, when you faile in prouing the affirmatiue, to put vs (which is a hard prouince indeed, and a heauy taske;) to proue t • e negatiue. Nay in requiring vs to shew, being once in vse, when it was abolished (that is so taken awa • , as that it might neuer be in vse againe▪ • is a further matter, then in equitie you ought to desire: or in reason we need to performe. Fo • hereby you manifestly go about to draw from vs a most vnchristian verdit, and an open reproofe against all the Christian Churches of the world, that heretofore haue, or at this present doe imbrace, the Primitiue Church discipline: a thing so farre from our hearts, as that it neuer once entred thereinto. No, respeake all peace vnto them, and wish them to prosper, and fare well with that their desired, and wished kind of Church Gouernment: and oh that there were a heart in you likewise, not to enuy our good, nor to trouble that peaceable estate; which by the manifest leaue, and approbation of God, we doe, by the same mercy and fauour of God, with them, inioy: which is the point that wee meane to labour in, and to shew, not that the Primitiue Church Gouernement is vtterly abolished: but that it is arbitrary, and e • ther may, or m • y not, bee retained in a Christian Kingdome: which being once openly shewed, will vtterly cleare vs that haue subscribed to this present Church Gouernment: ouerthrow your assertion, and cut the sinewes of that Ecclesiasticall discipline, that of necessity you would thrust vpon vs: and vtterly take away the maine, and 〈◊〉 ground • f your principall reason, which is this.

list.item: Such a kind of Church Gouernment • s was vsed in the Primitiue Church, • s to be •• t vp in this, • nd in all the Churches of the w • rld:
But in the • rimitiue Church, there was a speciall kind of Church Gouernement exercised by the Minister and certaine chosen Elders:
Ergo, Such a Gouernement is to bee set vp in this, and in all Churches of the world.

div.p:
The Minor part of this sillogisme, you stand very long vpon, to make the Reader beleeue, that your discipline is a part of the word and Gospell of Iesus Christ. But the Maior which is the maine part, that is false, and can haue no show out of the word, with a prettie kind of rhetorike, you shift off, and passe ouer, and
thereby leaue it open to our bare deniall. To this therefore being the onely weake part, and wanting his armour of proofe, I meane to giue an assault, and making a breach here, to enter in, and to ouerthrow that, which you hold to be your strong, and inuincible hold, and to this point, to bring the whole force of my disputation, and by strong and inuincible arguments, to let you see, that the Ecclesiasticall discipline of the Primitiue Church, vnder a Christian King, is altogether alterable, and may wholly, either be changed, or taken away.

div.head: REASON I.
div.p: NOw for the better shewing hereof, I will compare, the Gouernment of the Primitiue Church, with an other Gouernment, altogether of the same nature, and like vnto that. I meane the Iewish pollicie, euen the Gouernment of their Church combined with their kingdome, by the iudiciall law: which was giuen vnto them by God, set vp in the middest of his owne people, charged vpon them perpetually by the commandement of God, in vse with them, in the dayes of Moses, the Saint of God: and after him, in the dayes of Iosuah, the faithfull seruant of God: and after them in the dayes of all the Iudges of the land, and a • ter them, in the dayes of all the Kings of Iuda, which sprung vp successiuely one after another: euen vntill the vtter dissolution, and desolation of the Iewish Empire: all which notwithstanding, it is confessed by our enemies themselues, that this ciuill pollicie, and Iewish Gouernment, is not thereby of necessity, to bee brought in, and to be set vp, in this kingdome of ours, & in all other kingdomes of the world: and if a man from hence should reason thus, and say.
div.q: Such a kind of Pollicie, and Ciuill Gouernement as was in the land of Iurie, set vp there by God himselfe, and in vse for so many hundred yeeres together: such a kinde of Pollicie, and Ciuill Gouernement, ought to be in this our land, and kingdome.
div.p:
Would not trow you, euery reasonable man, easily perceiue, how feeble, and weake this argument, and reason of his were? now altogether like vnto this was the Ecclesiasticall Pollicie of the Primitiue Church, which was in like manner giuen from Iesus Christ, set vp in the middest of the Christian Gentiles, Charged
vpon them for the vpholding of the persecuted Church, in vse with them, in the dayes of Paul, and other the blessed Apostles of Christ, and after them in vse in the Church of God for many hundred yeeres: euen during the whole time of the persecution of the Church, now he that from hence reasoneth thus.
Such a kind of gouernment was in the Primitiue Church, Ergo,
Such a kind of Gouernement ought to be in our Church:
Reasoneth as hee that saith,
Such a kind of Gouernment was in the Common-weale of Iurie, Ergo,
Such a kind of Gouernement ought to be in our Common-weale.

Now by the weakenesse of this latter, you may easily perceiue the falsenesse of the former. And indeed, if a Gouernment Ciuill, g • uen by God himselfe charged vpon, and vsed by his own people, be notwithstanding alterable, and to vs altogether arbitrary, and a matter wholly indifferent: Then by the same reason, a Gouernment Ecclesiasticall, set vp by the spirit of God, and vsed in the Primitiue Church, is to vs in like manner arbitrary, and may be vsed, or not vsed, as best fitteth our Church, and Common weale.

div.head: REASON. II.
div.p:
ANd yet further, I looke into the Iewish sacrifices: which being a part of the Ceremoniall law, together with the whole, were charged vpon the people of the Iewes, by the commaundement of God, in the top of mount Sinai: from that time forth, to be in vse, and exercised, of all Israel, from time, to time; from age, to age; throughout their generations for euer: all which notwithstanding, without reproofe, and that in the presence of God that dwelt in the cloud, that would not reprooue them for that their Sacrifices were not alwayes before him: and in the presence of Moyses the faithfull seruant of God, and in the presence of Aaron, the Priest of God: by the space of fortie yeeres in the wildernesse, (as Stephen sheweth in the Actes of the Apostles) they were wholly, and altogether omitted. Whence I gather, that if the Sacrifices of the law, which were a part of the visible seruice of God, being giuen, (as Moyses well saw) for the setled estate of the Church, might (without speciall licence, the generall commaundement being to the contrary) in the vnstaied, and wandering

estate of the Church, be lawfully omitted: then by the like reason, on the contrary side, may a speciall kinde of Church Gouernment, (being no publique part of Gods worship, and but onely a fence, or a hedge for the same) giuen by God himselfe, in, and for the dayes of the troubled estate of the Church, in the peaceable estate of the Church, vnder a Christian King, be wholly omitted: much more altered, and changed, at the p easure of the King, to the fittest estate, and the best b • hoofe, of the whole land and Church: euen as those citie walles, whic • in the dayes of warre, are diligently repaired, watched, and warded▪ may in the dayes of peace, be regarded lesse: yea wholly at the pleasure of the King be demolished, and vtterly ouerthrowen. I will not apply the similitude, onely this I say, that Poperie knew well how to abuse the edge of the Ecclesiasticall sword, that in the dayes of the Church warre, was put into, and after that le • t in hand, to the cutting of the Emperours throat, to the paring away, and impairing of his authoritie, and the vtter subduing of him: and to the repairing, or rather building vp of the Popes Supremacie: the Lord giue euery man a wise heart to applie it, and to consider what I say.

div.head: REASON III.
div.p: ANd here because they precisely presse vpon vs the iumping with the Primitiue Gouernment, I would faine know, which they hold to be the Primitiue Gouernment. Doe they hold the Presbitery that is receiued of the r • fo • med Churc • es, & which they desire to be the Primitiue Gouernement? I • so they hold, they deceiue themselues, exceeding much, and all their followers. For the Primitiue Gouernment was in aristocra • ie▪ the chiefe ruling power being in t • e hands of the chief men of the Church, as the Apostles of C • rist, and the Euangeli •• s: but theirs is a meere democratie: the rule of the Church b •• ing equally partaked of their lay Elders, and Church Ministers all equall, as they hold, in power to gouerne the Church▪ their Gouernment therefore is not the Primitiue Gouernment, but the Gouernment of the Apostles: with which our gouernm • nt is more neerely proportioned then theirs: but they refuse that as the Primitiue, lest ours should be more like to the Primitiue, then that of theirs.

And that which more is, they would make vs beleeue, that that of theirs was in vse vnder the godly Kings of Iuda, and established
by Moyses vnder the law, if it be so; why doe they not call their Gouernment, the Gouerment of the Iewish Church, rather then the Gouernment of the Primitiue Church? why doe they not call it aswell the Gouernment of Moyses, as the Gouernment of Christ? and the Gouernment of the law, aswell as a parcell of the Gospell? but they are afraid that this name would signifie vnto men the abolishing, and determination thereof, aswell as the chaunge of the other Iewish Pollicie.

But to come to my intended purpose, I find diuers sorts of Church Gouernments, & all of them with times changeable, the first Gouernment was that of the Iewish Church vnder the godly Kings, who (without Presbetry of the reformed Churches) gouerned their Churches in all godlines, & peace, only by their authority ciuill: and this their Gouernment was wi • h the peaceable dayes of the Church chaunged into the Gouernment vnder the Sannedrim, who in the dayes of the heathen Kings (that gouerned the weale publike, but persecuted the church) rose vp to gouerne the dispised church, by another, & a new kind of pollicy: only, & meerely Ecclesiasticall & here a little stay with me, and consider what chaunged t • e first Gouernm • nt Temporall of the Kings, into the second Gouernement Ecclesiastical, vnder the Sannedrim, was it not peaceable dayes turned into persecution? & then why may not persecution turned into peaceable dayes, change the second, into the first, the Ecclesiastical Gouernment of the Church, vnder the eldership (which was that of the Sannedrim) into the ciuill Gouernment of the Church (which is vnder the godly kings?)

But yet further I find after the Sannedrim, another, and a third kind of Church Gouernment rising vp instead of th • abolished, and taken away: and that was the Gouernment of the Primitiue Church: where the affaires of euery Church, were gouerned by the Eldership of the Church, as by the vnder officers of the Church: the Eldership was gouerned by the Euangelists: and the Euangelists by the Apostles of Christ, and this is properly called the Primitiue Gouernment.

This third kind, which was the Primitiue Gouernment, was with the next age changed: For the Apostles were taken away. and the Euangelists taken away, and of the Gouernm • nt remained not • ing but the very taile, and baser part thereof, which was the vnder Eldership, and instead of the Apostles, and Euangelists, rose vp Bishops to gouerne the eldership, & the succeeding Churches.
And therefore which way soeuer I looke, I see with the times all Church Gouernem nts chaungeable, yea chaunged: that of the Kings was chaungeable, yea chaunged: that of the Sannedrim changeable, yea chaunged; that of the Primitiue Church (which is the point I stand vpon, and maintaine in this my booke) changable, yea changed; and why may not the l • tter, wh • ch is but the taile of the former, be chaunged, as well as the former? why may not the one halfe, as well as the other halfe? the whole, as well as the part? the Elders as well as the Apostles, and the Euangelists of Christ? or what vnchangeable nature haue the Elders, aboue the Apostles, & Euangelists of Christ? or this peece more then all the other Gouernments had? All this speaketh, that Church Gouernments are things different, and indifferent, according to the times, and that they must all serue the times: and the times, and they, serue the Churches: and not the Churches serue them.

And here obserue with me, that if the officers of the Primitiue Church (who onely might administer the Church censures) b • e alterable: then the censures also of the Primitiue Church, are alterable as well as the officers are.

div.head: REASON IIII.
div.p:
BVt here, I heare them say, that God in not sufficing of other, in stead of the former Apostles, and Euangelists, hath by his speaking worke shewed his pleasure, and will; for the abolishing of that kind of Gouernment, and leauing onely Pastors, and Elders to abide in the Church, hath left them as examples, and patternes for vs, thereby to fashion vnto our selues, and to forme for euer, the Gouernment of all our Churches. Very well, by the same reason I shew, that the Lord not sufficing in many Churches of our land, able Ministers, and godly Elders for the Gouernment of their particular Churches, hath by that his manifest, and reuealing speaking worke, in like manner, shewed his pleasure, for the abolishment of their rule, and Gouernement in those particul • r Churches. And then if God by his speaking worke, hath let the world see, that he will not haue these particular Churches to be gouerned by Pastors, and ruling Elders, as the Primitiue Church was, then from thence we can farther see, by this light, that God hath giuen from heauen, that the same is the reason of the whole, and the part, and if it may by Gods oracle, and voice, speaking in his worke, be changed in some Churches:
then as well in other some, and so by consequent in euery Church of the land. For God speaketh as well by his worke, as by his word, and this word of God in his worke going before, and speaking, and directing vs, is euer to be followed, and hearkened vnto, when there is no direct commandement vnto vs for the contrary, as the case standeth in this matter now in hand, as we presently meane to shew, if God permit.

div.head: REASON V.
div.p:
ANd here I might stand to shew how many things may alter the Gouernment of God; and first I find that it may be altered by a contrary dispensation from God: as the law of Moyses by the comming of Christ, and by the establishment of the Gospel of God: secondly it may be altered by the worke of God, abolishing it quite and cleane, as the Gouernement by the Apostles. Thirdly by necessitie, which maketh many things lawfull, which were otherwise vtterly vnlawfull, for that made it lawfull for Dauid to eate of the shew bread, and for the Disciples to plucke the eares of corne, on the Sabboth day. Fourthly, by the troubles of the land, and Church, in which case it was lawfull for the Machabees to fight on the Sabboth, and to breake euen a morall commaundement. Now what if I should step one step farther, and say, that it might vnder a godly prince be chaunged also by the consent of the land, and Church? fearing great hurt by retaining of it, (which they euidently sawe in the Popish Church, armed with the Ecclesiasticall power) seeing also much inconuenience thereby, in those places of the world, where it was imbraced: and lastly, that it could nor stand with the Kings Supremacy, and the present estate, without a wonderfull, and a dange • ous alteration, and chaunge: which are reasons altogether equiualent, either to present troubles, or to vrging necessitie: And reason in this case, as once Christ reasoned in another, not altogether vnlike vnto this, & say? that pollicies were made for men, and not men for pollicies: that Gouernments of lands, and Churches, were made for the vpholding of lands, and Churches: and not lands, and Churches, for the vpholding of Gouernements. And that all Gouernments whatsoeuer, must of necessitie giue place to the health, and good estate of their land and Church: and what if I should subscribe to this position? were I (thinke you) worthy of so great blame, as is laid
vpon me and others, for doing so? But I meane not to stand vpon this, we haue other, and other manner of reasons, to beare vs on, and to iustifie our subscription, then this is, although for mine owne part, I see not how to answere this.

div.head: REASON VI.
div.p:
BVt to omit these generals, and to come to the particular Church Gouernement in question: I see they vrge the example, but I looke into the co • maundement, that must warrant, and ground the example: and I finde in all the word, not one word, for the perpetuity thereof. In the fourth Chapter to the Ephesians, verse 11.12.13. The Apostle reckoneth vp precisely, the particular officers, that Christ hath giuen vnto his body, which is the Church, for the edifying thereof, vntill wee come to a pe • fect man, euen vnto the full measure of Christ, full growen: which onely shall be at the resurrection of the iust, and the officers that there hee mentioneh, so long to endure, are first Apostles, then Prophets, then Euangelists, then Pastors, and Doctors: and these are all that there are mentioned, to continue in their succession, vntill the appe • ring of Christ. As for ruling Elders, it seemeth the Apostle had forgotten himselfe: for hee m • keth of them no mention at all. In the Epistle to Timothie (a chiefe ruler in the Church) where hee professedly teacheth him how to behaue himselfe in the Church of God, and instructeth him in the whole estate▪ and affaires thereof, and how hee ought to gouerne, and rule it, hee speaketh not one word, for to charge vpon him the perpetuitie of the Eldershippe. In the sixt Chapter the eleuenth, twelfth, and thirteenth verse: he chargeth him to follow righteousnesse, godlinesse, faith, loue, patience, meekenesse, to fight the good sight of faith, &c. And concerning this commaundement, hee saith, I charge thee in the sight of God, who quickneth all things, that thou keepe this commaundement without spot, and vnblameable, vntill the appearing of our Lord Iesus Christ. But speaking of the ruling Elder, and giuing vnto him by his authoritie double honour, hee chargeth him not, as hee did in the case before, to obserue that commaundement without spot, and vnchaungeably, vntill the appearing of our Lord Iesus Christ: much lesse doth
hee commaund the perpetuall setting of him in the Church •• God. Onely hee dooth acknowledge vnto him double ho
• our, while hee is in being, and ruleth well in the Church: but • ee doeth not acknowledge him worthy to abide for euer; • nd to beare rule in the Church of God for euer. And yet, (if e
•• r) here, (remembring the ruling Elder) had beene a fit place, t • at would haue required the Apostle to • aue giuen this commaundement vnto Timothie. I read the second Epistle to Timo
•• e, where the Apostle might haue remembred what hee had • orgotten in the former, but I finde not a word for that poynt •• all that second Epistle of his. I read diligently the Epistle to
• itus, whom Paul left for that purpose in Crete, that hee might •• ll and fully order the Church there: I finde that hee com
•• undeth him to ordaine Ministers i • the Churches that wan
• ed. But hee giueth no charge for the ordering of the ruling E • ders: no, not so much as any commaundement, for the euer
• asting abyding of them in the Church of God. Neither doe I •• de in all the Scriptures, that are able sufficiently to teach the • hole will of God, any commandement at all, for the euerlasting continuance • f the consistorian Eldership. Now brethren, for the Lord to will the perpetuity of the ruling Eldership, & not to reueale his will for the perpetuitie thereof; is not answerable to the ordinarie manner of God, who neuer spareth in expresse wordes to reueale his will, for the perpetuitie of that, which hee is pleased to haue perpetuall in his Church. In the twelfth Chapter of Exodus, and the fourteenth verse, when he doth for euer establish the Passeou • r, he saith in expresse words: this day shall be vnto you a remembrance, and yee shall keepe it an holy Feast vnto the Lord throughout your generations yee shall keepe it an holy Ordinance for euer. Againe, in the foure and twenty Chapter of Exodus, the • i eteene and twent • e verse, wh • n hee will tie A • ron to the perpetuall vse of the brest-plate • n his appearing before God, hee saith: so shall Aaron beare the names of the children of I • raell in the brest-plate of Iudgement, vppon his heart, when hee goeth into the holy place, for a remembrance continually before the Lord. And the like charge is in the next verse for the continuall putting on of the V •• , and Thu • m • m, when hee appeareth before the L • d con • inually. And againe, in the same Chapter, speaking of the holy apparrell of Aaron,
and of his seede, he saith: this shall be a law for euer vnto him, and to his seede after him. And againe in the next Chapter, verse 23. establishing the Priesthood for euer vnto Aaron, and his seed, he saith: and Aaron and his seed, shall haue it by a statute foreuer of the children of Israel. In like manner▪ when hee doth ordaine the perpetuitie of the Morning, and Euening sacrifices: Exod 29.38. The perpetuitie of the incense: Exod. 30.8. The washing of the Priestes hands, and f • ete: Exod. 30.21. The sweet oyle: ver. 31. The vse of the Sabb • th. Exod. 31.13.17. In expresse words hee commandeth the perpetuitie thereof, the time would faile me, and it would be needlesse, to bring forth all the particular places of Scripture, for the confirmation of this point: in these, being but a few, you may see the trueth of the whole, and how euer the Lord vseth to tie to a perpetuall ordinance, a perpetuall commandement. And this being in all other things the ordinary course of the Lord, doth it not seeme strange and wonderfull in your eyes, that the Lord should not in like manner by a plaine commaundement, for the perpetuitie of your Church Gouernment, establish, and set it vp for euer? doth it not amaze you, and make you dumbe, and mute, that the Lord should be vtterly mute, and silent in this point: and yet vsually in all other perpetuall ordinances, vse so many, and so plaine words, for the perpetuitie of them? Pardon vs Christian brethren, if we dare not auouch it to be perpetua • l, when the Lord doth not speake it, if we suspect it not to hee his will, when himselfe doth not say that it is his will, if we be suspicious, where the Lord is silent: if we doubt, where the Lord is dumbe: if we make no conscience to obey, when you can shew no: we see, any commandement, which we are tyed to obey. And therefore to conclude this point, I say of Ecclesiasticall Discipline, as once Paul said of an other indifferent thing; namely of marriage, that concerning this thing, neither I, nor you, haue any commandement at all: and therefore, though as faithfull men, you may giue councell to entertaine that, yet you can giue, in the name of God, no commandement so to doe. But as Paul left marriage, so must you leaue the Primitiue Church Discipline at libertie, and hold it to bee free for the Church peaceably to receiue, or not to receiue it at all.

div.head: REASON. VII.
div.p:
ANd that which is yet a farther point, the Scripture hath not precisely defined, what sinnes the ruling Elders of the Church are to intermeddle in, as whither they are to lay the cen
•• re of excommunication vpon murder, theft debt, rebellion, and such like sins as were seuerely punished euē by the heathē Kings, and whereof the Scriptures, and all succeeding ages haue giuen not any one example: or whither they were to draw the sword of excommunication onely against adulterers, couetous persons, extortioners, railers, idolaters, and prophaners of the Sabboth: which being esteemed the lesser sinnes, were neglected of the • eathen Kings, but seuerely punished of the Church of God: as • ppeareth both by expresse commaundement, and manifest ex
•• ples in the word of God. Neither is it plainely reuealed in the Scripture, whither onely the Minister, or iointly with the Mini
•• er, the Lay be to Elder minister excommunication: if the Lay •• der may excommunicate, then how is that saying of Christ spo
•• n onely to the Ministers, whose sinnes ye remit, they are remit
• ed; and whatsoeuer ye bind in earth, is bound in heauen? if he • ay not excommunicate, how is he a gouernour Ecclesiasticall, that hath not the power of the Ecclesia • ticall sword to gouerne, a • d rule withall? and thus the Scripture hath left vs in a doubt, •• at hath neede of an Apostle to determine: neither is the time 〈◊〉 the Lay Elders rule, limited by the Scripture, as whether it be to • edetermined yeerely, or wh • ther it bee to endure his whole life. And thus hath the Scripture, not determining the office of the • ay Elder, as it hath the office of Aaron, the King, the Pastor, the Deacon and the aged Widowes, made vs of necessitie to doubt of •• and to suspect that it was not the pleasure of the Lord, that such • one should bare for euer office in the Church, whose office for •• e Church is so barely, or rather not at all, in many points determined. And surely it seemeth an incre •• ible thing to me, that the Lord should set an o • ficer perpetually in the Church, and not •• e him nor shew him his office, in plaine and open words, pre
•• el • determined.

And that which more is, the Lord hath not vouchsafed to set •• m forth no, not by his particular g • ifts, n • r what manner of •• n he ought to be, th •• should beare the office of the Church Elder. In the first Epi •• le • o Timothie, Chapte • 3.1. the Lord hath
particularly described the Bishops by their seuerall guifts: and so he hath described the speciall guifts of the Deac •• s, and of the Church widowes, Chap. 3.8. & 5.2. Where also had bene a fit place to haue described in like manner, the guif • s of the • ay Elder. But the Lord by his spirit in deepe silence passeth ouer him, and toucheth not his required guifts, no not in one word. In the Epistle to Titus, Chap. 1.7. The Apostle te • eth vs what manner of man the Elder must bee: but least we should take him to speake of the lay Elder, hee presently vnfoldeth hims • l • e, and saith, for a Bishop must be without blame, &c. And here I m • ke the challenge to all on the contrary side, if they can to shew, where the lay Elder is described by his particular guifts: which I know already they shall neuer be able to doe. Now whence was it tr • w ye, that the Lord doth not vnfolde vnto vs, nor set downe the the particular guifts of the lay ruling Elders? was it thinke you of forgetfulnesse, or of contempt, or of neglect? was it no matter what manner of person he were, that beate office, a • d rule in the Church of God? God forbid that we should esteeme so. What was it then? Surely I can in equitie, and reason, see no other reason of it, then this: that the Lord did foresee, that he was, but for a season to endure: euen till Kings spr • nge vp that should according to their office rule the Church in all the wayes of God, as once without the kings, the ruling Elders did. And that this was the meaning of the Lord, I gather by the reasons of our aduersaries, that argue the perpetuitie of the Deacon, and the rest of the Church officers, because they are set into the Church, with their particular guifts, and call • ngs from G • d. Whence I reason, that if the Pastors, and Deacons, being set out in their guifts, are thereby set vp in the Church for euer: then on the contrary, ruling Elders being not set out in their guifts, are not to be set vp for euer, and that of necessitie, in euery particul • r Church: and then, if the rulers be needles: the rule it selfe, the Primitiue Gouernement is needlesse in like manner, as well as they are.

div.head: REASON VIII.
div.p:
BVt omitting these things: I come to c • nsider the persons that were in the Primitiue Church gouerned, by Ecclesiastical Discipline and I find them to be all brethren: • ll b • gotten of one, and the same seede of the word: all Saints, as • he Apostle calleth them: all called by the Gospell of God: and separated from the
multitude of the vnbeleeuing Gentils; and ioyned vnto the Church of God: all open professors therof, and such as had at the least, a temporary faith. All these voluntarily gaue themselues first vnto God, and then vnto the Apostles, and to the Church of God, to be gouerned by that. And vnto these men, the Ecclesiasticall censure of Excommunication, and the power of the Church seemed to be, and was indeede vnto them, of very great power, to keepe them in awe, to restraine them from sinne, and to leade them forth in all the right wayes of God. For these men to be seperate from the brethren, whom they loued as their own soules: to be cast out of the Church, where one day was better then a thousand else-where; where to be a doore-keeper, was better then to be a king in another place, was a heauy cen • ure, and a grieuous punishment indeede; for these men to be counted as Heathen, whom Christ, and themselues counted as dogges: to be giuen by excommunication vnto the Diuell: to haue their sinnes bound in heauen, as the Church had bound them in the earth, was a terrible coertion, and a punishment in their iudgement equall to hell, and vnto eternall death; and therefore as bad, nay farre worse then temporall death. But this censure of the Church, that was to the brethren, & vnto the Church so terrible, & so fearful a thing, was to the Gentiles, and to the rest that were without, a most contemptible, and dispised thing: it concerned not, nor touched their bodies; and they, of a certainty did not know, that they had soules, it was the binding of them in their sinnes, that were slaues, and vtterly sold vnto sinne: it was a spiritual punishment, and they were carnall men: for them to be shut out of the Church, that despised the Church, and persecuted it: for them to be seperated from the brethren, that of themselues, did seperate themselues from the brethren, and did hate them, and s • e from them, as from a Toade, or a Snake, was a most absurd thing. In a word, that which to the beleeuers, was a censure as heauy as death, to these men, was not so much as a slea-biting; and therefore these men were not by the Iudgement of the Apostle, lyable, to the gouernment of the Church. I wrote vnto you (saith the Apostle, in his Epistle to the Corinthians. 5. ver. 9.10 11, 12, 13.) that ye should not company together, with fornicators, and not altogether with the fornicators of this wo • ld, or with the couetous, or with extortioners, or with idolaters, for then ye must go out of the world. But now I haue written vnto you, that ye companie
not together; if any that is called a brother be a fornicator, or couetous, or an idolater, or a rayler, or a drunkard, or an extortioner with such a one eate not; for what haue I to doe, to iudge them also which are without? Do not you iudge them that are within? But God shall iudge them that are without: where the Apostle plainely sheweth, that the censure of excommunication, did not appertaine to the despising Gentiles, nor the wicked of the world, that were without, and were not, nor could not bee called brethren: for these men were to bee left to the fearefull iudgements of God onely, hauing none from the Church that they regarded; nor none from the King that he inflicted: and therfore he permitteth none to be gouerned by the Church, but them that were first within; and secondly were called brethren: so the censure of excommunication fitteth none in the Apostles iudgment, but them that were within. Now it is plaine, that the greatest parte of our Church, are no such manner of men: they came not voluntarily vnto the Church, but came by compulsion: they were not specially called, but turned Christians with the King: they haue not so much as a temporary faith, but are drowned as deepe in vnbeleefe, as the very Gentiles were: they make not so much as a profession of the Gospell, but despise the professors and the profession, as much as euer the Gentiles did: they are some of them as grosly ignorant, as euer the Gentiles were: they delight in sinne, and are as prophane, as euer the Gentiles were: they despise the brethren, the Church, and the censures of the Church, as much as euer the Gentiles did: In a word, in name they are Christians, but in deede, and truth, they are Gentiles: and if wee may rightly count him a heathen, that is excōmunicate by the Church: much more may we esteeme so of him, that is excommunicate ipso facto, as the law speaketh: That is, that of himselfe, by his notable sinnes, without the immediate authority of the Church, is an excommunicate person. Now such men as these; who can cal them brethren? And therfore to punish these men by seperating them from the Church, that hold it a punishment to be tyed & brought vnto the Church: to cast out these men from the Church, that desire to be lawfully absent from the Church: to seperate these by excommunication from the brethren, that seperate themselues from them, and flie from them, as from a serpent, and vtterly despise excommunication; is in the iudgement of our aduersaries, a very vnfit thing: and therefore if in the Apostles iudgement, the
censure of excōmunication (the very sword of Ecclesiastical gouernment) pertained only vnto brethren; and the greatest part of our Church are none such: then I cannot see, how that gouernmēt can be thrust of necessity vpon such a people. I confesse, that our prophane men are worthy, and fittemen to be excommunicate, but excommunication fitteth them not, nor is not worthy of them: it is not fitte to giue holy things vnto dogges; not to cast pearles vnto swine; not to set vp the holy gouernment Ecclesiasticall, as vpon a Stage to be made contemptible, and despised of the greatest sort of men. And if it be not now fit in the hand of the great men of the Church, armed with the power of the king, and countenanced by him; and that in the eyes of our aduersaries: how would it be despised among our prophane persons, in the hands of the poore Ministers, and baser men of the Church? And if now it fitteth not our estate, by their owne confession; how would it fit the estate of the Primitiue Church Gouernement? And therefore to hold that such a Gouernement, by the will, and commandement of God, is to be set vp ouer such a people, as by the expresse will and commaundement of God, are exempted from that gouernement; is to hold contraries, things impossible, monstrous absurdities, in very reason: and therefore to conclude this point; I hold, that if there were now (as the Brownists haue begunne, and as it was in the Primitiue Church) a seperation made of the brethren, from the rest of the Prophane; these brethren which would be but a poore few, a small number God wot, might be gouerned by Ecclesiasticall Discipline, with more reason: but the rest, which are the most parte of the land, were vtterly vncapable thereof; and therefore to tie to a people, mixed together, the discipline Ecclesiasticall, is not according to the Apostles rule; nor euer sprang of the holy spirit of God: as there is one King, one Church, one people of all; so there must be a gouernement fitted for all, that may feare all, Christians in name, and Christians in truth; that may gouerne all, and that may be reuerenced of al sorts of men: which cannot be (as the case, and people stand) the gouernement Ecclesiasticall.

div.head: REASON IX.
div.p:
ANd yet further, I looke vpon the persons that did gouerne, and bare the whole sway in the Primitiue Church, and I find
that the principal ruler there▪ was the preaching Elder: which was the Minister of the Church. And I find • that it is no essentiall part of the Ministers function, to rule the people with the sword Ecclesiasticall: and that the Lord vnder the word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , which is to feede the flocke, hath not giuen a necessary, and essentiall power to the Church, to rule, and to gouerne the same, for euer. For if to rule be as essentiall to the Minister, as it is to preach, and to minister the Sacraments, then it is as notable a sinne in the Ministers to omit ruling, as it is to omit preaching, then let them looke to this.

Then the Apostle tha • charged Timothie as hee would answere before God, and his blessed Christ, to preach the word, should also haue charged as earnestly vpon him, the like diligence, and care, in ruling the slocke.

Then would Christ also in like manner haue charged his Disciples, to go out into all the world, and to preach and to Baptise, and to rule, and gouerne the Church also: which yet it is plaine that he did not.

If to rule be of the essence of the Minister, then the same power being iointly, and in equall manner, in the lay Elder, the name of the Minister, (which is euer giuen by the form • , and essentiall part) must be giuen to the lay Elder: yea, and if a part of the essentiall function of the Min • stery, bee essentiall to the lay Elder, and doe sticke, and abide really in him, then must also the whole essence, and the forme it selfe of the Minister essentially dwell in the lay Elder, for the forme cannot be diuided: nor suscipere magis, aut minus: and then by consequent the lay Elder, shall bee made a Clergie man, and a lay man, at the same instant, which to hold, is too absurde and grosse.

To punish sinne is an essentiall part of the Kings office: if thou doe euill (saith the Apostle to the Romanes, Chap 13.4.) Feare, for the King beareth not the sword in vaine. For he is the Minister of God to take vengeance on him, that doth euill. Whence it appeareth that to punish sinne, is essentiall to the King, and therefore but accidentall to the Ministers, except you will haue all ministers, as Melch • sedeth, to be Priests and Kings.

The Priests vnder the Law, were full Priests; and yet they neuer had authoritie to rule, or gouerne the Church, nor to punish sinne by any censure at all. Neither did they euer intermeddle
therewith; vntill the kingly power was taken from among their tribes and put into the hands of strangers, that did not punish sinne according to the law of God.

Yea, Iesus Christ, as he was a Minister of the circumcision, and but a Priest onely, by vertue of that office alone, neuer tooke vpon h • m power, to rule the Church. And therefore, neither did he inte • meddle in diuiding the inheritance, (being thereunto r • ques • ed) betweene two brethren: neither did he condemne to death the • ou an taken in adultery: neither did he establish, before hee • as seated in his kingdome, that gouernment of the Church, that he set vp afterward. In a word it is confessed of all, that to go
• e • ne t • e Church, doth belong to the princely; and therefore not • nto the Priestly office of Iesus Christ, and therefore if it belong • ot vnto the office of Christ, as hee is a Priest, to gouerne the Church: I cannot see how it can belong to the Ministers of Chr • st, by vertue of their ministeriall function: except wee hold •• e Priesthood of the seruants, to be more ample, and large, then the Priesthood of their Lord, and master was: which to hold, I • old, to be too absurde, and grosse. I conclude therefore, that as •• e kingly office of Christ, is not essentiall to the ministery: so •• e ruling office to gouerne the Church, is not essentiall, but one
• y accidentall thereunto: and therefore may bee absent from •• em, or present with them, without any hurt or wrong vnto them at all: and that it is no perpetuall function, euerlastingly adioyned to the Ministerie, and an ordinary thing, appeareth: • or • hat the Priests vnder the law were neuer at all possessed thereof • ordinary daies For that the Apostles of Christ, for many daies, • ere not indu • d with this ruling power: and for that Christ as he •• s an ordinarie Minister, neuer intermedled there with. It is • ame therefore, that it was not in the ministers of the Church, •• er an essentiall, or an ordinary matter: but only a braunch of the kingly power of Christ that extraordinarily, (by reason that •• dinarie • ouerners could not be had) was deriued from Christ, • o the Ministers of Christ, by reason of the present necessitie. And therefore, that is was to endure but for a season in them: euen vntill the ordinary, which is the godly king; • ight be set up in the Church of God. And therefore was then to bee de
••• mined, when kings became Christians: and neuer after that, • th • m, to be held as a matter of necessitie. And as for the word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , as it signifieth to gouerne, and to rule: so it is most •• properly
applied to the king, and therefore Homer in his Iliades, vsually calleth Agamemnon,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that is the ruler, & the prince of the people. But as it signifieth to feede, as the shepheard feedeth the flocke: so it is most properly appertaining vnto the Ministers. To rule, and to preach, is a double worke, and therefore the Apostle tied to the ruling preacher, double honour: the honour of a Priest, and the honour of the prince of the people: both which the Pope still vnlawfully challengeth to himselfe vnder, and against the Christian Emperour. But for our Ministers, it were more seemely with vs, in peace, and humilitie to want it: then contentiously, I will not say ambitiously, vnder a Christian King, with the Pope to pursue it. And seeing they see it to be a part of the princely, and no part of the Priestly office of Christ: how is it, that they doe not see it to bee much lesse any part of their Priestly, or ministeriall function? and being they see it to be no part of their ministeriall office, but a part of the Kingly office of Christ, which is put ouer to the Kings and Princes of the Church: how is it, that not contented with their ministeriall function, they desire, nay dare, to take vpon themselues, and intermeddle with a Kingly office, and incroach vpon the office of the King, whereunto (it being no part of their calling) they haue no extraordinary calling by God, in these our dayes of peace, nor ordinarie, by the Church by God? And being they see it to be a matter accidentall, befalling the minister extraordinarily, as the fittest man to gouerne the persecuted Church, in the absence, and totall want of the Christian King: how is it, that they see it not as an accident of that nature, to be lawfully absent from them, vnder a godly King? And then if vnder a godly King, it may lawfully be absent from the Minister, that claimeth a speciall interest therein: much more may it be lawfully absent from the inferior flocke, and the lay people, from out of whom the lay Elders were taken: and therefore can claime a lesser interest therein, then their superiour Ministers: which are in this case euery way priuiledged aboue them. If then it may bee wanting in the Minister and in his flocke, then it may be wanting in that one Church, then in euery one; and if it may be wanting in the parts, then the same being the reason of the whole, and the parts, it may be wholy wanting in the whole Church, that is gouerned by a godly King.

div.head: REASON. X.
div.p:
ANd yet further, I looke into the procreant cause, that first brought forth Ecclesiasticall Discipline, & I find that to be •• e want of godly kings, and the want of care, and iustice, in the • eathen Kings: & so by consequent, the meere necessitie of such Gouernment to be established, first brought it into the Church • f God. For in the dayes of Dauid, Salomon, Ezekias, Iosias, and or
• inarily of all the Kings of Iudah, the Sannedrim, that is, the • uling Councell of Elders, and excommunication, the very sword and power Ecclesiasticall, was not so much as once named, much • esse in vse in the Church, by any commaundement from God: but all sinnes were there, and then punished, by no Ecclesiasticall, • ut by the ciuill magistrate, and by power meerely ciuill, according to the Law of Moyses. But when persecution raged in the Iewish Church, when the kingdome was departed from Iudah, and a law-giuer from betweene his legges, when straungers rose vp, & bore rule, that feared not God, nor looked to the execution of iustice, according to the law of God: then for want of other Iustices, and Iusticers, rose vp the Sannedrim: to bridle by the censures of the Church, (which onely were left free for them lawfully to vse) the lesser sinnes so accounted: for as for the greater which were punished by the Kings of the Gentiles, them they intermedled not with. Then wee read that the high Priests had determined to vse excommunication, (a thing neuer before heard of among the Iewes) against them that beleeued in Christ. Whence it appeareth that Ecclesiasticall Discipline sorted not with godly and Christian Kings, that it stood not with the peaceable estate of the Church, and that it was no ordinary kinde of Gouernement: but altogether extraordinarie, accompaning the troubled, and persecuted estate of the Church. And as it neuer was in vse during the time of the godly Kings: so neither could it, nor should it haue beene in vse, had the like godly rulers still carried the sway in the Iewish Church. For that pollicie of God that was for the former times, and vnder the former kings, all sufficient for the absolute Gouernement of the Iewish estate: should haue bene vnder the like, for after times, as suffiicient for the absolute gouerning of them: and therefore being as sufficient for those latter, as for the former times, it should haue bene as needlesse in the last dayes, as it was in the first: and therefore
as well haue bene wanting in the latter dayes, as it was in the former: and so, as a needlesse Gouernement, in the full light of the former all sufficient, haue beene still put out, and wholly wanting in the Ecclesiasticall estate of the Iewes.

And yet further it is confested by our brethren, that the Ecclesiasticall Gouernement by them so desired, is in effect the same, that the Iewish persecuted Church, gouerned by the Sanneorita, first brought into vse: which being so, plainely sheweth, that the Ecclesistaical Discipline was not first brought into the Church by the power of Iesus Christ. Neither was it then set vp as a parcell of the Kingdome of Christ. Neither was held as any part of the Gospell of Christ: for it was brought into the Church before the father had giuen all power to his sonne in heauen, and in earth, before hee had receiued as yet the kingdome. Yea before the dayes of the Gospell: yea before Christ Iesus was as yet come in the flesh. And therefore it was not brought into the Church, first by Christ as our brethren would seeme to beleeue, and perswade vs with them to beleeue, as the power of Iesus, for the perpetuall Gouernement of his kingdome the Church: but it was first brought in by the Iewish Church, in the mere want of the other Gouernement of God, by the Gentile Kings by strong hand with-held. Seeing therefore that this Ecclesiasticall Discipline was neuer brought in by Moyses, the first law-giuer: nor yet at the first by Christ, the second law-giuer: nor neuer in vse in all the dayes of the godly Iewish kings: no nor neuer should haue beene in vse in all their peaceable estate: And in that it came first into the Church in the persecuted estate thereof, and when all godly kings were vtterly taken away and wanting: It must needes follow, that onely very necessitie, and the want of godly kings to gouerne the Church, first, brought it into the Church of God.

And this will the better appeare, if we looke into the Primitiue Church, where this Ecclesiasticall Discipline was in the greatest vse: for in that it will more manifestly appeare, that meere necessity there set it vp; for there was thē a Church: Ergo, a body. A body, if it keepe his good constitution, must be gouerned well: this body therefore of the Church that it might be well; must be gouerned well: that it might be gouerned well, there must be good gouernours, and good lawes, by the which the gouernours must
gouerne well, this good and well composed body of Christ. But where should they haue gouernours to looke to this body of God? The Kings and Princes of the earth, the ordinary rulers to whom it belonged, refused it; and all the Gentill rulers refused it; ordinary rulers therefore there were not any to bee had: Nay, where should they haue rulers Christian for the body of Christ? Should they, or could they fetch them from Gentile, and Heathen Kings? There was vtterly then a want of all ordinary rules, and rulers for the gouernement of this body Ecclesiastical, which was the Church of Christ; the ordinary therefore being wanting, Christ extraordinarily from heauen reached them foorth lawes, and raised them vp gouernors extraordinary from among themselues, their ruling Pastors, or chosen Elders: and withall, put into their hands a sword Spirituall and Ecclesiasticall (excommunication I mean) which he borrowed of the former Iewish Church. And to make it exceeding sharpe, he tyed thereunto a curse, far more fearefull then temporall death: and thus in the want of ordinary, Christ for those dayes raised vp extraordinary rulers, to gouerne the body of the Church; all which plainely speaketh, that for the very want of the ordinary Magistrate to gouerne the Church, the Ecclesiasticall gouernment sprung vp first And for the better beholding of this, consider, I pray you, what sinnes the Apostle in the fift to the Corinthians chargeth the Church of Corinth to censure by excommunication, and you shall finde them to be idolatrie, adulterie, couetousnesse, extortion, rayling, and drunkennesse: all which to bee no sinnes, the Heathen Gentiles were fully perswaded, or at the least sinnes of that small account, as that the Kings and rulers of the Heathen needed not to intermeddle therewith. All which I could well proue out of Heathen Authors, if I thought that any man would once make a question thereabout. These sinnes then being not punished by the Heathen Kings, must of necessity bee punished by rulers of the Church, or else it must be left • ree for the men of the Church to runne without bridle into these notable sinnes: had the ordinary Magistrate therefore punished these sinnes, as they did the other, that they counted the grosser sinnes, the extraordinary Magistrates of the Church should not haue needed no more to punish those lesser sinnes then they needed to haue punished the other which were the greater; for why did not the Church as well punish the greater sinnes as the lesser? was it not because the ciuill
Kings did that? The want therefore of the ciuill Gouernement brought in, and set a foote the Ecclesiasticall: This want therfore being taken away, and the ordinary godly King being set in the Chuch of God, the procreant cause of their Ecclesiastical gouernment is vtterly taken away; and so the ground-worke and pillar thereof being taken away, it must needes, as the Philistims house pulled downe by Sampson, fall vtterly to the ground: and if without this his first, his right and his iust cause it standeth; without any right, iust or necessary cause it standeth in the Church of God: the Christian Magistrate is not taken out, and therefore no cause now is, as then was, to bring Ecclesiasticall Discipline in.

div.head: REASON XI.
div.p:
AND yet I goe further, and I looke into the m • ine body of the Church, as it stood in grosse, in his first and Primitiue times; and I see that it was a kind of body, cleane differing from that which now it is: for in regard of the multitude of beleeuers whereof it confisted, it was called a pure body, but now there be many open sinners therein: then the Church was a body simple, of it selfe: absolute without any composition; but when it came vnder a Christian King that brought with him a Kingdome beside, of people al vnbeleeuing before then it did manifestly degenerate into another nature; and of a simple, became a compound body; for both the Church and the Common-wealth, grew into one compound body: mixed together of the Church, and the weale publique, the visible head whereof was the King: which being but in a word spoken, I desire at large to lay open to euerie mans view; and therefore I boldly auouch, that in the Primitiue time there was a plaine difference, and an open seperation, betweene the Common-wealth and the Church they were as two seuerall Cities; the one heauenly, the other altogether earthly. And as two diuers Cities, they had their two diuers regiments: they were as two diuers standing campes, hauing their seuerall Generals, their seuerall Collonels, their seuerall Captaines, and their seuerall Standard bearers; they were as two seuerall Kingdomes, hauing their seuerall Lawes and constitutions, their seuerall Kings and vnder-officers; they had their diuers Gods, their diuers faith, their diuers rites and ceremonies, their diuers professions, their diuers religions and worshippings of God, their
diuers members, their diuers companies, their diuers and seuerall places for Church-assemblies, their diuers officers and rulers seuerall, differing one from the other. In Ierusalem, there was the Church of Christ, gouerned by the Apostles, the Euangelists, and the Elders of the Church, and this was one body: Againe in the same Ierusalem, there was Pontius Pilate, the high Priests, the Scribes, and Pharises, together with the rest of the vnbeleeuing Iewes. and this was another bodie, hauing another head, another spirit, and other kind of members. But now, especially with vs, this diuision and seperation betweene the Church, and the weale publique, is vtterly abolished, and taken away; the King doth not diuide himselfe from the Minister; nor the Common-weale doth not seperate it selfe from the Church; neither are the members of the Common-weale one, and the members of the Church another: they haue not their seueral Churches, their seueral Synagogues, their seuerall professions, their seuerall rites, and ceremonies; they are not disiomed in their God, in their faith, in their spirit, in their bapt • sme, in their body, in their head: the King commeth to the Church, and the Church commeth to the King: they ioyne together in one Church in one God, in one faith, in one baptisme, in one spirit, in one Christ, in one holy profession, in one body: they are all builded as Ierusalem, that is at vnity in itselfe: they are all one army; the hoast of the great God: they are all one Kingdome; and that is the Kingdome of Christ: all the members of the Church, are the members of the Common-weale: and all the members of the Common-weale, are the members of the Church; the same with vs, is the Common-weale and the Church: al the people are as the people of the Iews; a holy natiō, a royal Priesthood, a kingly people, by profession & baptisme. And albeit there be with vs a multitude of cast-awaies, that to euery good worke are reprobate; yet these make not a diuers body, for in the visible Church there be Goates as well as Sheepe; chaffe as well as corne, cockle as well as wheate; and yet but one Church: Yea, there be diuers offices, and seuerall functions; some spirituall, some temporall and yet but one body. In the Common-weale there be some Counsellers, some Chancellers, some Iudges some Iustices, some Captaines, and one King; and yet these diuers offices make not a diuers body politique. In the Primitiue Church, there were some spirituall Ministers, some Lay Elders (as they say) some Deacons for the poore, and some aged
Widdowes; and yet but one body Ecclesiasticall. In the body of a man there be diuers seuerall parts, hauing seuerall functions; there is the mouth, there is the nose, there are the eyes and the hands, there is the flesh that is earthly, and the spirits that are heauenly; and yet all make not two bodies, but one body: In a man there is his visible, and materiall body, and his spirituall soule; and yet these diuers natures make not two, but one man. There are in the Parliament that representeth the whole estate, the Burgesses of the lower house, the Lords temporall, and the spirituall Lordes, and there is one King the head of all this body: the Ministery is a seuerall calling; but it maketh not now a seueral state, a seueral body, as it did in the Primitiue times, but it is coupled with the Weale publique, and groweth with it into one body, vnder one head, which is the Christian King, as once did the whole Iewish estate vnder Dauid their head and King: and thus the whole Kingdome of the land, is become the Kingdome of Christ, and the Kingdome of Christ, is the kingdome of the land, which could not be said of the Primitiue Church. And thus of two states before the faith, they are become one state in the faith: of two bodies before, they are growne into one newe body • ; exceeding much differing euery way, from the Ecclesiasticall bodie of the Primitiue Church. For now this new body, comming into composition with the Weale publique, hath therby receiued a member, higher, and nobler then the former visible head; and that which in the new making of this body must not be set below the former head, but according to his highnes, be placed aloft, and be made the head of this new composed body: and this eminent member, excelling the head of the former visible Church, is the Christian King, who, as we all subscribe, is become the head of this our English Church. This body therefore must needes be chaunged, for it hath changed his head, the very maine and principall parte of the body: for the head of the Primitiue Church were the Apostles, and after them the Bishops (as we say) (the Eldershippe, as our brethren say) but the head of this Church is the King, as we all say: Yea, with the new head, answerable, and proportionable thereunto; it hath receyued other, and new organicall members, I meane the Nobles and the Peeres of the land; the Councell and the Chanceller of the Kings; the Captaines of warre, and the Iudges of the land: all which beeing once the members organicall of the Common-weale, are now with their
