head, become the members organicall of our English Church▪ seruing euery one of them, as hands directed by their own head, to defend the faith, to maintaine the Gospell, to vphold the sinceritie, and puritie of Christian Religion, the profession, and the Preaching of the word of God. Yea to beat downe all the enemies of the Gospell, by the power of the sword: whether they be forraine, in other lands, or the domesticall enemies of the church: whither they be the disobedient in life, or erronious in doctrine. Aduetie once belonging to the Eldership; but now made common to them: which thing was not so in the Primitiue Church: and that which is more, all the lawes of the land, are in right the lawes of the Church, and the Ecclesiasticall lawes, are the kings Ecclesiasticall lawes: & no longer the lawes proper to the church; and all the rulers of the Church, are at the kings pleasure, to attend the affaires of the commonweale. And that which is yet a farther point; this new formed body hath receiued not only new organicall members: but other inferior members, of lesser & baser note: in their very nature differing frō the ancient & proper members of the Primitiue Church: members, led with another spirit, and moued with another spirit, (and therefore to be gouerned with another spirit) then those of the Primitiue Church. For there were no visible members, but such as came thereunto by a speciall calling: being wonne thereunto, and brought thither, by the power of the Gospel, and mighty worke of the spirit. But now there is a great number added vnto our Church, that neuer came by any speciall calling; but onely for company came, and turned of necessitie with the king their head: men (their baptisme onely excepted) vtterly irreligious, and heathen, and nothing like vnto the auncient members of the auncient Primitiue Church. And these are they that astonish and amaze our brethren, the Ministers especially, as not knowing what to say vnto them, how to rule them, how to deale with them, how to Minister vnto them the Lords Supper. These are to them heteroclites, that is men out of their rule, and without the compasse of their carde; to admit them to the Lords Supper they are afraid, for they iudge them not worthy; and to cast them out of the Church they dare not, least they should iumpe with the Brownists, that would cut them off, and throw them out of the Church againe, and set them in that their old place, wherein they stood before their comming for company with the king: and then as they shall be called specially,
so to receiue them into the Church, as the Primitiue Church did: that the members of this Church, and that, might bee alike. For herein they plainely, and truely see; the members of this Church, and the members of the Primitiue Church, do differ exceedingly: and thereby giue vs, and all to vnderstand: that these must bee gouerned by other rulers, then those of the Primitiue Church: and by other rulers, then the Eldership: euen by that head, whereof they are members, and that head is the king; seeing then that this bodie is of a simple, become a compound; and hath receiued more members, and that of another bodie, and of another sort and kind; and hath receiued another head, and so is become a new, and another kind of body, then that of the Primitiue Church: It followeth, that this new body must not be gouerned with the old forme of the Primitiue Church, but altogether with another, and a new forme. For this is euer vsuall, and euer constant, in the whole course of nature, and in euery worke of God, to giue vnto a new body, another, and a new forme, to gouerne and rule it by. See it in man, whom God made of the clay of the ground; and yet is not ruled by the forme of the ground, but by the breath which the Lord breathed into the face of man: which is another forme, differing cleane from that of the earth. All the trees, and plants of the earth, God made to grow and to spring out of the earth; and to euery one of these, he gaue his diuerse forme: the tree of life had his, the tree of knowledge had his, the rose hath his, the violet hath his; yea euery bird of the aire, made of the aire, hath his; euery fish of the sea, hath his forme diuerse from the sea; the Whale hath his, the Salmon hath his, the Carpe hath his, the Pike hath his: yea the foure Elements being simple, haue their simple, and their seuerall formes. But comming into composition, they loose and let goe their seuerall formes; & submit themselues to another, & a new forme: the Mouse that is made of the slime of the Egyptian Nilus, liueth not by the forme of the Nilus slime; nor the Bee, that is made of the heyfer, is not ruled by the forme of the heyfer; nor the Worme that is bred of man, liueth not by the reasonable soule of man, euery new body hath to rule it, a new forme. Yea our brethren corrupted in their old man, are become a new, and strange sort of men & labouring to bri • g in a new Gouernement, haue lost their old light of reason, to gouerne their iudgement by, and pretending to set vp the Gospell▪ deface the law of God, & the law of nature,
imprinted in al things, that euer God made. Oh how are our • isemen become fooles, and the auncient men become children • n vnderstanding? where is their wise heart, and vnderstanding • n all other things? what is become of their enlightned minde? • ow haue their eyes lost their wonted light, and become dimm? • hat they cannot see this work of God, imprinted in euery worke • f God, and euer before their eyes, which way soeuer they turne •• eir eyes; whether they looke vpon the elements, or vpon the Sea, or vpon the earth, or vpon the plantes of the earth, or vppon •• e beasts of the earth, or vpon the fowles of the ayre, or vpon the fishes of the Sea, vpon man, or wormes bred of man, or vpon • ay of the workes of God; they cannot, whithersoeuer their eyes all, but see, that euery body made new, is euer gouerned • ith a new forme; & yet they that can see it in euery other thing, •• e blinded, and cannot see it in this. But if they haue any eyes • eft, or any light in their eyes; if they are not become blind and • inke not; I will shew them this, by my conclusion, which is this: Namely, that the Church, of a simple element before, being to come into composition and to be coupled with another element, simple before, which was the Common-weale, and so being ioy
• ed with another, to become another, and a new body, is to bee gouerned after another manner, and with a new forme of gouernment, differing from the old forme of the Primitiue Church gouernement: that this worke of God, might be answerable vnto, and conformable with the worke of God, in euery worke of God, and not become, being the most comely of the creatures of God, a Monster in nature, in his nature, differing from the ordinarie, •• e vniuersall, perpetuall, constant, and euer one, and the same course of nature; which nature, is the very created power of God, & the very power of Iesus the Lord to gouerne aright, and to his • ight end, this his Church, and euery other creature of God.

And being that this body hath changed his head, and the former head is become a lower member in this body: how standeth it with reason, that any inferiour member should gouerne the head and the whole body besides, and hauing lost his old place, should gouerne still, as if he had not lost his old place? and being not the head; should rule still the whole, as if he were the head?

And being this bodie hath members, as iudges and Captaines,
that the olde head cannnot inspire with life, and being, how standeth it with nature, that this head should rule still as head, these members that are inspired with another spirit, and with the spirits of another head then that?

And seeing that the Church, and the Common-weale are ioyned together, and growen into one bodie: how is it, that our brethren hold a necessity of two heads to gouerne this one body? as a Pope or a Presbytrie to gouerne the Church: and a king to gouerne the Common-weale? or how standeth it with nature, and Philosophie, Diuine, or Humane, to hold a necessitie of two formes, (a Ciuill, and an Ecclesiasticall forme) to gouerne one, and the same body? Fie, let them for shame leaue of to hold such straunge, and monstrous assertions.

div.head: REASON XII.
div.p:
ANd heere, the better to shew this new chaunge, in this new body, I will offer to your consideration the particular changeable partes, of the Primitiue changeable, and chaunged Church-Gouernement: and herein first I will let you see, that excommunication, the very sword, the scepter, and power of the Primitiue Church Gouernment, is in the iudgement of all, to be exchanged with other more effectuall coercions, in this cōfused, and mixed Church of ours. And as for the Iudgement of the King, the Iudgement of the Counsell of the land, and the Iudgement of the learned fathers of the land, it appeareth, by the conference that is extant, which his excellent maiestie had, together with his honourable, gratious, and wise counsell, with the reuerent Fathers, the Lord Bishops of the land: that they were resolued, insteede of excommunication, to set vp some other coertion, that had in it, a more effectuall power to redresse and to represse sinne. It seemed no doubt vnto their wisedomes, an vnreasonable thing, that the vnbeleeuing part, that were with the ancient Kings of the land turned Protestants, should againe by excommunication bee cast out of the Church: but rather that they should bee brought vnto the Church: whether they were brought, and whether they came to bee taught. by the Church. It seemed no vnlawfull thing vnto them, to exchange excommunication, the weighty censure of the Church, with other more effectuall: but this rather seemed vnto them, an vnlawfull thing, to make contemptible the holy censure Ecclesiasticall:
or to vse, or rather abuse the auncient censure of the Church, to ouerthrow the Church, & the spredding of the Church; & to the making of a Schisme in the Church: and a separation, betweene the Church againe, & the Common-weale, as the Brownists do; and so to the ouerthrowing againe of the vnion: & by the meanes of the Church, that, other Kings, & God by other Kings, had builded: & therfore that it were better, that excommunication should be thrust, & shut out the Church, then that excomunication shold thrust and shut out the Church: and that the vse of it could not stand, nor as it was once, be now put i • vse, except it thrust out frō the Church, the disobedient part whic • is the greatest part of the Church; out of the which the Church must gather a multitude, and a farther increase to it selfe: and therfore that excommunicat • on sleeping, some other fit censure, meerely Ciuill, should be put in vse, that should gouerne the beleeuing, & the vnbeleeuing part: & further altogether, & no whit impaire, or impeach the growth, & good estate of the whole Church, as now it standeth. And as for our aduersaries: themselues hold (as appeareth by their owne profession, & by their often suits to the Parliament) that excōmunication, the only censure Ecclesiasticall, in the cases of adulterie, Idolatry, Heresie▪ & such like, as being too light, vnder a Christian king, is to be exchanged with death. So that in the iudgement of all, excōmunication the principall part of Ecclesiasticall Gouernment, is a matter changeable, vnder a Christian prince. If then the principal part therof be changeable, no questiō, but the whole gouernmēt it self is chāgeable, & altogether mutable, as wel as that is

And heere I hope, that our aduersaries will easily graunt, that these men were not ignorant of the power of Iesus, and the gift of the keyes, bestowed by Iesus vpon the Church. All which power notwithstanding, and gift of the keyes, they saw, and that wisely, and truely, that the sword of excommunication might be closed vp in his sheath, and as a needlesse one, be laid aside; vnder a godly and Christian king. For the gift of Christ doth not make excommunication perpetuall vnto the Church. Christ ascending vp on high, saith the Apostle, led captiuitie captiue, and gaue gifts vnto men; and the gifts that he gaue, are there reckoned vp by the Apostle: he gaue some Apostles, some Prophets, some Euangelists, &c. And: yet notwithstanding the gift of the Apostles, Apostles are ceased, and Prophets, notwithstanding the gift of Prophets, are ceased, and Euangelists, notwithstanding
the gifts of Euangelists are ceased: and the key of excommunication, notwithstanding the gift of that key may surcease vnder a Christian king. The office of the high Priest was giuen by God vnto Aaron, and his seede, by a perpetull decree, and yet notwithstanding the perpetuity thereof, by expresse words, confirmed to Aaron by God himselfe, the Priest-hood was altered with the law, and transferred to another, euen to Iesus, that was of the tribe of Iuda, by an euerlasting decree of God. Much more excommunication being tied to the Church by no perpetuall decree of God, or of Christ, may bee altered with the visible estate of the Church, and may bee taken away from the peaceable, that was giuen to the persecuted Church of Christ. Who knoweth not that there are gifts temporary, and eternall; for liues, and for euer: estates onely for certaine termes, and perpetuities. Especially, that vnder offices are arbitrary, and remoueable from person to person, at the pleasure of the high and chiefe Lord and king, Iesus.

But be it that excommunication by the gift of Christ is affixed to the Church by a perpetuall decree, so that it may not be taken vtterly away: yet the vse of it may be discontinued, though the right, and interest therein, doe abide perpetually in the Church, For the gift of it to the Church by Christ, doth not binde the Church vnseasonably, or without vrgent, and iust cause to put into vse this power, or to draw out the sword of excommunication: euen as the word, & the gift of the Sacraments, by Christ bestowed vpon the Chur • h, are not euery day, or euery houre of the day. or euery minute of the houre, to be put into execution by the Church▪ because that by Christ they are giuen to the Church, but onely then, when necessitie, and iust occasion so requireth: a father bestoweth a dagger vpon his sonne, not that he should euer be stabbing therewith. A master giueth his seruant a sword, not that hee should carry it euer drawen in his hand, or euer be fighting, or smiting therewith: bu • onely then, when necessitie, or iust occasion offereth it selfe: So Iesus hath giuen vnto his Church the sword of excommunication onely then to • ee vsed, when necessitie & vrgent occasion so requireth. But vnder a Christian p ince, punishing all sinnes by his sword ciuill, there can be no such necessary vse, or vrgent occasion, to vse that sword of excommu • ication. It may therefo • e he closed vp in his scabberd, and be l • yd aside in such dayes, and vnder such Kings: and
yet againe be drawne out, and put into vse, in the dayes of persecuting kings. And this is not to take away that which Christ hath giuen to his spouse, the Church: but onely to vse it in his fit time, and place; euen then, and there, and onely then, and there, to vse it, when and where, there is fit vse for it.

And thus you see vpon how weake principles, and vnsound ground, our brethren build the necessitie, and perpetuall vse of excommunication in the Church: and thus you see, that notwithstanding the gift of the keyes, which is their maine proofe, for the •• tting vp of discipline, the key of excommunication may bee •• yd by, vnder a Christian King. And then if excommunication which is the power of Iesus, for the Gouernement of his perse
•• ted Church, and the very sword, and principall part of the Primitiue Church Gouernement, may be wanting, & abolished, vnder a Christian King: out of all question, the very Primitiue Gouernement, which cannot bee without this, may bee taken a
• ay in like manner, and vtterly abolished in the peaceable dayes of the Church. And if the Apostle in the Epistle to the Hebrewes, soundly prooueth the abolishing of the ceremoniall •• w, by the abolishing of the Priest-hood, which was the principall part thereof, and serued for the execution of the law ceremoniall: then this reason of ours, that prooueth the lawfull • aking away of excommunication out of the Church, vnder a • odly King▪ soundly proueth the lawfull taking away of the Primitiue Church Gouernement vnder a godlie, and a Christian King.

div.head: REASON XIII.
div.p:
IN the next place, I looke into the Ecclesiasticall officers, of the Primitiue Church; I meane the ruling Elders: and I see, that •• ey, in like manner are in a Christian Kingdome, iustly exchanged, with a more excellent ruler, which is the godly, and the christian King; whom our aduersaries acknowledge by their •• bscription to the supremacy, to be the principall, and supreme gouernour in the church ouer all persons: that is ouer the Mini
• ters, ouer the Elders and ouer all th • flocke, that before were vn
• er the ruling Elders: and that in all causes, whither they are matters of instance, 〈◊〉 matters of crime; in matters of Whoredome • f Sla •• er • or •
•••• nne • ie, of vsury; and in a w ••• , of all those causes, wherein the Elders sat as Iudges, in the Primitiue Ch • rch;
in all those causes, now sitteth the King, and the officers vnder the King, as Iudges, to giue righteous iudgement therein. To him therefore comming into the Church, the ruling Elder resigned, and gaue vp his sword: To him, and to his rule, the church that before was vnder the Eldershippe, submitted it selfe; and looked, and waited for iustice, from his handes: of the Primitiue Church one of the fathers said, that the Church knewe nothing greater therein then the Bishoppe, but wee know one greater then the Bishopp, euen the sacred person, and power of the king. For doe you suppose, that when the King came to the Church, that then there came but a priuate person, that was to be vnder the rule and power of the Church, and to be topped by the Eldershippe? I tell you noe: he came a publique person, to rule, and to take into his hand, out of the hand of the Elders, the whole gouernement of the Church of God; to gouerne them, that before were gouerning Elders, to gouerne all them, that before were gouerned by the Elders: yea, and to gouerne them in the same cases, and in all the same affaires, wherein they were gouerned before by the ruling Elders of the Church. There is therefore another ruler sprung vp in the Church, and that planted by God, that the Primitiue Church neuer knew: and that is the King, that hath authority from God to rule there, and a sword for that purpose giuen him of God: as the Elders before him had authority to rule there, and a speciall sword giuen vnto them for that purpose from God The King therfore now is to gouerne the church by his power, and to be Custos virius{que} tabulae: which is all that the ruling Elders had to doe in the Primitiue Church. And this is so apparant, that it cannot be denied: the light hereof shineth vppon our enemies, and they confesse the King to be such a one indeede. The Lord that before put Pastors and Elders in trust with his body, which is the Church, and committed the rule therof into their hands, hath now in stead of them, made choice of more excellent guardians: euen of the Kings, and Princes of the world, and hath committed to their trust, the same body of his, that before he put into the hands, and custody of the ruling Elders: and of these dayes, and of this change, spake the Prophet before, forewarned thereof, by the spirit, and forewarning vs thereof by the spirit of God, saying, thou shalt sucke the breasts of Kings, and Princes shall giue thee milke, Esa. 60.10.16. And againe, I will make Kings thy nou • sing fathers, and Queenes thy
noursing mothers, Esa. 49.23. Where it is plaine, that the Prophet told aforehand of these daies, and that the after times should come, wherein God would chaunge the hearts of the Gentile Kings, and out of them raise vp gouernours, that should feede, as nourses, his chosen in Israell, with the milke of iudgement, and with the rodde of iustice: and rule them prudently with all their heart, as once Dauid did the people of God. The holy man of God therefore, l • d by the spirit of God, hath prophesied afore hand of these times, and of this new gouernor to come from God, and hath thereby giuen vs a sure warrant from God, that the will of God is, that the baser officers of the persecuted Church, should in better daies, be exchaunged, with more excellent ones: namely, with Kings, and Princes, which being not to gouerne with the Ecclesiasticall sword, but with the ciuill, haue power (by consequent) in stead of the Ecclesiasticall sword taken away, to set vp, as all sufficient, their owne rule in the whole Church of God: and in place of the former, that must giue place to theirs, to place, and set fast their owne. So that with the new Gouernour of the Church, the old gouernement must needes be changed: and in stead of the Ecclesiasticall, which onely was in the handes of the ruling Elders, must be set vp the ciuill sword, which onely, by God, is put into the hands of the King, therewith to gouerne the whole land, and Church. And indeed by necessary consequent it followeth, that if by God there be set vp a new kinde of ruler, with a new kind of sword, to rule the Church withall: then there must needes be set vp a new kind of rule, a new sword, a newe scepter, a new gouernement, in the whole Church of God: and so euery part of the Primitiue gouernement, being changed, the whole of nece • sity must be changed in that.

And here I must admonish our aduersaries of three thinges; first that the common distinction of the ciuill, and the Ecclesiasticall sword, doth not destroy, nor ouerthrow this argument of mine: for though the King may not rule with the Ecclesiasticall sword, whereof he hath no neede; yet he may as sufficiently rule the Church with his ciuill sword, without the Ecclesiasticall; as the Ecclesiasticall ruler could gouerne it, with his Ecclesiasticall sword, without the ciuill: yea, in stead of destroying of our reason, it doth strengthen it more; for in that they confesse that the King may gouerne the Church by his ciuill sword: the bringing in of that argueth the throwing out of the other: the setting vp
of that, argueth the pulling downe of the other: euen as the bringing in of the new law of Christ, argued the disanulling, of the old law of Moses, as the Apostle reasoneth to the Hebrewes.

Secondly, the distinction of the ciuill, and Ecclesiasticall persons, doth not dissolue this argument of mine. For though the king be not a meere Ecclesiasticall person; yet we haue made a question of it, and proued, that being but a ciuill person, he may for gouernement in the Church, d • e all that the Ecclesiasticall Elders might doe: for he is now, what they were before. Hee is now, as they were once, custos vtrius{que} tabulae: that is, the executioner of eyther table of the Law. And here it is now too late to runne in a ring, and to runne backe to the distinction of the Ecclesiasticall sword, and the ciuill; which to preuent, we haue taken away that before. It is enough for vs, that hee may doe the same, being a ciuill Magistrate, that the Church elder might doe before; though he may not doe it, the same way, nor with the same manner of instrument. For what helpeth it them, or what hurteth it vs, to say, that the King may gouerne as the Elder did, and in stead of him? marry he must not doe it with a leaden dagger, but with a bright and a sharpe two edged sword, of steele: he may not gouerne the Church with the blunt sword of excommunication, but with the guilded, shining, glittering, and in ameled sword of ciuill iustice.

Thirdly, I admonish our aduersaries, that the question betweene vs, is not principally, about the censures of the Primitiue Church, which they denie not, but that we doe enioy; But the maine question is about the persons, that should censure the Church, and the manner or kinde of censures to bee vsed in the Church Gouernement: the persons that should censure the Churc • , they denie to be Arch-bishopps, B • shops, commissaries, or officials; and affirme, to be the pastors, and their supposed seuerall Elders of euery Church. But I hold that the very Pasto • s and elders, dreamed of vnder a Christian king, are not to gouerne of neces • ity without commission from the King. And that it is the King, that may, and ought to censure all offenders in the Church as once the ruling Elders did: and that not by the censures Ecclesi • sticall, whereof he hach no neede, but onely by his power and authority ciuill, which is of it selfe all sufficient thereunto without the ecclesiasticall,

div.head: REASON. XIIII.
div.p: AND now to shew this, and yet to goe on with my entended purpose, I must in the very entry encounter an opinion, by our brethren broached, exceeding derogatory to the Kingdome of Christ: which holdeth, that the Kingdome of Christ, is confined within the bounds of his Church, & there determined, where he ceaseth his medi •• ion; but these men that thus shutte vp his Kingdome within the limits of his Priesthood, speake at Randome, and without all sound ground of the word: for his Priesthood is not for the world: but for the beleeuers of the world: his med •• aion is for his friends: but his kingdome is for his enemies, that he might d • stroy and ouercome them: according as it is writtt • n be thou ruler in the middest, euen among th • ne enemies •• en among the Iewes, that crucified thee, the King of the Iewes • mong the Gentiles, that persecuted thy body; which is the Ch •• ch; among the Turkes, which sight against the beloued citie.

All power, saith Christ, is giuen to me, in heauen, and in earth, Mat. 28.18. The Kingdome then is not diuided betweene the father and • he sonne, with these conditions: that the father should gouerne the Iewes, the Turkes and the Gentiles, and the sonne, the beleeuers, and the faith ull: for then all power were not giuen to the sonne, but some power, and that the greatest, reserued to the father.

The father (saith Iohn the Baptist, Iohn 3. ver. 35.) loueth the sonne, and hath giuen all things into his hands. Iesus (saith Iohn chap. 13.3.) knew that the father had gi • en all into his handes: not some things, but all things; not the Church onely, which is but some parte of his all things: but all Churches, all nations, all tongues, all people, all realmes, and Kingdomes whatsoeuer, euen all.

The Father iudgeth no man, (saith Christ, Iohn. 7.22, 23.) but hath committed all iudgement to the sonne, ver. 27, Yea, euen as he is the Sonne of man, that all men might honour the Sonne, as they honour the Father. The kingly seat then, and throne of iudgement, which once the fathers was, and wherin as Souereig • e and King, he sat to rule, and iudge all nations, and kingdomes of the world, this kingly seate, and • oyall power, hath the fa • her giuen ouer vnto his • onne Christ: but the power of God was o • er
all nations: Erg • , the power of Christ is ouer all nations: the father iudgeth no man: the Turke is a man, the Iew is a man, the Heathen man is a man: none of these are Iudged, none therefore ruled by the father, but all by the sonne Christ; the Father hath giuen that honour of the kingdome, that royall, and kingly power to the sonne, which once was his, that all men might honour the sonne, as they honour the father.

Aske of me (saith the father, to his king Christ, set downe vppon his holy hill, Psal. 2.8, 9. That is, residing in Ierusalem that is aboue, euen at the right hand of his father) and I will giue thee the Heathen for thine inheritance, and the vttermost partes of the earth for thy possession. His kingdome then is ouer all the nations of the earth: Yea, ouer the very Heathen: and it is not, as the Church is, shut vp in a little corner of the earth: but stretcheth it selfe to the furthermost parts of the earth: and that not to gouerne them as his Church, by his word and spirit; but with an iron rodde to breake them in peeces like a Potters vessell; not like his children, whom being broken, he healeth againe by his owne blood.

Dauid notably defineth the very breadth, and length, the greatnesse, and the exceeding largenesse of the kingdome of Christ, Psal. 72.8.9.10.11. His Dominion, saith he, shall be from one sea, to the other: from the floods, round about vnto the ends of the world. Before him shall the Barbarians bow themselues; his enemies shall licke the dust, the Kings of the Oceane, and the Islands, shall bring him gifts: the Kings of Sheba, and Seba, shall doe him seruice. Finally all Kings shall bow themselues to him; all Nations shall doe him seruice. What can be more plainely spoken for his kingdome ouer all Churches, and Realmes, Iewes, and Gentiles, yea ouer all the world, I cannot possibly see, or imagine.

There is a kingdome ascribed vnto Christ, that is an euerlasting kingdome, Psal. 45.7. Dan. 2.44. & 7.14. Thy throne O God, saith Salomon, (speaking of Christ) is for all ages world with out end. And there is a kingdome ascribed vnto Christ, that he shall resigne againe to his father, and that shall haue an end. Then commeth the end, saith the Apostle, when he shall deliuer vp the kingdome to God the father. 1. Cor. 15.24. That kingdome, that shall haue no end, is ouer his saued, and redeemed onely. Ouer whom, being his bodie, Christ shall euer abide the head.
yea after the vniuersall dissolution of the world. Ergo, that kingdome that shalbe resigned, being another, differing frō this, cannot be that his kingdome that is only ouer his bodie, the Church: but it must be that his vniuersall kingdome ouer his enemies. As it is said, he must raigne, till he haue put all all his enemies vnder his feet: his kingdome therfore, and that which shall haue an end, is ouer his friends to saue them, and ouer his enemies, to destroy them.

It is a part of his kingdome, to raise from dead, and bring into iudgement all flesh, 2. Tim. 4.1. and ouer them, as a King, to sit in his glorious throne, and iudgement seat, and pronounce a sentence irreuocable of life, or death euerlasting. But this power to iudge, is ouer all Nations; yea ouer quicke, and dead: for therefore he died, and rose againe, that he might be Lord ouer quicke, and dead. Ergo, His kingdome is as large as his iudgement is, 2. Tim. 4.1.2. Which is ouer more, then ouer his Church: and far larger, then his office of mediation is, for he is the Sauiour of his Church, but iudge of all.

Because hee humbled himselfe saith Paul, to the death of the Crosse: therefore he hath a name, (that is a power, and authority giuen him) aboue all names (whither they be the names of Churches, or of Common-weales: whither they be the names of Emperours, or Kings) that at the name of Iesus all knees should bow: of things in heauen, and things in earth, & things vnder the earth. Philip. 2.8.9.10. He meaneth that God hath giuen him a kingdome ouer all Angels, ouer all Diuels, ouer all Churches, and Common-weales: ouer all things on the earth, bee they men, or others.
Else how should hee bee the fift Monarch of the earth, that should take to himselfe the kingdome from the rest of the kingdomes, and giue it to the high Saincts. Dan. 7.14.27. and 2.34.35.44.

The Angel told his mother Marie, that vnto him should bee giuen the kingdome of his father Dauid, Luke 1.32.33. But the kingdome of Dauid did not gouerne the Church onely, but the weale publike; the gouernement therefore of the kingdome of Christ, reacheth not onely to the Church, but to the Commonweale: else the kingdome of Christ, is not as ample, as the kingdome of Dauid was.

Thou art a Priest, saith God to his Christ, after the order of
Melchisedech; Heb. 7.1. But Melchisedech was King of Salem, a little Citie of Canaan, and the Priest of the strong high God, such a one therefore must Christ be: euen a ruler, not onely ouer the Church; but a king ouer the weale publique: or else the shadow shall be greater then the body.

The time would faile me, if I should stand to alleage all the proofes pregnant in the Scripture, to giue witnesse to this controuersie in hand, these are all sufficient, to let our aduersaries see, that not onely the Church is the kingdome of Christ: but weales publike are a part of the kingdome of, Christ, as wel as Churches are: and that his kingdome is ouer all, both Churches, and Common-weales. So ample and so large, the kingdome of Christ is; howsoeuer our aduersary-brethren, (that of all men would seeme most desirous to set vp the Kingdome of Christ, to their greater sin, & to the great dishonoring of Christ, vpon small reason God wot) denie this. But by this it appeareth, that faining to bee the greatest friends of that their Master and Lord Christ, they betray him, and the greatest part of his kingdome: which with one consent, they conspire to take away frō him, & to yeeld vp again into the hands of the father; that before had yeelded this into the hands of his first begotten, and beloued, the heire of this world, and all worlds to come: and going about to establish their owne kingdome, they destroy the kingdome of Christ, and labouring to inlarge their owne Dominion, and rule, they curtaile and diminish the kingdome of the Lord Christ. And therefore I cannot but in the zeale of my Lord, and king Christ, bid defiance vnto, and wage battell with this their opinion, that denieth the kingdome of my Lord and king Iesus. And hold him, if it were an Angell from heauen, accursed, that should preach me another Gospell then this that I haue receiued, from the mouthes, and liuely voices of all the holy Scriptures, consenting to this all in one, that Iesus is the king, and Lord ouer all things.

But I see what droue them to this, and made them run into this foule starting hole, they desired to sit their doctrine of the kingdome of Christ to their opinion of Ecclesiasticall gouernement, therfore indeede they fitted their sho • e according to their foote. For teaching their Ministers, and Elders, to be the onely officers of Christ to rule the Church, which is the kingdome of Christ; of necessitie, they must except the king from being any officer of the kingdome of Christ. That they might do this: first
they warily teach, that the kingdome of Christ is onely ouer his Church: and secondly, that they might not offend the Christian kings, they giue them, as they would seeme to thinke, a higher place: and that they might remoue them out of the kingdome of Christ, and out of all office in the Church of Christ, and so haue elbow roome enough for themselues, they giue them their place immediatly vnder God the Father: and set them to raigne in common-weales: that they might not intermeddle with the Church Gouernement.

And answerable hereunto, they teach, that the kingdome of Christ is a spirituall kingdome; that is, gouerned by spirituall men, and by spirituall meanes, that is, the word, and the censures Ecclesiasticall: that they might exclude the sword, and the censures ciuill out of the Church of Christ, and make it glad to stand armed at the Church doore, to keepe them in safetie, and peace, dominering within, in the Church: and this is all the power they giue to the ciuill king, in gouerning the Church of Christ, and this is good Poperie indeed.

Although all this geere will not hold, for to gouerne the spirituall kingdome of Christ, they call in meere lay men: and giue them place, and power, and office, in the kingdome of Christ, and call them by the name of Church Elders: and how will they then shut out the king, being a person more interessed in the Church gouernement, then any of his subiects, from being an officer in the Church, & kingdome of Christ, and that only for being no spirituall person, but a lay man? at the least let him be as capeable of office in the Church, as his vnder subiects, your chosen Elders, be.

And thus hauing cast downe that their strong hold, that stood in our way, we will goe on with the maine force of our argument, and inferre, that the Kingdome of Christ, reaching not ouer Churches only, but ouer Common-weales too, for the fit gouernment thereof, shall neede not onely censures ecclesiasticall, as our brethren beleeue, which will fit onely the members of the Church: but beside these coertions ciuill, and meerely temporall which will fitly serue both for the members of the Church & of the Common-weale, to gouerne them both; as they did vnder the gouernement of the Iewish Common-weale. And therefore accordingly, the father, for the better and more effectuall gouerning of his whole Kingdome, hath furnished his sonne Christ, not onely with censures ecclesiasticall, but with an iron rodde; therewith to breake in peeces his enemies, like a potters vessell. And this rodde is either the multitude of temporall afflictions, comming from the immediate hand of Christ, vpon the disobedient of the world; or those which are brought vpon the heads of the wicked, by the hands of the ciuill Kings; who bearing not the sword for nought, are the Ministers of God for to execute his wrath vpon all them that doe euill. And therefore in the second of the Reuelation, the Lord Christ threatneth that woman Iesabell, not with suspension, or with excommunication, that are the censures ecclesiasticall: but to cast her into a bedd; which is, to punish her sinnes with sickenesse, and other diseases of the body; and her sonnes he threatneth to kill with the sword. And in the third of the same booke, the same Lord, and King Iesus auoucheth, that he chasteneth, and correcteth euery sonne whom he loueth. Chastisements therefore, and afflictions, whither ecclesiasticall or ciuill, are the censures of the King Christ. And in the nineteenth of the same booke, Saint Iohn saw a mighty army of men follow the word of God; who had a name written on his thygh, to be the King of the Kings, and Princes of the earth; and with this army attending him, their leader and King, he slewe a
mightie army of his enemies; to eate vp whose flesh, an Angell that stood in the Sunne, called together al the beasts of the earth, and the birds of heauen. To gouerne therefore his Kingdome, the Lord Christ hath Angels, Deuils, armies of Kings & Princes, fire, sword, famine, thunder, lightning, earthquakes, haile, stocks, whippes, prisons, bootes, rackes, gallowes, hurdels, axe, losse, pouertie, banishment, sickenesse, shame, death, excommunication, suspension, and a number els: so many, and of so sundrie sorts, are the censures, and coertions of the Kingdome of Christ. And of all these, so many in number, in the greatest want of the Church, the Lord Christ put ouer vnto the rulers of the Church onely two principall the most vsuall whereof was excommunication, being a kind of banishment for a time from the Church of Christ; and being trusted onely with one or two at the most: how they face it out, as if all had beene put into their hands.

Thus far then hitherto haue wee traced out steppe by steppe the truth of this point: and by testimonies apparant out of the holy Scriptures haue brought the matter to this issue, that the Lord Christ is King ouer all realmes and Churches: and that to gouerne them, he hath censures, not onely ecclesiasticall, but ciuill. But now the question is, whither the Lord doeth gouerne these his kingdomes here in earth, by his royal presence on earth; or by his Vicegerents, and substitutes: and by the answere of Christ to Pilate, this question receiueth a manifest and a plaine answere. For to Pilate Christ plainely telleth, that his Kingdome is not of this world: not meaning heereby to denie the interest that he had in the Kingdomes and the Churches of this world: but his meaning is to tell Pilate, that his imperiall citie, which being the principall of his Kingdome, hee calleth metaphorically his Kingdome, his throne of glory, his kingly seate, his pallace royall, is not seated in this world: and that his meaning is not to reigne in Ierusalem, as their king, nor at Rome as their Emperour, nor yet in any other of the Kingdomes of this world: but in heauen; where he shall not hinder the reigne of the kings of this earth. This king therfore sitteth and raigneth in heauen, and giueth place to the kings of the earth to reigne as kings vnder him. But then not gouerning these his kingdomes by his residence heere on earth: it must needes follow, that as other kings residing in their imperiall cities, doe gouerne those their kingdomes that are a farre off by Proconsuls, Deputies, or
Vice-royes, which are their Vicars, and doe represent their person: so this King Christ doth visibly gouerne these Churches and Kingdomes of his, by his Vice-royes and earthly deputies. The further question then is, which of all the officers and rulers of the Common-weale and Church, are the Vice-royes and deputies of this King of heauen, to gouerne and to rule his whole realme on earth? What is the Pope the Vice-roy of Christ, for the gouernement of his whole Kingdome on earth? Indeede this power and great honour he doth arrogate vnto himselfe; but in no case can we yeelde him this. And as for our brethren, they had rather take it themselues, then giue it to him. What then are the Ministers the Vice-royes, and next deputies vnder Christ, to gouerne this his Kingdome of the earth? Indeede they are his Vicars to teach his Church, and so Priests vnder the high Priest Christ. And they say, that they are the Vicars and Vice-royes of Christ immediate to gouerne his whole Kingdome, which as they say, is onely the Church: they are then belike, like vnto Christ▪ a King, and a Priest, such as was Melchisedech, a Prince, & a Priest of the strong high God. But let all this be graunted vnto them, that they assume vnto themselues, yet dare they not intermedle with the earthly Kingdomes, nor ciuill censures of the King, which they falsly denie to be any parte of the Kingdome of Christ: and therefore they are not full Vice-royes indeede of the King of heauen▪ but we seeke a full Vice-roy of the king Christ, if he haue • ny: and being that the Pope is not, nor the Minister is not, it followeth, that the Kings onely of the earth, are the deputies, the Ministers, the substitutes, the Vice-royes, of this great and migh
• y king Christ.

And howsoeuer they will not teach it in their doctrine, yet to •• is they haue subscribed, that the king, next, and immediately vnder Christ, is the supreame gouernour, both of the Church, and the Weale publique: and with them subscribeth S. Iohn to this point, Apoc. 1. calling Christ the chiefe of the Princes of the earth: Ergo he is a Prince of the earth; and that the chiefe one: and other Princes hold of him in chiefe: and man other place afore cited, he calleth him the king of the kings of the earth: if he be • heir king, then they are not immediately the subiects of the father, but of Christ: if they be kings, & his subiects, they are depu
• ed and su • stituted by him to be kings vnder him; they hold then • heir kingdome of him, and are his Vice-royes and substitutes; euen
as Herod a King, being the subiect of the Romane Emperour, held his deputation, and Kingdome, of the Emperour of Rome, whose Vice-roy and substitute he was, for the gouerning of that parte of his Iewish Kingdome; wee therefore conclude, that as the Minister is the substitute of Christ, to teach the Church: so the King is the substitute, and Vicar of Christ, to gouerne the Church: and as it is the office of the Minister to teach the Church; so it is the office of the King to gouerne the Church: and as it is essentiall and ordinary to the Minister, to minister the word; so it is ordinary and essentiall to the King, to minister iustice, and to gouerne the whole Church of Christ. But so, as if the King doe, or shall neglect this parte of his duety; I meane the holy rule, and good gouernement of the Church of Christ: and in stead of well gouerning the Church, shall become a persecutor of the Church: then in the contempt and persecution of the King, extraordinarily, the Lord deputeth the Eldershippe, as his Vice-roy, to gouerne for him that part of his persecuted Church. And (ouer, and beside that which hath beene said) this may be well prooued out of other portions of the holy Writ: for, that it belongeth to the ordinary office of the king, to gouerne in his daies the Church of God, by his ciuil sword, appeareth plainely, by the example of all the godly kings of Iudah; who all, as their prerogatiue royall, euer had, and held this power and authority, by their ciuill sword onely, without the Ecclesiastical, to gouerne as the weale publique, so the whole Church of God, that was vnder them. And againe that, in the persecution and contempt of the king, the Eldership might gouerne the Church of Christ, for Christ; appeareth by the example apparent of the Church Primitiue: which in the want of godly kings, receiued power from Christ, to gouerne for Christ, the Church of Christ. Godly kings therefore in their daies, as the chiefe Officers of the Church of Christ, are to gouerne the peaceable Church of Christ: but in the want of godly kings, the Eldershipp of the Church, is, in the persecution of the Church, to gouerne the persecuted Church of Christ. There are therefore two estates of the Church; the one peaceable, and the other persecuted: and according to these two estates, two kindes of Gouernours, and two kindes, as I may in some sort say, of Gouernements: to gouerne the peaceable Church, there is the ciuill king, and the ciuill sword; to gouerne the persecuted Church, there is the Eldershippe Ecclesiasticall,
and there is the sword Ecclesiasticall; and neither of these must intermeddle in the time, or in the place of the other; but eyther of them must keepe his place and his time: in the dayes of peace, let the king raigne, and let the Eldershippe sleepe; in the daies of persecution the king sleepeth, let the Eldershippe then awake, and the sword Ecclesiasticall. For in the Primitiue times they had their seuerall times, and their seuerall places, to bestirre and occupy themselues in: when godly kings raigned in the Primitiue Church of the Iewes, the Eldership was not in vse. Againe in the Primitiue Church of Christ, when the Eldershippe raigned, the kings of the Gentiles, and the Iewes raged against the Church, they raigned not ouer the Church, as they ought: when kings slept, the Church gouernement awaked; againe when the kings awaked, the Church Gouernement slept. And thus in their Primitiue times, they were not both iumbled together, as our brethren would haue: but they had their seuerall standing, and vse apart one from the other; they had their interchaungeable raigne and their successiue vse and place; and so let them stand still: let them keepe their first place, and their fitte time, and their gouernements may both st • nd, both agree, both haue their being, and their euerlasting vse, in some time or in other; in some place or in other. The Discip • ine ecclesiasticall may haue his vse in Turkey, in Fraunce, in the persecuted Churches of the Low-countries, or in the Territories of Geneua, or Berne, where there is no king to gouerne. But the Discipline ciuill may haue his place in England, in Denmarke, and vnder al godly and christian kings. Distinguish times, saith one, and the Scriptures will agree: Distinguish the times and the places, & the diuers gouernments wel agree: runne not on on a head, without the consideration of the times, and the places; and this controuersie shall haue an end.

And thus you shall haue a wedge for this hard knotte: but if you will vnseasonably set them vp both at one time to raigne: and make them, being different, to be as one; and being of diuers natures, to agree both in one gouernement, in one place, in one kingdome, you will attempt almost impossibilities, breede confusion, bring in disorder, make contentions, as betweene contraries; and the one will iustle out the other, as by wofull experience hath beene found in the Gouernement of the Pope, and the Emperour: and therefore when the kings rage, then must the Church raigne: againe when kings raigne, then must the Church
cease to raigne: and of a raigning Q • eene, become an obedient subiect, vnder the gouernement of a godly king. And heere I challenge o • r aduersa ies, if they can, to shew mee out of the word of God, where these two gouernements euer were in vse at one time, and in any one kingdome of the world.

div.head: REASON XV.
div.p:
ANd here the better to deduce this from the former grounds, we must beware, that wee doe not childishly imagine, that because the Kingdome of Christ reacheth vnto two sortes of estates, the Church, and the Common-weale: and because it hath beene executed by two kind of swords; therefore, that (as a fooles coate is made of two kinds of cloath, so) the one kingdome of Christ, is made of two sorts of kingdomes; and that the one part of his kingdome is made, & consisteth of one kind, and the other part of another kind: that the one part of his kingdome is an Ecclesiasticall kingdome; and that this was executed by Ecclesiasticall men, and by a sword Ecclesiasticall; and that the other part, is a ciuill kingdome; and that this was and is executed by ciuill kings, and by a sword ciuill; and so that it was one Office of Christ, that was executed by the ministery gouerning the Church: and another office of Christ, that was executed by the king, gouerning the Church. No, it is plaine, that the power to gouerne the Church, that is giuen to the king, and to the Eldershippe, is the one and selfe s • me kingly power of Christ; and that the one kingly office of Christ, to gouerne the Common-weale, and the Church is notably put ouer to one person, I meane the king: so that the office of the king Christ abiding in him, the office, and the duetie to gouerne the Realme, and the Church really abideth in him; although the execution of that part of his Office, that concerneth the Church, be neglected of him; and therfore put ouer by Christ vnto the Minister, to execute for him, and that by another, which is the Ecclesiasticall sword: so that to gouerne the Church, is a part of the office, the royaltie, and prerogatiue of the king, euer abiding in him, while he is a king; yea, though he persecuteth: and that the gouernment of the Church that the ministery executed, was a branch of the Kings duetie, and that which by the King should haue beene put in execution by his owne sword ciuill; whereupon doe depend these consequents: First, that it was no new power that was put ouer to the
Minister for the gouernement of the Church: but the very selfe same that was put ouer to the King before: and therefore the Church gouerned by the king, is gouerned by the same power whereby it was gouerned vnder the eldershippe: Secondly, that this power to gouerne the Church ordinarily, as his essentiall office, doth belong, and appertaine vnto the King; and the dispising King shall answere to God for his negligence herein; but he is not thereby depriued of the office. Thirdly, that being ordinary to the King, and essentiall to him: it could not be, but bee extraordinary, and onely accidentall vnto the Minister. Fourthly, that the power that the Minister had to exercise this office of the King, was extraordinarily made lawfull by the power of Christ: who onely (necessity so requiring) might l • wfully transferre for a time, the exercising of this royaltie, to the Ministers of the Church: Fiftly, that the Lord Christ might leaue the royaltie in the king, and yet giue the honour and the practise of his duty to the Minist • r. The Lord left the sword ciuill in the handes of the King, and framed vnto the Church a sword ecclesiasticall, for the execution of the ciuill duety of the king: and thus in persecution to gouerne the lay men of the Church, he framed an ecclesiasticall sword: as otherwise in peace he framed a ciuil sword, to gouerne Ecclesiasticall men, and Ecclesiasticall affaires: so that the distinction of the sword made no disti • ction of the office: Sixtly, eyther of these two were inabled by God to gouerne the Churches in their times, without the other: and therefore to this end are as powerfull now, as euer they were before. Whence I inferre, that seeing it is ordinary, and essential to the King to gouerne the Church, and extraordinary to the Minister, and but only accidentall: that the king executing his gouernement, the Church must n • t execute it too: the king executing it by his ciuil sword, the Church must not execute it by his ecclesiasticall sword. For this is an infallible rule, that when that office is set vp in the Church, to which it belongeth ess • ntially to gouerne: that then the gouernement must departe from that office wherunto it was but accidentall, and cleaue vnto that, vnto which it is essentiall, and ordinary: for the Church is not to content it selfe with accidents, which are the baser and lesse noble, when it may enioy the very essence and substance of things: and extraordinary thinges must then cease, when ordinary may be had. And seeing that the right and duety to gouerne the Church abideth still in the
King: and ther • being nothing wanting in him, but the ex • cution of his owne office, which is the good Gouernment of the Church: when he shall take vp this; the Church must let it fall: and whē he claimeth it asking but his own, the Church must not wrāgle, nor contend with the king for it; clayming it by their wrong, whē they cannot by their right, pleading possession of some hundred yeres, against the ancient euidences of kings, registred for an eternall memorandum in the holy writings of God. All which with one consent auouch this Gouernment to be the kings, and would you depriue him of his inheritance, and his right, because of his want, and your obtained possession? The king lost onely the pr • ctise of his duety, & this practise of the kings duty is all the Church found, so that the Minister was euer but the kings Vicar to gouerne for him, but extraordinarily deputed by Christ therto, not by the king. The king did not execute his office, & the Church found leaue, fauour and power from Christ, to execute his office for him: and therefore this power of the Church to gouerne for the king, in reason could no longer continue, then till the king would gouerne himselfe, and with his owne sword ciuill, as with his owne handes execute his owne office. For what reason, or what need, had the Church, by her sword Ecclesiasticall to gouerne the Church for the king: when he was willing and able of himselfe to gouerne it by his owne sw • rd ciuill? I conclude therfore, that he being but the kings Vicar, may be deposed at the kings pleasure. The case therefore st • ndeth thus betweene the kings, and the Church: the persecuting kings through their carelesse security lost the kingdome: vigilant and Christian kings found the kingdome, that their predecessors lost: the Ministers of the Church lost a kingdome, that their predecessors found: and found peace, that their predecessors lost: the members of the Church lost their ruling Elders; and found kings their noursing fathers, and Queenes their noursing mothe • s: so when kings lost the Gouernement, the Church found it; when the kings found it, the Church lost it. And thus in right, these Gouernements were euer disioyned, the Gouernment of the Church being a branch of the kingly office of Christ, ordinarily put ouer to kings, but extraordinarily to the Eldership.

div.head: REASON XVI.
div.p:
ANd this distinction for the seuerall times of their Gouernement must be kept, (if our brethrens doctrines bee sound,
that teacheth the Church to be the onely kingdome of Christ) vnlesse we will lift vp the Minister, aboue the king: and extoll the office of the person, and the power of the Minister, aboue the office of the person, and the power of the king Christian: (and extoll him aboue all that is worshipped, and aboue all that is called God, as the kings of the earth are. For the Prophet saith of them I sayd that you are Goddes: but ye shall die like men.) For if you will put vpon, & giue vnto the Minister in the dayes of peace, the whole person, & office of the king Christ: and make him the full Vice-roy, of the king Christ, ouer his Church, which you hold to be his whole, and his onely kingdome: you giue him, and put vpon him, the very office, and person of a king: yea of the king Christ, who is the king of the kings of the earth. And a greater person then this, no king of the earth euer had, or euer shall haue; and so by consequent the office and the person of the Minister is as great as the office, and the person of the king: and beside this office, equall to the kings; you put vpon the Minister another office, more then the kings, and that is, the person, and office of the Priest Christ: and so make him a very Antichrist, another Christ vpon the earth; the full Image and Vicar of Christ: such as the Pope holdeth himselfe to be; and such a one, as is higher then all the kings of the earth. A Christian Minister therfore can not hold this office vnder Christ, immediatly in the rule of a godly king, except he wil make himselfe a greater person then the king. Of the king he may hold this power, if the king will, and at his pleasure, and so be vnder the king, as the Deputie of the king; who is the Deputie, and Viceroy of Christ: but to ho • d it, as our brethren bold, immediatly from Christ, as his Vicars, and Deputied immediatly by Christ, to gouerne for him, they cannot, except they lift vp themselues aboue all that is called God, and is worshipped. In the dayes of persecution, there being then no feare, least the Minister should lift vp himselfe in the greatnesse of his person ouer kings, might such an office, with more reason be put vpon him: Especially need so requiring. But now no need so requiring, for a minister to beare an office vnder a Christian king (that denieth the Minister no part of his honour) greater then the office of the king; is a way to lift him vp aboue the king, and so to make him Antichrist: and therefore in the Thessalonians, the hindering of Antichrist, is truely ascribed to the persecuting Emperour, that withheld the reuelation, that is the setting
of him vp. For he euer kept this person, that would be counted so great a person, vnder: but when he was taken away, then the Ministers being (as they held) so great persons, and honoured by kings Christian, according to their pretended greatnesse, lifted vp themselues aboue kings; and thus sprung Antichrist vp: so that if our brethrens doctrine bee true, then they must let fall their claime to the Church Gouernement, vnder a Christian king, or else be greater then the king. But if our doctrine be true, & theirs be false; then must they needs let the claime fall too, for the reasons aboue-said: and now let them chuse, which they will doe. For which soeuer be true, I will still hold, & conclude, that vnder a Christian king, the Church lost his Primitiue Gouernment Ecclesiasticall, and that the raigne of the Eldership is determined in the raigne of godly kings Christian: this the Pope not knowing, holdeth still his power like Saul, that hauing seased on the kingdome, would not part frō it, to his neighbor Dauid, & so is become Antichrist; this the Popish kings not knowing, doe slauishly leaue this power in the Popes hands: and this our brethren not knowing, forgoe their Ministery, because they may not obtaine this their desired, and now long thirsted after kingdome.

But my labour, and desire is, that all men may see with me this truth, and take knowledge, that there is something in the Ministery that is essentiall: which they receiued both then, and now, from the Church, by vertue of their Ecclesiasticall function: and that is the ministration of the word, and Sacraments: and there was something which was accidentall, and altogether mutable, and that was a branch of the regall, and ruling power: which departed from them, when the ordinary ruling power came into the Church, that was wanting before. And hauing lost this power, they cannot hold it now, but at the pleasure of the king: who if he will, may giue it ouer vnto others: or returne againe vnto the Church, the power ouer all, sauing ouer himselfe. For I hold, that the king is not to loose his place, nor to suffer himselfe to be topped by any subiect, in his kingdome. And sith some must bee free from all rule vnder heauen, in some things: as the Pope would be; it is most fit, that the king should be exempt from all vnder rule, and left vnto the immediate power and rule of God. As the Apostle left the vnbeleeuers, that were without, in some things, neither to the rule of the heathen kings, that would not, nor to the Church that should not iudge them: but onely vnto
the iudgement of God, saying, doe not yee iudge them that are within? them that are without God shall iudge: and here obserue their contrariety, that hold a necessity of their discipline in all the Church, and yet except from discipline the head of the Church; which is the king, and if they except the head, I will except the body; for the same is the reason of the whole and the part.

div.head: REASON XVII.
div.p:
BVt our aduersaries haue subscribed, not onely vnto the Gouernement, but vnto the supremacie also of the king: with the which I plainely see that Ecclesiasticall Discipline cannot stand. Without Ecclesiasticall Discipline, the king is supreme Gouernour of all persons, as well Ecclesiasticall, as Ciuill: but with Ecclesiasticall Discipline, the king is vnder the rule of the pastors, and Elders of the Church. For in Ecclesiasticall Discipline, the whole congregation of euery particular Church, consisteth of the rulers thereof, and of the people that are vnder their rule. The rulers are, either the Bishops, or the Elders of the Church: all the rest, whither they be iudges, or rulers of the land, Whither they be Lords, or Councellours, whither they be Kings, or Queenes, are to be ruled; and so by consequent, to be vnder the rule of the Pastors, and Elders of the Church. Now the king being no Elder, for that is to be lesse then the Pastor; nor no Pastor, for that sorteth not with his calling: must needes bee vnder the rule of his particular Pastor, or Bishop; if he be vnder, he cannot be aboue him, then not his supreme head. Then being vnder his rule, here must needs at the least arise a controuersie (as betweene the Bishop of Rome, and the Emperour) whither of these two should be the chiefe, and vnto whom the supremacie should incline. The Emperour he challenging it, because the Bishop was his subiect; the Bishop challenging it, because the Emperour being a member, & a child of his Church, was vnder the rule of him, the head and father of all his particular Church. Now to ende this controuersie, the Emperour he draweth his Ciuill sword: and the Pope draweth his Ecclesiasticall sword; and there begi ••• th array: the Emperour he sighteth against the Church, and p • secuteth it the Pope he rebelleth against his king, and excommunicateth him. And say, that it breake not forth into open warres: yet the seede, and sparke of this fire lying hidde within cannot but kindle inward grudge, in the king: because his subiects would
rule him: and in his subiects; I meane, his Pastors, and Elders: because hee will not bee ruled by them. Therefore the king must needs keepe vnder, or curbe Ecclesiasticall Discipline, or else bee kept vnder, and curbed by Ecclesiasticall Discipline. And either loosing his supremacie ouer the Pastors, & Elders of his Church, put himselfe vnder them, and vnder their authoritie; or else putting them downe, set vp himselfe, and his rule ouer the Pastors, and Elders of the Church.

I haue a heard a Papist say, that the Ecclesiasticall Discipline could not stand with an absolute Monarchy. For that it taketh away the supremacie from the king: and shareth halfe the kingdome (which is the absolute rule of all the Church, which is not halfe, but all the kingdome) with the king: and againe, I haue heard some of our aduersaries say, that Popery could not stand with a Monarchy: for that it taketh away the supremacie from the king, and vsurpeth authority ouer the whole Church in his kingdome, which is the whole kingdome of the land. The Pope, as Christ his Vicar, challengeth an immediate power from Christ, ouer all, yea ouer kings, and princes: and so our aduersaries challenge ouer all, yea ouer kings and Princes, a power immediate from Christ, to gouerne them all in the Church, as the Vicegerents, and rulers of Christ, yea as the Vicars of Christ: and then if they haue rule ouer the king, in like manner must they haue rule ouer all the subiects of the king: & indeed in a Church, confounded as ours is with the Common-weale, if the Pastors rule ouer all the Church, then they rule ouer all the kingdome: and yet farther, if excommunication may bee vsed in all criminall causes, as our aduersaries hold: then haue they power to rule ouer all the kingdome, in all causes, as well Ecclesiasticall as Ciuill. And thus of them both, is brought forth this monster in nature: that the king should bee ouer all, and yet vnder his subiects: that the king should gouerne in all causes, Ecclesiasticall and Ciuill: and yet the Church gouerne in all causes, as well Ecclesiasticall, as Ciuill. And I wonder that a Papist can see this monster in our aduersaries, and not in the Pope. And againe, that our aduersaries can see this in popery, and not in their Discipline Ecclesiasticall.

And thus I heare either, to accuse each other, and if either of both say true, then neither of both is sound, and a friend to the Kings suprem • cie: although to speake for our brethren: I thinke that they are prooued to hold against the supremacie,
more by force of reason: then by any experience of disloyaltie. And although they cannot hold their discipline, with the supremacie: yet before, they thought, in the error of their iudgement, that well they might vphold both. Onely this in our brethren is to be misliked: that hating Popery: in this point they should be rancke Papists, though ignorantly. And that praying against, and laboring to discouer Antichrist: themselues •• ould ioyne with, and vphold Antichrist: yea in that wherein he is Antichrist? For if this ma • eth the Pope Antichrist: for that he lifteth vp himselfe in his rule aboue all that is worshipped, or called God: and they ioyne with them in this, and say, that the Church, that is the Bishoppes of the Church haue this power indeede, ouer Kings and Princes: and so vphold them in that: doe they not vphold the Pope, in that very thing, that maketh him very Anitchrist? And thus I see, how zeale without knowledge, and a desire to set vp the Church discipline ouer kingdomes, and Kings, set vp vnawares Antichrist himselfe: and mounted the man of pride to that great and wonderfull height. And euen then, when in Rome was set vp the authoritie of the Bishoppe, or chiefe Pastor of Rome, ouer the Emperor: then was set vp Antichrist in Rome.

And here if any man aske of me? why it being the will of God that the rule of the Church should then cease, when Emperors became Christians, that it was not plainely so mentioned, and expresly reuealed in the Scriptures? my answere is: that the Lord would leaue a way by hiding this for a time, (which hee would open in his time) for to let in, and to set vp Antichrist: whom he would reueale in his time: euen as in hiding the end of the law of Moyses, he laid a snare, to take therein the vnbeleeuing Iewes, whom of old hee purposed to cast of. And heere brethren consider, what a grosse error it is, to hold a discipline against the supremacy of the King: which is in your owne iudgement, to hold treason: and to hold an opinion against the proportion of faith. And how little it becometh Christian men, to vphold the raigne of the Popes, and the Bishop of Rome, ouer the Emperour and ouer the Kings of the earth. And therfore for my part hauing subscribed to the Supremacy, I make no bones of it, to subscribe to the present Gouernement established by our godly, and Christian King.

div.head: REASON XVIII.
div.p: ANd here because our Brethren be delighted with Quaeres I will propound a few vnto them.
And here first I demaund, Whither the Apostles during the Primitiue times were not the supreme heades of the Church next and immediately vnder Christ Iesus?
2. Whither the Bishops or Eldership next succeeding them, were not as they were, the supreme heads of the Church?

3. Whither in these dayes there be no alteration from those dayes, but that the Bishops or Eldership of England be now, as they were thē, the supreme heads of the Church of England, next and immediatly vnder Iesus Christ?

4. There being (as one of their side saith) no vniuersall▪ nor nationall nor diocesian Church: but euery Church being a P • rishionall Church: I demaund whither I. S. being the Minister of Saint Clements, be the supreme head of the Church of S. Clements, next and immediate vnder Iesus Christ?
5. Whither euery particular Minister be not the supreme head of euery particular Church of his, as well as I.S. is the particular head of his?
6. Whither the Minister being the s • preme head of the Church, the king can be supreme head of it too? whither can there be two supreme heads on the earth, of one and the same Church?
7. There being no nationall Church in England whereof the King can be head, and being head of no parishionall Church in England, what is become of the Kinges supremacie ouer the Church of England?

div.head: The second Question.
div.p: SEcondly, I demaund whither a body merely Ecclesiasticall, and not any way politike, can haue, as it is a body Eccl • siasticall, a head, that is merely politike, and not any way Ecclesiasticall?
Whither the head, and the body must not be of the same kind, nature, and sort?
What manner of body they make, that sowe a mans head, to an Asses bodie?

2. Whither two bodies really being in nature; and being both of a different nature: and seuer done, from another: and both liuing can haue • nd liue both, but by one head? much more, whither 500000 bodies all seuerally, can bee sufficed by one onely head, & that of another sort, & kind as they hold the king to be?
3. Whither doth not this argument well hold? the Church, and the Common-weale, haue but one head, Ergo they are but one bodie?

Whither the bodie being a bodie mixed, and a compound, of parts Ecclesiastique, and Politique: the head must not bee a me • ber answerable thereunto? that is a head, a Gouernour, or an officer, partly Ecclesiasticall, and partly politique, some thing like to your lay Elder, whom you hold to be a lay man: and yet a Church officer.

4. Whither the King being a Person, mixed of a lay and a Clergie gouerning man, be not as fit a head to gouerne lay and Clergie men, by his owne sword, as their gouerning Eldership, much weaker, & baser then the king, was to gouerne thē by a borowed sword? & whither he may not fitly stand in the place of that pulled downe? and what losse should the Church haue, if so it were?

div.head: The th • rd Question.
div.p: THirdly, I demaund whither it belongeth not to the King, as a part of his kingdome, to gouerne all the people of the kingdome in all affaires of the land?

2. Whither discipline doth not claime a right in the authoritie and name of Iesus Christ, to gouerne all the people of the kingdome, & that by no authority nor sword of the king, in almost half the affaires of the kingdome, as in the matter of witchcraft, idolatry, heresie, blasphemie, swearing, profaning of the Sabboth, wrath, vsurie, couetousnesse, whoredome, drunkennesse, backbiting, slandering, and such like?
3. Whither Iesus Christ came into the world to take from Caesar, those things that are Caesars? to take from euery king Christian, the one halfe of his kingdome, and to giue it to the Church?
4. Whither the power and office of the king be not out of all question, of God?
5. Whither that power that giueth all to the king, be of God? and that power that giueth not all to the king, but onely halfe to the king and halfe to the Church, be of God too?
6. Whither you thinke him the kings friend, that layeth claime to halfe his kingdome?
Whither he that claimeth a right to gouerne halfe the affaires of the kingdome, doe not claime a right to gouerne halfe the kingdome?

div.head: The fourth Question.
div.p: FOurthly, I demaund what necessitie there is, that the king should punish some sins, & not the Church: & that the Church should punish some sins, & not the king: as vsually was, & is done and yet, that both the Church and the king, should punish all sins iointly? as some hold & how can these contraries stand together?

2. Whither the Primitiue Church punished all sinnes? And againe, whith • r it ioyned with the king, in punishing all sinnes? If it did not, whither they that vrge, and presse this, and stand for this, doe vrge, and presse, and stand for the Gouernment of the Primitiue Church?
3. Whither the Church punishing all with the king, doth not iointly gouerne all with the king? and so shareth the whole kingdome with the king?
4. Whither if it so fall out that the Church will not punish, and the king will punish a man, what wi • l follow▪
5. Whither the king be the sole king of that kingdome, where the Church shareth the kingdome with the king?

div.head: The fift Question.
div.p: FIftly, I demand, whether the kingdome of the king doth consist rather in outward honor, & wealth, thē in power, & rule?
2. Whither he that deuideth the rule with the king, doth not deuide the kingdome with the king?

3. Whither tne Church doth not claime as absolute authority, & right, and that not in right nor authority of the king, but in her owne authority and right, to gouerne by her owne sword, and her owne lawes, all the subiects of the kingdome: as the king doth to gouerne them by his sword and his lawes?
4. Whither all the s • biects of the king, be not also the subiects of the Church, if their challenge be good?
Whither the Church be not then halfe ruler, and halfe king, with the king?
Whither the king be any more then halfe king, and the Church halfe king?
Whither but halfe the kingdome be Christs? why doth not the Church claime all the kingdome, sith Christ will not be contented with halfe.

div.head: The sixt Question.
div.p: Whither al heathē kings, in whole kingdom the Church is not be not without the Church, sole rulers ouer their subiects?
Whither then Christian kings should not bee sole rulers as well as they?

Whither the heathen king turning Christian must loose his former praerogatiue, his monarchy, and sole rule? whither for becomming a Christian, must he be punished with the losse of halfe his kingdome?
Whither Christian Religion doth indeed depriue kings of any part of their kingdome?

div.head: The consequents and conclusions inferred vpon these Questions.
div.p: FRom the first I inferre, that this Church hath lost the supreme Gouernment, that the Primitiue Church had, it is deuolued to the king.

From the second I conclude, that their ruling Elder meerely spiritual, as a head not fitting a mixed body, is taken away, and insteed of him another fitter, and worthier set vp to gouerne this combined Church.
From the rest I conclude, the Gouernment to be departed from the Church, or else the Church to bee halfe Gouernour of the kingdome with the king.

It they deny that they haue power and right in the immediate authoritie of Christ to rule ouer the Church of England, which containeth and includeth all the subiects of the king, they yeeld me the question, and denie their Primitie Gouernment, and the Church Discipline. For the Primitiue Gouernment, or Church Discipline, as they hold it, is nothing but a certaine power, immediately by Iesus Christ, giuen to the Elders of the Church to gouerne the Church, by the censures of the Church: now he that denieth this right, denieth his Primitiue Discipline.

If they auouch that such authority and right they haue: they take halfe the kingdome frō the king: they equall & shole themselues with the kin • , in the Gouernement of his kingdome: they deuide the kingdome with the king: and make them • elues halfe kings, and the king the other halfe king Now if they haue such a right, let thē speake it out, and claime their right, & if they can, let thē proue it vnto vs, let thē challenge it boldly as the Pope doth.

I conclude the fore that the Church must loose her kingdome, or the king his kingdome; the one halfe of it at the least now whither hath most reason to yeeld vp his kingdome, iudge you? And here note that the contention is who shall be king, a sweete contention for Christian Ministers, that pretend all humility and lowlines of Christ; and whither doe better the subscribers that yeeld it, or the gainesayers that refuse it?

div.head: The seuenth Question.
div.p: Whither did not the Primitiue Church exercise her Gouernement, without the leaue of the kings of the earth?
Whither may not the Church now exercise the same Gouernment without the leaue of the king?
If they say that it may, they ioine with the Brownist, that setteth vp the gouernement without the king.
If they say it may not, they denie the Church to haue the same power to rule now vnder a Christian king, that it had vnder the heathen kings, and so they giue me the Question.
Whither they, that haue all authoritie to gouerne the Church from Christ immediatly: haue any mediatly from the king?
If they haue no authoritie from the king, why doe they expect the King?

div.head: The eight Question.
div.p: WHither doe you not hold, that the king may neither alter, nor yet immedi • tly by himselfe exercise the Church Gouernement? onely he must establish it, and vphold it?

Whither he that may not immediatly, but onely mediatly, administer or exercise the Church Gouernment be the next, and immediate gouernour of the Church vnder Christ? This opinion therefore denieth part of the Supremacy.
And heere, I pray answere mee this argument, that seemeth in mine eyes very reasonable.
That Gouernment of the Church, that the king (being Christ his Deputie) may not administer, he is not tied by Christ to vphold or establish:
The Primitiue Gouernment he may not by himselfe administer:
Ergo, he is not tied to vphold the Primitiue Gouernement.

And heere for my resolution, giue me an instance, but not in eodem, of a Gouernement established by the chiefe Lord and king, to the vpholding whereof he createth a Viceroy, or Deputie, that may not by himselfe administer, or execute that Gou • nment: me thinketh it a very vnreasonable thing, that a Dep •• ie should be inioyned to doe that vnder paine of life, that himse • fe if neede be, may not doe.

That the Lord Christ should commaund his Deputie the king to see that the Gouernement of the Primitiue Church should vnder him be administerd, & exercised: and yet restraine him from
the administration, and exercise thereof: this is as if he should bid him run, and then tie his legges.

div.head: The ninth Question.
div.p: IN the Primitiue Church all the sinnes of the Parish were punished in the consistory of the same Parish, as you say: and this approued by the Apostles. In Scotland the sinnes of twenty Parishes in one Consistorie; and this is approued by you in the latter Iewish Church: all the sinnes almost of the Church in the one Consistorie of the Sannedrim: why may it not be so in England? Is the place a matter of essence, or circumstance? is the person that punisheth, be he Lay, or Clergie man, a matter of essence, or circumstance • both punished in the Primitiue Church, as you say.
