Is the instrument a matter of essence, or circumstance? as whither sinne be punished by a Whip, a Halter, a sword, fire, or excommunication? cannot God be satisfied if sinne be punished, except it be punished by a Lay, and Clergie man, or by excommunication?

div.head: REASON XIX.
div.p:
ANd heere to grow to an end, I demaund whither the iudiciall Law of Moyses being giuen in the wisedome of God, as the fittest pollicie, in iustice, to gouerne the Iewish kingdome, may not by Christian Kings be brought into, and set vp in their seuerall Dominions? And heere I know, that howsoeuer they hold it not a matter of necessitie, yet they will not denie, but that it is lawfull for Christian kings to set it vp in their seuerall Domitions. If this be graunted, then I see there may be a Christian Kingdome of Priests, a great and flourishing Church, gouerned exceeding well, and flourishing with all goolinesse, and yet wholy want, and be altogether without Ecclesiasticall D • scipline. For the Iewish kingdome, and Church ioyned both together, and gouerned according to the iustice and pollicie of God, for many hundred yeeres together prospered, and was without all exception passing well gouerned, vnder the god • y Kings, and yet • ltogether without Ecclesiasticall Discipline. Yea I see there may be a kingdome, (plotted by God himselfe, and a Church ioyned with a kingdome (from which sort wee must take our patterne) planted by the pollicie of God him • elf • and by the same pollicie of God gouern • d euen as th • Primitiu •
•• urch was gouerned by another pollicie of God with the which Ecclesiasticall Discipline
cannot stand. For in the Iewish kingdome, all sinnes being iustly punished, according to the iudiciall law of Moyses, by the ciuill Magistrate, there were no sinnes left to be punished by the Ecclesiasticall censures: there was then no vse, nor place at all, in such a kingdome as that, left for the Discipline of the Primitiue Church. Now then if the kingdome of Iewrie, and the Church affixed thereunto, might be gouerned by another policie of God, then the Primitiue Church pollicie was, and yet bee allowed, nay planted of God, and flourish without Ecclesiasticall Discipline: may not trow you, the kingdome of England, and the Church affixed there vnto, be gouerned by some other pollicie then the Ecclesiasticall pollicie, and yet be gouerned by the very pollicie of God: planted by God himselfe: and flourish passing well, without Ecclesiasticall Gouernment? If with the kingdome and Church of the Iewes, gouerned by the pollicie of God, this their Ecclesiasticall pollicie of God, could not possibly stand: then the like kingdome being here, as there was; with our pollicie of God, could not bee placed, nor stand their pollicie of God. And thus the pollicie of God, should not stand with the pollicie of God: the Ecclesiasticall pollicie of God, with the Ciuill pollicie of God. And therefore they were neuer made both by God to stand both together: but the one, that I meane of the Primitiue Church, to haue his place in a single Church, where the kings were wanting: the other, I meane that pollicy of the Iewish kingdome, to haue his place in a Church compounded, as ours is, with a Common-weale, where-ouer one Christian king beareth the whole sway. And thus God in mercy hath giuen a pollicie in his word, for a Church persecuted: which is to haue his place in a Church persecuted: and a policie for a Church peaceable, vnder a Christian king: that is to haue place in such a kingdome. And I wonder that our aduersaries see not this distinction: and consider not how God hath giuen a seuerall kind of Gouernment, to these seuerall and diuerse kinds of Churches, and what reason they haue to thrust vpon a Church peaceable, that kind of Gouernment, that God gaue to a persecuted Church, and so confounding the order of God, and nature of things, to giue the forme of one thing, to a diuerse, and almost contrary thing: the forme of a persecuted Church, t • a Church that is peaceable; and florisheth vnder a goly king. And herefully and finally to determine the question.

I demaund whether, a Christian king may not punish all sinnes whatsoeuer, by the Ciuill Magistrate: as the kings of Iudah did, by the law of God? And I doubt not, but that they will easily yeeld vnto me this. If then the king may punish all sinnes by the Ciuill Magistrate: then are there none left to be punished by the Discipline of the Church. If there be no sinnes to be punished by it, then is there no vse of it; nor nothing at all for it to do there: if it hath there nothing to doe, and if there be no vse of it; then is it vtterly laid on the ground, ouerthrowen, and made void, and vaine in such a Common-weale. And therefore in some Common-weales there is made a meere nullitie of Ecclesiastical Discipline; but our Common-weale is such, or may be easily made such: Ergo, in our Common-weale there is, or may be a meere nullitie of Ecclesiasticall Discipline. And so it is plaine, that it is not of neces • i •• e imposed by God vpon all Commonweales. for it is not by God imposed vpon such a one, as I mentioned now. And then, if our Gouernment be, or may be, in that number, and of that sort, and kind: then is it not of necessitie imposed vpon our Church, and kingdome; All sinnes may be heere punished by the Ciuill Magistrate: Ergo, there neede to bee none left to the Ecclesiasticall censures: Ergo, there may bee no vse of them, in this Church, and kingdome of ours: Ergo, they may bee vtterly taken away, or suffered to sleepe, in this kingdome of ours. And heere I charge our aduersaries, before the liuing God, that shall iudge all flesh, that if euer they meane to reply, besides the rest, that they remember to shape me a sound answere, without cauelling, to this argument of mi • e, or else to subscribe with vs to this Gouernment of ours. For I hold the argument to bee demonstratiue, and vtterly vnanswerable; and to confesse the truth, it is that reason that fully resolued me, that hung ind ff rent before, and was swayed onely that way, whither I was carried by the force of • rgument. And if any man be not obstinate, nor wilfully blind, it may let him see, that Ecclesiasticall Disciplin • is not of necessitie to be set vp in this, and in all other kingdomes of the world, as our aduersaries would make all men, and vs too, if they could to b • l eue: for surely, if all sinnes (to repeat it once againe) may be p • ni •• ed by the Ciuill sword: then there are none to bee punished by the Ecclesiasticall: then there is made a meere nullitie of it in a kingdome, as this is. And thus it is plaine, that there can bee no place for their Eccl • siasticall Discipline, but onely
where kings gouerne ouer loosely: which is a thing altogether vnlawfull for Christian kings.

But men being by nature hold-fast of their opinion, and in loue with the child and daughter of their owne braine: and being loth to be taken in such a fault, and to haue it discouered, being hardly brought to beleeue that they haue erred thus long and to confesse it; being ashamed to be conui • ced as deceiuers of the people, and to haue it proued that they vented vntruth, & set abroach errors, in steede of the Gospell: enuying this, that a weake man, and a man of my place, should see that light, that for so many yeeres hath bin hidden from them: rather then they will haue this Discipline of theirs (for the obtaining whereof they haue suffered so many things) thus to be set packing: and as an Idle one to bee banished out of Christian kingdomes; they will set it a worke, and find something for it to doe, yea in such a kingdome as wee haue already spoken of. And therefore, though without it a Christian kingdome may be gouerned passing well, and abound in all godl • nesse, and religion: yet they perchaunce will hold (though it be absurde, and too grosse) that it is a matter of necessitie, that with the Ciuill, should bee ioyned the Eccl • siasticall Discipline: and that the king may not punish all sinnes by the Ciuill Magistrate onely. And that it is a notable sinne, to diuorce these two Gouernments asunder: and that in no case, it is lawfull for the Ciuill Magistrate, to proceede to censure, or to giue sentence, without the Ecclesiasticall: and so they will finde a place for euer in all Common-weales, for their Ecclesiasticall Discipline.

But if it be a sinne for the Church, with the censures therof, not to ioyne in punishing sinne, with the Ciuill Magistrate: Oh Lord how long haue euen our aduersaries themselues liued in this sin? that haue all this while (being fully perswaded that this had bene their dutie) and that against the light of their consciences, omitted this their bounden dutie.

If it be a sinne for these two Gouernments to be diuorced: then for many hundred yeeres together, vnder Moyses, and all the Prophets, the whole kingdome of the Iewes sinned, and that by Commission from God, that ordained all sinnes to be punished onely by the Ciuill Magistrate, without the Ecclesiasticall: and setting not vp the Ecclesiasticall Discipline, diuorced these two Gouernements asunder.

And heere I would know how or when kings Christian lost this power to rule the whole Church and Common-weale, by the sword Ciuill, without the Ecclesiasticall: who, as all godly kings set vp and approued by God, euer had power and authoritie so to doe.

Yea the whole Primitiue Church sinned in this point, and that by commandement from Paul: who forbidding them to excommunicate them that were without, did not suffer the Church, to ioyne with the Common weale, in punishing of sinne.

Yea the Sannedrim, Iesus Christ our Lord, and the Apostles of our Sauiour Christ, sinned, in that they ioyned not with Herod, with Pontius Pilate, and the rest of the Romane gouernors in punishing of sinne: but we feare not to sinne with the Churches of all ages, for so many hundred yeeres together: with the blessed Apostles and with our Lord and Sauiour Iesus Christ himselfe.
If it be a sinne, in punishing sinne, to diuorce these two Gouernements: let them bring forth the commaundement of God for the combining of them together, and we will feare, and confesse our sinne.

But if they cannot bring forth any commandement, as I know vndoubtedly that they cannot: yet let thē bring forth some one example out of the word, for the approuing hereof. I aske them, did the Iewish Church and Common-weale, both plan • ed by God, euer do • so? And it is plaine that they did not: all sinnes were punished there by the Ciuill Magistrate onely, without the Eccles • asticall. Nay, did Christ, the high Preiests, the E ders, and the Sannedrim, proceede against the two theeues crucified with Christ, by Excommunication, when Herod, and Pontius Pilate proceeded, to giue against them the sentence of death? and I know that they are not able to shew this. Nay did afterward the Primitiue Church ioyne, with the princes of their land, in punishing the sinnes of the land, and it is plaine that they did not; they were forbidden so to doe, as we said before. Nay those sinnes of the Church, that were punished by the heathen lawes, as treason, murder, theft, and such like, did the Church punish, in the members, and in the b • ethren of the Church? And it is plaine that it did not, they were stinted and concluded by Paul, 1. Cor. 5. within their compasse: and he named vnto them the particular sinnes, that they should punish with excommunication: and they were adulterie, couetousnesse, idolatry, rayling, drunkennesse,
and extortion: all which were made lawfull ynough by heathen kings, especially extortion, was a thing vs • all in their Publicans, and in many of their officers, but was intoll • rable in a Christian man: and as they medled not with the sinnes punished by the Church: so the Church medled not with the sinnes punished by them But their iurisdictions remained dist • nct, and this distinction of either iurisdiction hath bene continued from hand to hand euen f • om the P • imitiue, to this Church of ours: where you see this diuorce of the seuerall iurisdictions to be continued, as we receiued it of auncient time, from the former Churches. And yet fur • her, looke into the Churches of Scotland, France, and Flaunders: and you shall in no time, and in no age, and in no place of the world, find in all things, this combination of Gouernments, that some men of ours haue dreamed of.

Now then, if they can shew for doing of it no commaundement out of the word, nor no example, neither out of the auncient Church of the Iewes, nor out of the latter Church of Iewry: nor out of the Primit • ue Church, (whose onely example they presse vpon vs) neither out of any ancient, or newly planted Commonweale. (though our newer Common-weales be more corrupt • d then the auncient were) nor yet out of all ages of the world: how will they tye vs to ioyne together these, that the word, and the world, neuer did before? and goe about to make vs beleeue, in diuorcing of these, that wee are guilt • e of s • ch a sinne, as the word, the world, and all the Church of God, neuer knewe before? Surely before I would holde such stuffe, to holde in Discipline: and before I wou • d broach a lye, to vent a shadow of t • uth: before I would holde such paradoxes, to make men beleeue, that the moone is made of greene che • se: I would l • y my hand vpon my mouth, and dash my pen against the wall. If I could not defend Discipline, but by defending this position: I would rather a thousand times subscribe, and I should therein commit a hundred times lesse absurdities, then in holding of these tearmes: but we must let goe words, and come to reasons.

Wee haue shewed before, and that from the example of the Iewish kingdome, and Church, that a kingdome, and a Church combined as ours is together, without their Ecclesiasticall Discipline, may florish, and be gouerned by another pollicie, that is of God, as well as theirs is: and may without all exception be ruled
passing well, yea exceeding well. And is it a sinne, if our kingdome and Chur • h be not gouerned better then passing well? If it be not better gouerned then it is possible to be gouerned? If it be not better, th • n the best that euer was? Be • ng a bo • , I learned no degree aboue the sup • rl • tiue; and being growen a man, I can reade of none higher. If they haue another Grammer, or another Art, th • t teach • th a higher degree▪ let them vent their new found, I had almost said, new fond Art, and we will bee glad to learne any true, though it be a new thing. For mine owne part, I neuer fancied Platoes Common-weale, nor Sir Thomas Mores Ʋtopia: n • r any such Common-weales, or Churches, as dwell in the cloudes: and are fetched from beyond the Moone.

If th • re be such a necessity for the coupling of thē both together: then it is, for that the one without the other, is not in iustice sufficient, for the reuenge of sinne: or in mercy, for the preseruation of the sound, from the infection of the sower leauen: or in power, for the eff • ctuall working of repentance. For beside these I can see no other end, for the necessarie combination of these two.

And first, concerning the punishment of sinne, I hold, that it is a suffi • ient punishment, to punish treason, and murder, two of the greatest sinnes, with death: and so it once seemed in the wisedome, and iustice of God: that proportioning the punishme •• , to the sinnes, ordained by the iudiciall law of Moyses, no othe • punishment for these two sinnes, but onely death, without the excommunication of the Church. And then was it ynough in those dayes: and is it not ynough now in these dayes and times of ours? was it iustice then: and is it not iustice now? how is that become a sinne now: that was i • stice, and very righteousnesse then? and that by the sentence, and iudgement of God himselfe: or what, shall we condemne God of vniustice: that giuing lawes, and punishments for his people, appointed not punishments, iust, and sufficient ynough, for the sinnes of his people?

In sinnes of the lesser nature, to vse excommunication (the greatest punishment of the Church:) and besides this, to adde to excommunication, some other ciuill puni • hment, to make it more sharpe: is not iustice: which euer proportioneth the punishment to the sinne: but extreame crue ty.

In the greater sinnes, which death (then with there was none more heauy ordained for his owne people the Iewes) to ioine excōmunication (then which there was no greater punishment, ordained by God, for the beleeuing Gentiles) is to lay that vpō one which God ordained as sufficient, to be laid vpon two: namely vpon a sinning lew, & vpon a sinning Christian Gentile; & so to be twice as seuere as God is, twice as iust as God is; which is not to be iuster then God, but to be too too cruell indeed. When the iudge bindeth the hands of the t • iefe, for the Church also to bind his sinnes in heauen, and earth: when the ciuill iudge giueth his body to the hangman: thē for the Elders to giue his body & soule to the diuell: when the Shiriffe hangeth & killeth the body; then for the church to hang, & to kil his soule, in hel fire, is not iustice, but a meere butchery of body and soule, that my soule abhorreth, and a punishment, which the Lord reserueth to his last, and to his owne iudgement seate: and for vs being men, is farre more vnmercifull, then to seeth a Kidde (that is a poore sinner) in his mothers milke: which is the excommunication, of his mother the Church: and b • side, it is cleane contrary to the practise of the Primitiue Church▪ that in matters of death did neuer vse excommunication at all. For the Primitiue Church vsed excommunication onely in those sinnes, where ouer the Chu • ch had power. But the Church had neuer power ouer the cases of death: Ergo, the Church did neuer vse it in the cases of death.

But being mercifull men, perchance they will hold one of them to bee ynough for punishment: but both of them, to bee little ynough, for to breede repentance. And therefore, they will haue them to be ioyned together onely▪ to worke repentance effectually: very well, then they must be ioyned together onely in those cases, where the law respiteth the death of the sinner: which falleth not out in a thousand cases, in one yere; and then in these cases by their own confession, without sinne they may be diuorced, Ergo, by their owne confession, in some cases, without sinne, they bee separate, and put asunder, the one from the other. And what if vpon this we should conclude, (that the ease standing alike, in the whole, and in the parts) that in all other cases, without sinne, they may stand apart, and one without the other bee put in execution.

But how haue our brethren forgotten their owne rule? Nay the rule of the Apostle: which is, that wee may neuer doe euill,
that good may come of it. And therefore, that wee may neuer vse vngodly cruelty, to beget most godly repentance thereby.

But what? is it true indeede, that without excommunication, death inflicted by the Ciuill Magistrate, is not sufficient, to beget repentance? De • th inflicted vpon Ach • n, brought forth a most humbled confession, without excommunication. Death, without exc • mmunication, wrought repentance in the thiefe, that was crucified with Iesus Christ. Death, without excommunication, hath wrought it, as our eyes haue seene, in many thousand sinners, that haue suffe • ed death, by the onely hand of the ciuill iudge: and how hath the ciuill Magistrate, and his imposed death, lost his auncient, and his wonted force? how, hath it of a sudden become weake, that in all ages hath bene so powerfull to effect repe • tance?

How many of the children of God, being neuer touched by the ciuill Magistrate, but being smitten only, by the immediate hand of God, and that with some lesser punishment, haue taken this smiting of God to the heart, and haue beene truely touched in their hearts, with godly sorrow, that bred repentance, neuer to be repented of?

Remember saith Salomon thy latter end, and thou shalt not sinne for euer. If the bare remembrance of death, as witnesseth the ho
• y Ghost, be able to driue a man from sinning, and so by consequent, to driue him vnto repentance: what can the presenting of it to the view doe, and the setting of it before the eye of the seeing, and beholding sinner?

The houre of de • th is the farthest, and the last time, that the sinner taketh with himselfe, for the beginning, and accomplishment of his repentance: so that when the houre of death is come, the very prefixed time is come, that he set to himselfe, to repent in: and then either he must indeed repent, or else without all help of • fter repentance, be damned for euer.

And although the ciuill Magistrate, neither doth kill, nor intend to kill the soule: yet without repentance, the Lord, who on
• y may lawfully do it, then killeth the soule, when the ciuil Magistrate killeth the body: then doth God seperate the vnrepentant sinner from himselfe; and from the company of the blessed soules, and from the Saints on earth; when the ciuill Magistrate, doth seperate the sinner, from the land of the liuing: and then doth
God giue ouer the soule of the wicked man by excommunication from himselfe, to the diuell: when the ciuill iudge, doth giue ouer his body, vnto the executioner: and therefore excommunication is really contained in the ciuill punishment: and with greater power inflicted by God, and by his hand; by meanes of the Ciuill Magistrate, then it can be inflicted, by the Church of God. For the church doth but represent it, but death doth present it; the Church doth but foreshew it, but death doth really shew it: the Church doth but put in the feare, but death putteth in the feeling of it; the Church doth but giue the sentence, but death giueth the present sence of it: and is the very executioner of excommunication. So that if excommunication be of that force, to breede repentance; it is not wanting in the Ciuill censures: though the Ecclesiasticall censures be wanting there. And when it is without imputation of vniustice, ministred by God, more effectually, by the hand, and meanes, of the Ciuill Magistrate, and euery sinner euidently knoweth, and seeth, and heareth this: alas to what end shall it, with lesse power, and that with the blot of vnmercifull dealing, be ministred by the Church of God? and he that feareth not God, that he may repent: h • w will he be afraid of the Church of God? and if a sinner feare not to be excommunicate, and seperated by God: how will he feare, and be brought to repent, by the bare excommunication of the Church? An • when the Ciuill Magistrate doth it with more power, and all sufficiently: it is too iridiculous, to doe the same thing by the Church, and lesse in effect, and more farre vnsufficiently.

In a cast-away, both ioyned together, are not able to worke repentance: in the child of God, one alone, without the other, is of power sufficient, able ynough to worke it: in a cast-away, both are bootelesse, in the child of God, both are needlesse: and therefore neither in the good, nor in the bad, is required a necessary coniunction of both these.

And howsoeuer they will not acknowledge this sufficiency to the Ciuill Magistrate onely: yet I hope they wi • l not denie it to Ecclesiasticall censures alone, which we see wrought repentance in the incestuous person of Corinth; without the Ciuill Magistrate: which wee see by experience to be of power to conuert some, which they themselues would therfore ioyne with the Ciuill sword, that it might bring foorth repenta • ce, and which they hold to be a holy meanes, giuen of God, to this end, that it might
beget repentance in the man, that hath fallen away by sinn • : will they so disgrace their owne censure, that it shall not be all sufficient without the addition of the Ciuill sword?

And surely, had this combination beene a matter of that importance, and of that necessitie, I assure my selfe, that the Lord would not haue denied both, to his owne, and peculiar people the Iewes. Nor to his owne, which was the first, and the Primitiue Church, but in that he giueth to them both, but either of them both: he plainely lets vs see, what the iudgement of God is in this case: and that is, that either of them both, is of power, and all-sufficient, to worke repentance, in all that belong, and appertaine to the calling of God: and then if one, without the other, be sufficient to worke repentance: In vaine is it to vse more meanes to worke that, which by fewer meanes may be wrought as effectually.

And as for the preseruation of the sound, from the infection of the wicked, there can be no better meanes to effect that: then to make an vtter seperation betweene them, and of seperations, there can bee none either more full, or more finall, then that, which is made by death: by the which the corrupter of men, is vtterly taken from among men: and seperated finally from the sonnes of men. And being cut off from the earth, can neuer hurt the men of the earth any more. Now this seperation being made by the Ciuill Magistrate, is farre more full, then the seperation, that is made by excommunication: and therefore to effect this by the addition of excommunication, to the Ciuill sword, is more then palpable folly.

I conclude therefore, that if for the reuenge of sinne: or for the breeding of repentance: or for the preseruation of the good: there be no necessary coupling together, of the Ciuill, and of the Ecclesiasticall censures required: then is there no necessary reason that may, or can inforce, the necessary coniunction of these two at all. But wee haue shewed before, that for none of these causes is required, any necessary coniunction of those two censures: and therefore, it followeth, that of those two, there is required no necessary coniunction at all.

div.head: REASON. XX.
div.p:
ANd yet further, if of necessitie the Church, and the Ciuill power, must be ioyned together in all things: then they must ioyntly proceede, not onely to punish sinne: but also, to iudge betweene brother and brother, in matters of controuersie, and in cases of right and law. And indeede, the Apostle, that in the fift to the Corinthians, and the latter end therof; inuested the Church in the right, and power to punish sinne by excommunication: in the very next words, which is in the beginning of the sixt, giueth power, and authoritie to the Church, to iudge betweene brother and brother, in matters of law; so that the Church, by the authoritie of the Apostle, hath as good right, to iudge in matters of law: as it hath, to iudge in matter of sinne. If then, they must ioyne with the Ciuill Iudge in cases of right: then must wee pull downe our seates of iudgement, and build gr • ater: that may containe, not onely the Iudges of the Law, the Iustices of Peace, and their Officers: but also, the Ministers, and Elders of the whole Shire: then must the Ministers turne their studies, to looke out what is right, and law in matters of controuersies: then must they cease, to waite onely vpon the Ministerie of the word: and intermeddle with all cases, and controuersies of the whole land▪ then must they deale in all those cases, wherein the iudges, and Iustices of peace, are tied by their office to deale; a thing which they permit not, no not to the Bishops of the Chu • ch. And little reason shall they haue to condemne the Pope, for vsurping authoritie in Ciuill cases; when they themselues hold it still to bee the right of the Church: & themselues intermeddle therein. But if vnder a Christian King, and vnder Christian Iudges, they hold this to be no necessary duety of the Church; how doe they hold it, vnder a Christian king, and vnder Christian Iudges, a matter of necessitie, for the Church, with the ciuill Iudge, to punish sinne? And if they can see, that the power to iudge in matter of right, was but extraordinary, and onely for the times of persecution, and for want of Christian Magistrates: how commeth it to passe that they cannot see that the power to punish sinne, was only extraordinarie, and for the dayes of persecution, and f • r the want of Christian Magistrates? For they haue no more power to doe the one, then they haue to doe the other; and the power to doe the one, they must hold to haue ceased: or else they must hold
the absurdities afore mentioned: now let them choose of these two, which they will hold.

And here I might stand to bring forth those particular cases, wherein the Church ought not to ioyne with the Ciuill Magistrate, in punishing of sin; as in the cases of death, of present repentance, and such like: and here I might shew the great questions that might arise about their manner of proceeding: the fittest places, and the fittest times; the great also inconueniences, the manifold absurdities, and the meere impossibilities, implied herein, all which I omit: hauing dwelt already ynough, if not too long, in this point. And thus I haue plain • ly prooued, th • t it is no sinne to d • sioyne, nor no matter of necessity to conioyne together, both these aforenamed censures.

But though they cannot hold it to bee a matter of necessitie, yet perchaunce they will hold it to bee a matter of expediencie, and that it were meete for the better Gouernment of the Church, to be set vp in this, and all other kingdomes of the world. But whither it be meete, or not meete, I will be no iudge in this case: but leaue the t iall of that, to men of more wisedome, and of better iudgement then my se • fe am. For if they hold it a matter of no necessitie, but onely of indifferencie; and that where it is found expedient, it may be vsed: where it is found a matter of inconueniency, there it may be refused; they giue me my question, and hold with me, that vnder a Christian king, it is a matter meerely indifferent: and that there is no necessity laid vpon the king, to entertaine it, or to set it vp, in this land and kingdome of his.
If therefore they hold it but a matter of expediency: they giue me my question.

If th • y hold it a matter of necessitie, I shewed them their error, and therefore vpon the praemises I conclude, that the king by the Ciuill sword onely, may punish all sinnes, without the Ecclesiasticall: and so leaue no vse no place; nor nothing for Ecclesiasticall Discipline to doe, in this Realme, and kingdome of his. And thus my argument remaineth firme, demonstratiue, and is not, by any possible meanes, to be answered.

And thus they graunting, that the Gouernment of the Iewish kingdome, and Church; is not to vs necessary: and wee hauing proued, that the Gouernment of the Primitiue Church, is neither a matter of necessitie to vs: it followeth, that it is free for
the king to set vp either of them both, or to ioine together either of them both, or to receiue neither of them both: and therefore, that it is lawfull for the king to set vp some other (if it may be) more fit, for Godlines, and peace, then either of them both bee. And then, if it be lawfull for the king, without sinne to set it vp; it i • lawfull for vs, without sinne, to subscribe thereunto: and thus it is plaine, th • t we in subscribing to this godly and peaceable Gouernment of the King▪ haue committed no sinne, neither are we guiltie of Apostacy, or of treason to God, to his Church, or to his holy truth. But of sound knowledge, and of faith, & of infallible grounds out of the holy word of God, in peace of conscience, and in the peace of the Church, haue lawfully subscribed to the holy Gouernment of the Land, and Church.

And thus, wee haue spoken in regard of the apparent trueth of the cause, something too much; in regard of our enemies and friendes, fully ynough: but in regard of our selues, something too little. For we desire at full, to let the world see, with what feare of God, with what care of our consciences, and vpon what sound grounds, wee haue proceeded. How diligently wee haue searched out the trueth, & how we haue looked into euery • ooke and corner of the cause.

And therefore in a word, wee will handle one point farther: for the satisfying of our enemies, and for the clearing of our selues: and that is, that this Gouernement of ours, onely in a necessarie circumstance, a • d in no materiall point, differeth from the Primitiue Gouernement of the Church. And this necessary circumstance, is in the onely addition of the officers, and the power of the King, to the auncient officers, and the power of the Church. And that to this end; that the king, as his duetie, and place requireth, may see, that the censures of the Church be iustly, without all partiality, put in execution.

And heere to shew you this, I must tell you first: that in this our Church, wee haue in vse all the censures of the Primitiue Church. For wee haue in vse admonitions: lawfull for the ministers, and the Elders of the Church: we haue suspension from holy things in vse, and lawfull for the minister alone; and we haue in vse excommunication, lawfull for the minister to administer: but so as the approbation, and coniunction of the king, and the officers of the king, for the faithfuller, and more forcible proceeding be first had, and obtained: and these are all the censures, that euer
were in vse in the Primitiue Church.

And as we haue all the ruling censures in vse, that euer the Primitiue Church had; so haue we all the same officers, that the Primitiue Church had, for the putting in execution of the Primitiue censures. For the officers of the Primitiue Chu • ch, that onely, or principally intermedled in the administration of the Church censures, were either lay, or else ministeriall Elders: the ministeriall Elders were either the Pastors of the Church; or els the holy Apostles and Euangelists of Christ, to whom it was giuen to ouersee, and ouer-rule the whole Church: as for the lay Elders, they haue their being, & standing place in this Church of ours, vnder the name & title of Churchwardens, and Sidemen, to whom it is made lawfull to ouer-see the maners of the whole Church, to giue to the offensiue parties, holy and wholesome admonitions, & of the greater offences, to informe themselues, their particular Pastor, & together with their Pastor, to informe the officers of the King; & so iointly to proceede to the execution of punishment, vpon the offensiue perso • : the Elders therfore of our Church are the first, that espie & detect the fault, that giue countenance, and consent, to the punishing of the fault, & desire vnder their hands, the help of the king, for the punishing of the fault, and this is, as I can soundly gather, all that the Elders had to doe in the Primitiue Church.

And if any be iniured, or haue cause to complaine, it is the particular Minister; but let vs see what iust cause of complaint is ministred to the Ministers. First, as watchmen, they haue power to spie out the sinnes of the whole flocke: they haue power to admonish, to reproue, to exhort, and to rebuke them that sinne openly. Secondly, they haue authority to suspend, and for a time to seperate from the supper of the Lord, the offensiue man: onely the absolute and free power to put in execution excommunication (the weightest censure of the Church) for the causes afore mentioned, is restrained, till the king be fully informed; of the needfull, and the iust vse thereof. And the sinne being once made knowen vnto the king (that is to the officers of the king) and the sinn • b • i • g found to deserue so, the king as the first in place, giueth his consent, and his sentence first: and the minister as the second vnder God, and the king, ioineth in the next place his sentence, and power with the power of the king, and thus the offensiue man is seperate from the Church, and cast out thereof,
in the name of God, and the king. So the minister, is the first, that with the Elders, seeth the fault; the king is but the second, that searcheth out, and looketh into the accused sinne: the Minister, with the Elders, are the first that detect the sinne: the king is but the second, that examineth the detected sinne; the Elders, with the ministers, are the first, that thinke the sin to be worthy of punishment, that giue their allowance, & countenance therunto: the king is but the second that well waigheth, first the cause, & considereth, whither it deserue excommunication; the minister, first consenteth, and in his priuate iudgement, excommunicateth the person; craueth and desireth the authority, and consent of the king: the king is the second in all this, and consenteth not, but vpon reasonable and iust cause: and so maketh a wise stay of all rash and partiall proceeding, and layeth a bridle vpon all sinister affections of the ministery. But the king vpon sound deliberation, and weighing well the matter, consenteth to the minister; and as he is first in power so onely in this one thing is he the first, that pronounceth the sentence; and the minister onely in this is but the second: and thus, where the cause is iust, there ioyne together, the king and the minister, in throwing out of the Church, a wicked man; the king first pronounceth him, then the minister denounceth him, to be an excommunicate person: and thus the minister hath his share, and interest in excommunication, as had the Pastors of the Primitiue Church: but restrained, as needs must be; that the authoritie of the king, may come in betweene, and haue his iust place in the Gouernment of Gods Church, and though by this meanes, there be made some stay; yet the stay is recompenced, with the sound, and more adui • ed proceeding: and with the addition of the power of the king, to the power of the Church; and if in this circumstance, there be any other proceeding then iust, the fault is in the corruption of the persons; and not in the sinne of the course. And here what other cause haue our ministers to complaine, as if they were wronged; saue onely that they are ouer-looked, and ruled by the king, and be not as absolute monarches in their Church, as the Pope is in his, or the king is in his? and now let our aduersaries speake, if such a one be an intollerable circumstance: and whither a man, by reason of this, is iustly, and with a good conscience, withheld from subscription to the present estate.

And thus, because the Church is increased with the person, and
the power of the king: therefore the Church, beside the auntient officers thereof, hath receiued the increase of the officers, of the king; and these are the seuerall Bishops, of euery seuerall diocesse: which our aduersaries hold, to be an ouerplus, and an vnnecessary burden to the Church. But I hold them, in, and ouer the Church, as necessary, as is the officers, and power of the king. For they bare the office, the rule, and the person of the king, in, and ouer, the whole Church. And therefore more plainely, to lay out this, to the vnderstanding of the simple: they must know, that in the person of the king, (who is, as our lawes hold him, a person mixed, of a lay, and a spirituall man) is inuested, the Gouernement of spirituall, and of lay men: the Gouernment therefore of the land, and the Gouernement of the whole Church of the land. Now the hands of the king, being by nature too short, to reach forth his Gouernement from one end of so great a kingdome, to the other: are by Arte Politique, made exceeding long: by ioyning thereunto, the armes of inferior men: all which fastened together, lengthen out the armes of the king, and make him able for the smiting of a sinner, to reach, from one side of the kingdome, to the other: and from one end of the Church, to the furthermost part thereof. The king therefore, being not able to ouersee his subiects, without his subiects: for the better ruling of his subiect Church, and land: (according to the councell of Iethro, to Moyses) communicateth, and imparteth, to some sufficient, among his subiects, a little beame of that his imperiall rule, and Gouernment, ouer the whole Church. And the persons to whom the king hath giuen of his spirit, that is, of his power to gouerne the Church, the men, the affaires, and the censures of the Church, are the Lords spirituall: that is the Reuerend Bishops of the land, whom the king hath increased, & made great by giuing vnto them so great a power, by imposing vpon thē so great a person as his owne is; & answerably thereunto, by indowing them, with Barronies, and with the wealth and titles of great, and mighty Lords. Now these by the authority, and power of the king, being set ouer a whole Diocesse; that consisteth perchance, of many hundred parishes: are not possibly able, with their own eyes, to view and ouersee the manners, and seuerall sinnes, of so many hundred Ministers, and of so great a multitude of men: nor yet in all those places, the right execution of the Primitiue Church Gouernment, without the helpe of their inferiour men:
they therfore are inforced againe, to set vnder • hē, some Commissaries, some Archdeacons, & some Officials. And these setting • p, and holding for the purpose a Court Spirituall, receiue information, of all open, and notorious crime • : and these men (the consent o • the Pastors, and Elders first had, by thei • pr •• entment: the cause so requiring) doe in the name of the king, and in the name of the ministers, and the Elders, draw out the sword Ecclesiasticall, and put it againe into the hands of the minister: therewith to smite in the name of God, and the King, the offending man. And thus it appeareth, that an addition of some such officers, must of necessitie, vnder a Christian king be had, to ouersee the right execution of the Primitiue Church Gouernment: or else, the Church of England must be exempted, and set free, from the supreame authoritie of the king: as the Church of Rome, and the Pope is; but our aduersaries by their subscription approue not this. And although the laying of this bridle vpon the ministers, layeth open a gappe, to many inferior Officers, of much bribery, and partiall dealing: yet for any thing I see, it openeth thereunto, no greater gappe, no, nor in reason, so great as it would; if the bridle were taken away, and the Ministers left, to Lord it ouer their seuerall flockes. And therefore, if the king; then the officers of the king, be necessarily added to the Church of God: and if the king be not, how shall wee count the officers of the king, a burden, to the Church? but the spirit of Antichrist would be free, and bee set aloft, would rule, and ouerlooke all, but would be ruled, and ouerlooked of none.

But heere ariseth a question, where about our aduersaries wrangle exceeding much, & that is: whither the king may not take of the ministers of the Church, as wel as of lay men, & set them in his place, to rule ouer the Church; to ouersee the particular proceedings of euery Church, and indue these ministers, representing his person, with the honour, the titles, and liuings of Lords. And howsoeuer it is vnsauery in the sense of our aduersaries: yet to me it seemeth a thing exceeding harde, that the ministrie of Iesus Christ, and the publike seruice of God, should keepe him from all worldly preferment, and for euer after, (as if he had bene conuinced of some notable crime) make him vncapable of all Ciuill honour.

But heere to prooue the Ministers vtterly vncapable of all Ciuill honour, they alleage the saying of Christ to his D • sciples, contending
for the supremacie. Mat. 20.26. You know (saith Christ) that the Princes of the people bare rule ouer them; and they that are great men exercise authoritie ouer thē: & (as Luke sayth, Luk. 22.29) are called gratious Lords: but it shal not be so among you. From hence they inferre, that by Christ it is forbidden to the Ministers of the Church, to beare the titles, or the office of gratious Lords: and verely so well might they seeme to doe, if these were words of commandement, and spoken indifferently to all the ministers of Christ.

But for my part, I hold, (first) these words to concerne the after Ministers of Christ nothing at all: but to be spoken onely to his Disciples, as many other things were. For these words were spoken onely to them, the people being absent; and that not vpon any doctrine before deliuered: but by occasion of a priuate controuersie betweene themselues moued, and that was, which of all thē twelue, Christ being a temporall king, (for so they often before, and euen then dreamed) should carry the greatest sway, and be the most gratious, and honorable Lord; matters, out of all controuersie, onely concerning themselues, and their priuate honours: and touching the after Church of Christ, nothing at all; to this Christ maketh that answere before mentioned: and therein telleth them, that vnder him, and in his kingdome, which was not of this world, they must neuer hope for, nor expect, those honourable titles nor that lordly nor earthly rule: that in the courts of earthly kings, and princes of this world, such honourable titles might be had, but in his kingdome it was not so. And therefore their honour should not consist in the possession of offices, and titles that were of that nature: but rather in the painefull worke of their Ministery, in the which, whosoeuer was the most painfull man, should be the most honourable man. So that if their controuersie was onely concerning themselues, and touched the Church of God no farther, then onely in the knowledge hereof, as out of all doubt it was; and if the answere of Christ was direct to their question, as out of all controuersie it was: then it must needes be spoken to the Disciples of Christ onely, as many other things were: and therefore not to touch, nor to bind the after ministers of Christ any thing at all: no more, then they are conmaunded to preach the Gospell to all nations of the world, because the Disciples of Christ were commaunded so. And yet this better appeareth, by the answere it selfe, that Christ maketh to
his Disciples: for that, the answere of Christ teacheth plainely an equallitie betweene those persons to whom he speaketh, he (saith Christ) that will be the greatest among you, let him be inferior or seruant vnto all: but among the Apostles only in office, & honor, there was an equallitie: and not betweene the Apostles, and Prophets; nor betweene the Apostles & Euangelists; nor betweene the Apostles and Pastors of the Church. There are diuersitie of gifts in the Church: an Euangelist, is more then an ordinarie Minister of the Church; a Prophet is more then an Euangelist: and an Apostle, is more then a Prophet, and more then euery Minister else of the Church. They are Ministers of Christ (saith the Apostle) I speake like a foole, I am more. There being therefore difference betweene the Apostles, and the after Ministers: and this being spoken only to thē where there was no difference, but an equallitie: could not equally be spoken to the Apostles, and to the after Ministers of the Church: and therefore are these wrongfully applied vnto them.

Secondly, I say, that euen these words thus spoken by Christ, to the Disciples of Christ, are not a simple forbiddi • g of them to take this honour, but a pl • ine foretelling of them, that they should not inioy this honour: to you (saith Christ • it sha • l not bee so. This word shall, is a word of the Indicatiue Moode, a • d the Future tence which foretelleth onely that it shall not be so; and not a word of the Imparatiue Moode, which indeede fo • biddeth, th • t it be not so. If I say to Iohn a N • kes, you shall not e Bishop of Canterbury, I meane not to forbid him, but only foretell him, that he shall not inioy the place: so Christ only foretelleth them, that they shall not enioy honor: but he doth not in one word forbid them to receiue it, if any would make the man offer therof: & yet this better appeareth, for that in vaine it were for Christ to forbid thē, the entertaining of such honor •• s in his foreknowledg he saw should neuer so much, as once be tendered, or offered vnto them. Persecution & Bonds waited for thē & of this he foretold them: but lordships, and honour attended them not: and of this in this place, he foretold them, but forbad it not.

A Prophet (as Elias) well might, and indeed did take vnto himselfe, the title of a lord, when it was giuen him by Obadaiah, one of the lords of Achab: much more, may an Apostle, who is more then a Prophet, if it were tendered vnto him, by any of the Emperours, or kings of the earth.

The Elder that ruleth well, saith the Apostle to Timothy, is worthie of double honour: especially such as labour in the word, and in doctrine. I aske, what this double honour is? is it not worldly wealth? is it not authoritie ouer the Church? is it not reuerence? the putting of the capp? the bowing of the bodie a reuerent, yea, an honourable appellation, or title? or what? doth the word honour, that is to be giuen by all, exclude an honourable title, that is giuen by the king, and taken of our Bishops? this were strange. Pardon me, Christian brethr • n, if I interprete these words by you brought, in a sence something differing from the expositiō of other, but agreeing with the words of Christ, the occasion of the Apostles, the proportion of faith, the very proprietie of Grammer, the vse of the Church, and the very light, and manifestation of reason.

And yet further, if these words of Christ forbid the office, and title of a gratious Lord, to the ministers of Christ: then they forbid also to them, the exercise of authority ouer others. For he that saith, they are called gratious Lords: saith also, they exercise authoritie ouer others: and by that commaundement, that sayth, it shall not be so with you, forbiddeth both alike. If so, then as the Ministers must not be called gratious Lords: so they must not exercise authoritie ouer others. If they must not exercise authoritie ouer others, neither must they exercise that Discipline Ecclesiasticall that they presse vpon vs so much: for Discipline Ecclesiastical, is authoritie Ecclesiasticall. But you will not denie, that Christ denieth vnto you the exercise of your authoritie Ecclesiasticall ouer your Churches, any thing in those wordes to the contrary notwithstanding: and then may not (thinke you) the Bishops, with as good reas • n thinke, that Christ doth not in those wordes denie vnto them, the offices, or titles of gratious Lordes, any thing in those wor • es to the contrary notwithstanding? or are you not partiall in the interpretation of those wordes? interpreting that which seemeth against you for your selues: and setting that vpon the racke, (giuing leaue to no reasonable interpretation,) which maketh against the Bishops.

And here brethren, let me a little wade with you in this your exposition of this place: wee vrge you, that Christ forbiddeth, euen s • , and no otherwise, the exercising of authority ouer others, then as he doth the t • king of the titles of gratious Lords: the answere
of some of you to this is, that Christ forbiddeth onely the exercising of Lordly, or tyrannicall authoritie ouer others: and not the exercise of lawfull Ecclesiasticall authority; and is not this I pray you the very answere of the Bishops to these words, and for the other part of the sentence also? and doe you not see, that you are driuen to the very same interpretation, for the vpholding of your Discipline, that they are for the vpholding of their Lordships? and yet is the answere good, as it commeth from, and serueth for you? and is it naught, as it commeth from, and serueth for them? brethren, this is no good dealing.

But others answere, that Christ forbidding the exercising of authority, forbiddeth them only the exercising of ciuill authoritie. And these men you see plainely answere, by making a distinction: and shewing, that there are two sortes of authoritie; the ciuill, and the spirituall: and that Christ forbiddeth onely to his Disciples the one, and not the other; very well, heere you take libertie to answere by a distinction. And if you may take libertie to doe this in one part of the sentence: may not the Bishops take libertie to answere the other part of the same sentence, by the same distinction? and say likewise, that as there is a ciuill and a spirituall authoritie: so there are ciuill, and spirituall Lords to exercise those authorities: and that the Lord forbiddeth them onely to be Lords Temporall: but not to be Lords spirituall; and so by this your owne answere, you must receiue an answere to your owne obiections.

And so by this answere of yours, if it be right, the meaning of Christ must be to forbid his Disciples, of poore fishermen, & Disciples persecuted, to become great, and honourable Lords Temporall: and to intermeddle with the greatest offices and sway of the Iewish Common-weale. A thing in my iudgement, so farre from the meaning of Christ, that I may say of this, that recitasse, is r • futasse: to repeate it, is vtterly ynough to refute it. For who seeth not, that Christ vseth, as others, to forbid such things, as men are likely to fall into? but there was no likelihood that euer the Disciples of Christ should become Temporall gratious Lordes: that is Dukes, or Peeres of the land, and carry the Gouernement of the Iewish Realme: no the Lord often foretelleth them this will neuer bee: it is therefore ridiculous to thinke that the meaning of Christ was to forbid this: but it is not so to thinke that he did foretell this.

So that if for the vpholding of your authority, you expound those words, as spoken of tyrannicall authoritie, you lumpe with the Bishops, if as spoken of ciuill authoritie: you make your selues an answere: and what farther answere shall you neede?

And yet farther, let it be graunted, that Christ forbiddeth to his Disciples the rule and the titles of Ciuill Lords: because hee would not haue his Church erected by countenance, and authoritie Ciuill: least the worke should seeme to come of man, and not of God: Yet how doth it follow, that in a Church erected by pouertie, there can bee no place for riches, and Ciuill authoritie? and sith Christ forbadde it to the twelue: how doth it follow, that therefore hee forbad it to all the after Ministers of Iesus Christ? as if the Lord did enuie all riches, and worldly honour to those, that he hath made heires with Christ, of this world, and the world to come.

And yet further, say that a Minister, as he is a Minister of Christ, may not inioy the title of a Lord: yet how is he heere forbidden, as he is the minister of the king, and beareth his person, to receiue the • ame, if by the king it be put vpon him? I conclude therfore, that this place of Christ proueth it not to be vnlawfull for the ministers of Christ, to receiue the wealth & titles, of gratious Lords.

The second place that is brought by our aduersaries against the Lordship of Bishops, is taken out of the first Epistle of Peter, 5.3. where the Apostle exhorteth the Elders of the Church, to feed the flock which dependeth on them: and to take care of it, not by compulsion, but willingly; not as lording it ouer the lords heritage, but as ensamples of the flocke: all which, it is plaine, that the Apostle giueth not as a law, to forbid ciuill lordships to a Bishop: but imperious, and stately rule, to a minister. For the Apostle forbiddeth that sin that was incident, not only to aftertimes: but that which was incident to the times that were present then. But though the sinne (as they call it) of ciuill lordship, be incident to our dayes: yet was it not incident to those troubled, and persecuted daies, of the Primitiue Church. Secondly, the Apostle giueth this precept to the particular ministers of euery seuerall, and lesser flocke, and not to the ouerseers of the Church: such as Timothie. Titus, and our Bishoppes are: and therefore it is falsly wrested against them. Thirdly, it is giuen to the lawfull Elders of the Church: and then if our Bishops bee not, as our aduersaries hold it, the lawfull elders of the Church, this precept concerneth
them nothing at all: and though the lesser and inferior ministers, may not be Lords: yet how doth it follow, that the ouerseers & rulers of the Church, may not be Lords? fourthly, the Apostle doth not forbid lordship in, or to the Church: but lordly raigning ouer the Church: a Bishop may be a Lord, and yet not Lord it, nor Lord-like raigne ouer the Church: but in all vprightnesse, humility, and high lowlinesse, rule ouer it. A Barony, is a priuate honor to the Bishop: and not a publique power or lordship, ouer the Church: and the Apostle forbiddeth n • t the rule, but the corrupt manner of rule, ouer the Church. Lastly, it is plaine, that the word lording is a Metaphor, taken from euill and vnciuill, ciuill lords, and applied to the Ministers of the Church, forbidding them, so to raigne and rule ouer Gods flocke, as euill lords raigne ouer their flocke. But heere let vs a little examine this point. What? doth the Apostle here forbid that rule of the Primitiue Church, that else where is permitted? And it is p • aine, that he doth not; how then? doth hee forbid the Elders to rule their flocke aright, & withall vprightnes, as godly lords rule ouer their subiect people? no neither: how then? Doth he forbid the Elders to rule the Church with the ciuill sword, as godly Lords rule their flocke? if this be the sinne that the Apostle forbiddeth to the Elders; then of this sinne, are not our Bishops guiltie. Who gouerne the Church by the Ecclesiasticall, and not by the ciuill sword: what is it then? Surely, the Apostle forbiddeth the Elders of the Church, so to rule their flocke: as euill Lords, rule their people; but how doe euill lords rule their people? Surely thus, they commaund others to giue to the poore; but themselues will giue nothing: they informe others to keepe the law; but they breake it themselues: they by maine power, and by very force compell other to doe well: but by no godly example of life. Now thus to gouerne and to rule the flocke, the Apostle forbiddeth the Elders of the Church, and chargeth them, not to goe about by the meere Discipline of the Church, • wher ••
• uer they had power) to driue imperiously the people of God to obedience: but rather, by their godly ex • mple of life, to draw the • thereunto, and therefore to lording ouer the flocke, which he forbiddeth • he opposeth the example of godly life: which hee commaundeth; an • therefore, by the opposition of godly exa • ple, to lording ouer the flocke, wee may (as by the contrary) see, what is meant, by lording it ouer the heritage of the Lord: and this being
the true sence of the place, let vs see, how out of this sence, they can draw an argument, to ouerthrow the honor, and lordships of Bishops.

And therefore to conclude this point, I reason thus, if a Lord Temporall (which I thinke no man will denie) may be made a minister, and yet hold his Lordship: then may Ecclesiasticall Ministery, and ciuill Lordship stand together. If he may be first a Lord, and then created a Minister: then may he be first a Minister, and after created a Lord.

And h • ere I omit the example of the high Priest, among the Iewes, the example of Samuel a Prophet, and a Iudge of the land; the example of Elias, putting vp this at the hand of Obadaiah; to be called my Lord El • as: and many other examples beside. these are sufficient, to proue that it is no sinne for the king to giue, or for the Bishops to take, or for vs to subscribe to the Bishops Lordships.

And thus as it appeareth, hath the king giuen ouerseers, and rulers ouer the Church: and indued them lawfully with riches, and titles honourable: but the question is, whither God, beside the ordinary ministers, euer gaue ouerseers, and rulers ouer the Church? if he hath, then the next question is, what their office is, and how fa • re it doth extend, and stretcheth it selfe? to these questions, for the cleering of our selues; and for the satisfying of our aduersaries must we needs make an answere: because, it is the opion of our aduersaries, that God neuer set any Bishops ouer his Church: and that their place is not of God, but altogether Antichristian.

And for mine own part, this I hold; and meane by Gods grace to proue: that God neuer left his Church, without generall ouerseers, and rulers ouer the Church: that is, ouer the standing Pastors, and people of the Church: and so by consequent, that an ouerseer, or Bishop of the Church, hath his standing, and place in the Church, as good, and euery way as allowable, and approued of God as euer the ruling Elders had.

And heere before I enter into the proofe of mine opinion, it is needfull, that first we should agree about the name of a Bishop, or the ouerseer of the Church: and to dispatch this in a word, a Bishop in the Scripture phrase, is put for the ordinary Pastors of the Church; but in our phrase, it is put for the ouerseer, or ruler of the Church: that is, for such a one, as hath a speciall interest in
the creation of Ministers, and in the administration of the Church censures that ouerseeth the life, and the doctrine of the Pastors, that looketh to the peace, and good order of the Church Such are our Bishops, and ouer seers of our Church, and such Bishops, and ouerseers, I meane to shew, were set into the Church by God, and as concerning the word Bishop, which is made of the Greeke wo • d, Piscop, by taking away the former, and latter Letters, if it offend any man, they may, f they please, call thē superintendents, in Latin: or overseers in English. If we agree about the matter: I loue not to contende about the name, and here I meane to prooue first, that euer God gaue ouerseers to his Church, and neuer left it free, from superior rule, and that it is a matter conuenient, to follow the forme, and patterne that God gaue to his Church, for the Gouernment thereof, in this point. Secondly that the Gouerners, and ouerseers that God gaue, weare altogether of the same nature, and had the same power ouer the Church that our Bishops haue.

And now to proue that God gaue ouerseers to his Church, I alleage, the manifest, & expresse example of the spirit of God, that first gaue Apostles to take vpon them the care, and Gouernement of all the Churches. Yea then, when the Churches were replenished, both with sufficient Pastors, and with ruling Elders. As appeareth by the example of Paul, that being from the Church of Corinth, reprooueth the Church there; for suffering among them that incestuous, and offensiue man: and ouer-ruleth them by his authoritie, and commaundeth them, together with himselfe, to cast him out of the Church of God. Secondly, this more euidently appeareth, in that the Apostles, in their absence, set Titus ouer the whole countrey of Crete: and Timothie ouer the whole Ephesian Church: and so it appeareth, that in the dayes of the Primitiue Church, ouer-seers had their place and standing, in the Church of God, by the apointment and ordinance of God himselfe. Now if such a Gouernment were, by the very confession of our aduersaries, such a Gouernement ought to be now. If such Gouernours to vse our aduersaries reason) by God were giuen his Church: such Gouernours ought to be giuen to our Church now. For the Church euer being, the Gouernous of the Church must of necessitie euer be.

But to take away this plaine, and manifest example of God, and proofe of ours; they haue no other escape, nor st • rting hole;
but onely to alleage: that Timothie and Titus, were Euangelists, and that by vertue onely of that calling, they held the ouerseeing power, and generall rule ouer whole Churches. But now, they simply, and truely hold that, those gifts are taken from among men of the Church: and therefore, they falsly inferre, that for want of those gifts, the Bishoplike office, is perished out of the Church.

In which answere of theirs, there are as many vntruths, as there be full periods. The first whereof is, that Titus and Timothie, did hold the ouersight of those Churches, by vertue of their Euangelicall functions. For the Apostles, that were not Euangelists, held it as well as the Euangelists did: and againe, the Euangelists hold it, as well as the Apostles did: which argueth, that it appertaineth not to either of them, by vertue onely of their different callings: for then it must haue beene kept proper to either, and seuerall, as their callings were: and not made common to both, but being by the Apostle set ouer, to the Euangelists, it is plaine, that it was proper to neither of their callings; but common to more.

To be an Euangelist, is to be free; and to follow the steps of the Apostles: and to build further, by the preaching of the Gospell; and not as ouerseers of some larger Churches to bee perpetually affixed thereunto. But it is plaine, that Timothie was affixed to the Ephesian Church; and if he were euer remoued, let our aduersaries (against the testimonie of the auncient, and vnparciall Church, that is, to the end of that Epistle to Timothie affixed) shewe that: but heere I must admonish them, that if they intend to shew that, they must bring better reasons, and proofes, then to shewe, that Timothie was afterward sent for by Paul. For the sending for him to come to Paul, argueth no more, the remoouing of him, from his affixed place: then to send for the Bishoppe of Saint Andrewes to the court, argueth the putting him out of his Bishopricke there.

It is in reason to bee thought, that Timothie so excellent an Euangelist, and of so long standing in his calling, knewe before hee was affixed to Ephesus, what did appertaine to his Euangelicall office. But what did appertaine to the Gouernement of the Ephesian Church, he sufficiently knew not, before the Apostle, with a new doctrine, and new rules,
for the new place had furnished him: & therfore he writeth vnto him saying; these things, haue I wrote vnto thee, that thou mightest know how to behaue thy selfe in the Church of God: that is in the Gouernment, and rule of the Church of God. E • go, he giueth him precepts for the Gouernment of Gods Church: which was to Timothie a new, and other office, then the Euangelicall office was, wherein he was so well experienced before.

And yet further, that this was the standing calling of the Bishop put vpon him, for his whole life, I argue: because Paul giuing him precepts for his particular behauiour there: chargeth him, saying, I charge thee before the Lord Iesus, keepe this commaundement without blame, and spot to the appearing of our Lord Iesus Christ: that is at the least, to Timothies dying day. Secondly, for that he giueth to Timothie, and in him, to the Church perpetuall, and euerlasting rules to proceede by, in the Gouernment of the Church: which I thinke that our aduersaries themselues will not, nor cannot denie. Thirdly, for that sitting there, the Apostle writeth vnto him a second Epist • e, (being now the second time to answere at Rome, before Nero, which was a very little before his death) and chargeth him to looke to that his Depositum, or office, in trust committed vnto him. 2. Tim. 1.14.15.16.17.18. And the subscription to the Epistle. 2. Tim. 4.6. All which argueth a long time of his sitting ouer the Ephesian Church, there he sat when Paul went to Macedonia, and there he sat, when Paul was to die at Rome. 2 Tim. 1.18. with the 2. Tim. 4.19. and 2.14.15.16. Fourthly, for that, if his placing there, had bene onely to adde some things left imper • ect, and so to haue left the Church, to the other officers of the Church, as the Pastors and Elders: in a short time, he might haue dispatched this businesse, and followed the Apostles steps. But the Apostle giueth him charge to ouersee the life, and the doctrine of the setled Pastors: and therefore though the Pastors, and Eldership were setled; yet ouer them still, was Timothie to abide an ouerseer: and not vpon the setling of them, to depart: and therefore there could no iust cause of his after remoue be alleaged, which was not euen then in being, when yet it appeareth that he was not remoued at all. And so it appeareth, that he had not the wandring function put vpon him of an Euangelist: but altogether a newe office, which was the standing office of a Bishop, as the subscription to the Epistle calleth him.

Timothie was set to ouersee the Church of Ephesus; therefore he executed this office of his, as an ouerseer of the Church of Ephesus: but the office of an Euangelist is one, and the office of a Bishop, is an other; differing therefrom. For if the office of an Euangelist, and the office of a Bishop be all one, then so many sufficient Bishops as we haue; so many Euangelists we haue: but we may let you easily see, and meane afterward, so to doe, that wee haue many suficient Bishops, for the ouersight of the Church: we should therefore haue so many Euangelists, which I hope our aduersaries will neuer graunt the king: a temporall Lord, set by the king; a superintendant, set by the reformed Church: are sufficient ouerseers of the Church; and yet no Euangelists I hope. It followeth therefore, that an Euangelist, and an ouerseer of the Church, be different offices. It thē they be different offices, & Timothie did execute his office, at Ephesus, as an ouerseer, then hee did not execu • e it, as an Euangelist; as falsely our aduersaries replied to our former argument.

The second error • n their answere is, that this ouersi • ht of the Church, being tyed to the greater callings, is perished with them: all which opinion of theirs, is vtterly false. For the greatest gifts dwelt in the Apostles, in whō was first set this gouerning power: the lesser gifts, were in the Euangelists, in whō also this gouerning power after dwelt: and therefore, necessarily, and plainely, I inferre from thence: that this gouerning power, is not proper onely to the greatest gifts, but common to these of lesser measure.

Secondly euen in these dayes of ours, there are men sufficient ynough, and very able, to performe all that the Apostle in Timothie requireth to the ouersight of the Church: which what it is, we meane to shew in our answere to the next question: if then there be in our Church, men of sufficient gifts, for the execution of the ouerseers office: then how is this function perished, as our aduersaries say, for want of sufficient gifts? For there being able, and sufficient gifts, for that office: I cannot see, that an ouerplus, or that gifs more then sufficient, are of necessitie required thereunto.

Thirdly, hauing the patterne of the Primitiue Gouernement giuen vs, and the gifts not giuen vs: I thinke it better, and more safe, to keepe the patterne, though we haue lost the gifts: which is to keepe one, when we cannot haue both: then hauing lost the
gifts, to cast away the patterne, & so, because we cannot haue that one, to cast away both: and that it is more true wisdome, to keepe in our Church, the patterne that God gaue, without the gifts: then with the want, ot the losse of the gifts: to loose, & to want, the image, and resemblance, of the Gouernment of God, and that it is better to proportion ours to that; and to come vnto it as neere as we can: though we cannot fully shole it, and match it euery way.

And thus doth our argument, taken from the Patterne of the Primitiue Church, stand firme, and sure; their cauelling reply to the contrary notwithstanding: & thus haue we, by a particular & manifest ex • mple, that cannot be denied, taken from the word of God, plainely proued, that ouerseers, & Bishops, were by God, giuen to the Primitiue Church. Now it is not in reason to bee thought, but that (these Bishops, Timothy I meane, and Titus, liuing & dying, in the midst of the Church) the Church would inquire, and aske of them the will of God, concerning their succession; & cōcerning the perpetuity of the office, that they bore, & that they resolued the Church, that the will of God was, that others after them should sit in their seat: and hold the helme, as they did in all the dayes of their life, of the troubled, and persecuted Church of Christ, & that by their appointment, successors were decreed, and agreed on. For I dare not perswade my selfe, that either the church then, being in his sincerity, would be so carelesse, or negligent, as not to inquire of this point, hauing the opportunity of an Euangelist, to giue them an answere: or so bold, & peruerse, as contrary to the resolution of Timothy, to set vp in his place, an ouerseer to succeed after him. But what do we need, to run to reasonable coniectures, when we haue an expresse commaundent to Timothy, for doing so? For Paul, that charged Timothy in his first Epistle, 1. Tim. 6.20. to keepe that which of trust was committed vnto him: that is, the sincere Gouernment, and doctrine of the Church: againe, in his second Epistle (to let the world know, that the same office at the time of his second Epistle, was still in the hand of Timothie) remembreth vnto him the speciall care afore commaunded, saying, O Timothy, 2. Tim, 1.14. Keepe the excellent thing that thou art put in trust with. And a few words after, he addeth, saying, 2. Tim. 2.2. What thou hast heard of me among many witnesses, those things commit to faithful men, which are fit also to teach other men. So that it is plain, that it was commanded vnto Timothie, to set ouer the thing, in trust committed vnto him, to others,
that are fit, and able men. But the thing in trust committed to Timothie, was the Gouernement of the Church, and the doctrine of Christ. The ouersight therefore of the Church, and the sincere doctrine of Christ, was by commaundement of God, to be set ouer by Timothie to others: able and fit men, not onely to gouerne (for that must bee vnderstood by his relatiue also) but also to teach others: and what can bee more plaine then this, to the proouing of a succession of Bishoppes, after Timothie, I cannot see.

And yet farther, to argue the vse, and gift of Bishops vnto the Church; I vse the like reason, that our aduersaries vsed, for the prouing of the perpetuitie of their ruling Elders, and I reason thus: that officer that by God is set into the Church, and hath there his gifts described, his office at large defined, hath his place of God, in the Church of God: But an ouerseer, or Bishop, in the person of Timothie, was set into the Church by God: and he hath in the word, his gifts, and his office, at large expressed, namely, in the whole Epistle of Timothie: Ergo, an ouerseer, or a Bishop, hath his place, in the Church of God, by God.
Againe, the office of Timothie, was to ouersee the Church (namely of Ephesus:)
But the office of Timothie, did not die with Timothie: ergo, the office of ouerseeing the Church, did not die with Timothie.

If the office of Timothy had beene to die with Timothie, is it like that the spirit, to shewe an office of so short continuance, would haue indited an Epistle, of so great a length: & haue giuen it to the Church, as a parcell of Gods word, that indureth for euer?

If the office of Timothie, being set out in a particular Epistle to Timothie, was made priuate, and particular to Timothie onely, and not common to more: then the other offices of the Church, by the same particular Epistle established, and appointed to be created, and ouerseene by Timothie, are to die, and to bee determined with him: the offices then of the Elders, the Pastors, the Deacons; the Widdowes, that were to be erected, and gouerned by Timothie, must die with Timothie; when beside Timothie, after his death, none such may arise that hath like power, as hee had, to ordaine, to create, to erect, and ouersee such officers, and such offices. For the creating cause being taken away: the creature it selfe, must needes bee taken away also with it.

The Apostle speaketh to Tim • thie the ouerseer of the Church, concerning the fit gifts of himselfe, being to ouersee the Church, 1. Ti. 6.14. & saith, I charge thee in the sight of God, who quickneth all things, that thou keep the commandement without spot, & blame, vntill the appearing of our Lord Iesus Christ. But how could Timothy, that was to the before the comming of Iesus Christ, keepe that commandement till the comming of Iesus Christ: and therefore, that it might be perpetuall, and till that time obserued, it must bee obserued of a Timothie: not in name, but in nature: not in the person, but in the office and succession of Timothie: that can make onely this rule perpetuall, to the comming of Christ. But the nature, the office, and succession of Timothie: was the nature, the office, and the succession of ouerseers: that therefore was to keepe that commaundement, till the day of the Lord. And therefore, if that commaundement implieth in it the Ecclesiasticall Gouernement, and chargeth the perpetuitie thereof, as some of our aduersaries haue vnderstood it: then as it chargeth the perpetuity of the Gouernment, so the perpetuity of the person, that must keepe the Gouernement; and the person that must keepe it, was the ouerseer, or Bishop of the Church: whom yet our aduersaries would throw out of the Church, and retaining the rule, cast out the ruler; and so vse, and refuse, at their pleasure; what pleased their owne humour: but vpon what reason let the reader iudge.
In the Church which is the best estate, there must not be a democraty, which is the worst estate:
But where ouerseers are taken out of the Church, and all are left in an equallitie of power: there is a democratie, or a popular state:
Ergo, ouerseers must not be taken away out of the Church.
Whatsoeuer good order requireth in the Church, that must be there:
But good order requireth a prioritie in calling, and a Gouernment ouer a body: whither Naturall, Politique, or Ecclesiasticall:
Ergo, such a calling, such a Gouernement, and such Gouernors must be there.

In all ages since Christ, the Ministers of the Church haue had their ouerseers: in the time of Christ, Christ held it ouer his Disciples; in the dayes of the Apostles, the A • ostles • eld it ouer all the Church: after them, the Euangelists held it ouer the whole
Church, all their dayes: and after them, the godly Bishops, that were the most notable and choice men of all ages, held it, vntill this day of ours: and had this bene so vnlawfull a calling, and so Antichristian, as our aduersaries hold it, would Iesus Christ haue held it? would the Apostles, Euangelists, the Martyrs, and Bishops of all ages, haue held it, so many hundred yeeres together? or must now the Ministers bee set free: that so many ages of the world, haue euer beene vnder the Gouernement, of superior Bishops?

God hath giuen ouerseers to his Church, the King giueth ouerseers to the Church: themselues set vp superintendents ouer the Church: and yet must ouerseers, or Bishops needes be taken away from out of our Church?

But I hope, that by this time, they see their error: I leaue therefore to prosecute this point, and I come to see, what manner of Bishops they were, that God gaue to his Church: and how farre their office did extend it selfe.

And this we may best see, in Timothie, whom God gaue an ouerseer of the C • urch: and in the Epistles to Timothie, which for that p • rpose were specially written, by the holy Ghost, and left as teachers for euer vnto the Church, to let the Church know, what the office and duetie is, of the ouerseers of the flocke of Christ.

And first in those Epistles, I plainely see, and it cannot be denied, but that Timothie and Titus were by their calling, preachers of the word, and so to doe, haue a speciall charge giuen them by the spirit of God. 2. Tim. 4.1.2. An ouerseer therfore, or a Bishop of the Church, by his calling, must be a Minister, and dispenser of the Mysterers of God.

Secondly, as touching his life, he must be an ensample of the flocke in word in conuersation, in charity, in the spirit, in faith, in puritie. 1. Tim 4.12.13. and 6.11.12. He must follow piety, faith, loue. patience, and meekenesse: he must fight the good fight of faith, &c.
