Thirdly, as concerning his exercises, he must giue attendance to reading, 1. Tim. 4.13. but bodily exercise, as that which profiteth but little, he must but little vse.

Fourthly, as concerning his office, to gouerne the Church: it stretcheth it selfe partly ouer the vnder officers of the Church: and partly ouer the people. His office ouer the vnder officers, is either ouer the preachers of the word; or ouer the others that
preach not the word: the other officers that preach not the word, are either men or women, bearing office in the Church: the men are Elders and Deacons, the women are the aged widdowes concerning all which, (excepting the lay Elder) the Apostle instructeth Timothie, what manner of persons they must be, that must by Timothie, to those functions be chosen: & what care is to be taken in the choice of them: and this is the first part of the Bishops office, to make a fit choice of able, and sufficient men, to occupie those roomes.
Secondly, hee is to haue a speciall stroke in the creation of Ministers, lay hands, saith the Apostle, rashly vpon no man. 1. Tim. 5.22.

Thirdly, being once created ministers, he is first to looke to their doctrine, that they teach not peruerse, and false doctrine: that they teach not fables, and genealogies. 1. Tim. 1.3.4. Especially, that about indifferent things, as meate, and marriage, they teach not that vnsound, and false doctrine, that was foretold by the spirit, to be broached in the latter dayes. 1. Tim. 4.3.
Thirdly, they must see, that Ministers make prayers, and supplications, and thankesgiuing, for all sorts of men: especially, for kings, and Princes. 1. Tim. 2.1.2.

Fourthly, he must looke vnto the life of the Ministers, and punish them if they be found in fault: receiue no accusation against an Elder, saith the Apostle, vnder two, or three witnesses. 1. Tim 5.19.

Fiftly, if the Ministers labour in the word, and are faithfull, he must see that due honour, and maintenance be giuen vnto them, the Elders that rule well, saith the Apostle, are worthy of double honor, especially, such as labor in the word, and doctrine. 1. Tim. 5.17.18. And these are his particular dueties, in regard of the Church Ministers: Ergo, here is an ouerseer of the Ministers, a Bishop of Bishops.

In the next place he is to looke vnto the peace of the Church, if any man, saith the Apostle, teacheth diuerse doctrine, and commeth not vnto the sound doctrine of our Lord Iesus Christ, and to the doctrine that is according vnto godlines: he swelleth, and knoweth nothing, but is mad about questions, and the contentions of words. 1. Tim. 6.3.4.5. Whereby riseth enuie, euill speaking, euill suspicions, peruerse practises, of men corrupted in mind, & which are depriued of the truth, and make gaine of godlines, depa • t from such.
Sixtly, he must looke vnto good order, and vnto comelinesse in the Church. I permit not a woman, saith the Apostle, • o teach, nor to vsurpe authoritie ouer the man, &c.

But the greatest matter of doubt is, whither the Bishop might censure the offending Christians, that liued vnder the Gouernement of seuerall Elderships, & vnder the power of their standing, and their ordinary Pastor. And for my part, I plainely see, from the doctrine, and practise of Paul: that Timothie and Titus, had a gen • rall commaundement to ouerlooke both the Pastors, and all their particular flockes: and therfore the Apostle giueth them in charge: to looke vnto the rich men, and vnto seruants, to ouerlooke women, and generally all men. 1. Tim. 6.17.18.19. and 6.1.2. Them that sinne, saith the Apostle, reproue openly, that the rest may feare. 1. Tim. 5.20. If he may openly reproue the open sinner, I make no question, but that he might also punish them, if the case so require, with excommunication. Exhort, improoue, rebuke, saith Paul to Titus, 2.15. with all authoritie: but without the administration of the censures, he could not withall authority rebuke: the vse of thē. Therfore, was permitted vnto Titus. An Heretick after the first, or second admonition, saith Paul, eschew. Tit. 3.10. Knowing that such a one sinneth, being damned of himselfe: he giueth him in those words expresly, power, to excommunicate Heretiques: if any man teacheth diuerse doctrine, saith Paul to Timothie, as we cited the place before, him eschew: he giueth in like manner to Timothie, authoritie, to cast out of the Church by excommunication, the Schismaticke, and the troublesome man: and yet this is made plaine, by the practise of Paul: that of himselfe deliuered vnto Sathan, Hymeneus, and Philetus, that they might learne not to blaspheme. 1. Tim. 1.20. And yet is it made more plaine by his proceeding against the incestuous person, among the Corinthians. Of whom Paul hauing intelligence by common report, determineth thus, saying: For I verely, as absent in body, but present in spirit, haue determined already, as though I were present, that he that hath done this thing, when ye are gathered together, and my spirit, in the name of our Lord Iesus Christ, that such a one, I say, by the power of our Lord Iesus Christ, be deliuered vnto Sathan: where wee plainely see, that Paul the generall ouerseer of the Church, being absent, ioyneth with the Eldership, in casting out, that incestuous person, giueth them commandement to do it; and first pronounceth
by h • s writing, and word, the excommunication against that sinfull man: and this authoritie of his, he put ouer to Timothie, and to Titus ouer those s • u • rall Churchs, where-ouer they had authoritie and power: and they set it ouer againe to the after Bishops, and this is the very power, and all the power, that is put in vse, and practised by our Reuerend fathers, the Bishops of England.

And thus not running to the fathers, which are but the lesser stre • mes; b • t to the scriptures, which are the very fountaines of truth, we find at large described, the office of the Bishop, or the oue • seer of the Primitiue Church: yet safe, and pure, and without all spot, & blot of humane corruption. Now what Christian heart is there, that considering all these parts, so specially, and manifestly deliuered, can once thinke or perswade it selfe, that all this was written for one Timothie, or for one Titus onely, and for no more: a • d that with them, this doctrine, the vse of all these holy duties, the practise of all these holy commaundements, this power of ouerseeing the Church, this holy, and profitable office, was to liue, and to die, and after them, neuer more to haue his vse, or power in the Church of the li • ing God? and that onely for the guiding of one or two men, and for no more, was all this scripture inspired by God? and that it serued for no after age for euer? or who rather doth not beleeue, that to this end, was all this written, to teach for euer vnto the Church, what is the office, and the dutie of the ouerseers of the Church, that should in all ages of the world spring vp for euer.

And now out of all this, it appeareth: first, that the gifs, the calling, and the office of a Bishop, is particularly, & at large desciphered by the holy Scriptures, inspired by God: & that this was another office, then the office of the Euangelelist was: namely, the office of a Bishop, or the office of an ouerseer of the Church; and the selfe same office, that of trust is committed to our Reuerend Bishops, the ouerseers of the English Church. O could our aduersaries, out of the Scriptures of God, shew the office of their ruling Elder, thus particularly and plainely, at large described: How would they triumph, and conclude, that he was set into the Church by God; that he had his place, his office, and his calling, at large giuen him by the power of our Lord Iesus Christ: and therefore that he was to abide for euer in the Church of God.

Secondly, this being the office of a Bishop, it is apparent, as I sayd before; that for the execution hereof, there is no necessity
of the gifts of an Euangelist: or of the Apostles of Iesus Christ, and that God in mercy, hath giuen to our Church, many excellent men, that for gifts are made able, and sufficient to bare and to execute this ouerseers office.

Thirdly, that the office of a Bishop, giuen by God, and the office of a superintendent giuen by the reformed Churches, is not all one: & that God neuer gaue, as our aduersaries fancy to themselues, Titular Bishops, that is Bishops, in title, and name: but not Bishops in office, and power: such as our Bishops be.

Fourthly, that Bishops are no Antichristian creation: but that they had their first ordinance, and institution of God: and that had they kept themselues, within the compasse that was set them by God, there had bene no feare, of a Pope, to spring out of their of-spring: But ranging out of their stinted place, and adding to Bishops, Patriarkes, and Cardinals: and to those adding Popes: out of the addition of man, and not out of the creation of Bishops, which were of God, Antichrist sprung vp: by the principall, if not onely helpe of Ecclesiasticall Discipline retained, vsed, or rather abused by the Pope: powers therfore, in, and of the Church, aboue the Bishops of the Church, the Church of God neuer knew neither was it lawfull, sith God gaue B • shops, for the Church to giue Patriarkes, or Popes. No the ordinance, and the patterne of God, is closely to be sticked vnto, & it was not lawful to go an inch frō the example of God, in setting vp ouerseers, ouer the Church.

Fiftly, that the office of a Bishop, all the daye of the persecuted Church at the least, had his perpetuall, & necessary place, in the Church of God In which time he sat as a king, in the want of Christian kings, to gouerne the whole Church, that was vnder him. And euen now in the dayes of Christian kings, he hath as good, if not far better place, by God giuen him in the Church, thē the ruling Elder hath: and sith it hath pleased the kings Maiesty, when he might vtterly haue banished the discipline Ecclesiastical, to let it, (it being first made fit for his kingdome) haue his seat, and footing within this kingdome of his: I see no reason, why the other parts therof should be left in vse, and the ouerseers of the Church, the principall part thereof, be discontinued, and banished out of the land. The reformed Churches therefore, by cutting away of Bishops, haue made a maime in the body of Christ, and haue imperfectly, and to halfes retained, and set vp the Primitime Gouernment of the Church.

And heere, least my arguments as a loose broome, should not sweepe cleane, and carry all before them, I will fasten them a litle closer, and presse them into a few short, and plaine conclusions. Where first I will lay downe this, as the ground of the rest, that the office of Timothie, (which I will proue to be the office of a Bishop) is perpetuall. I meane to the persecuted, yea & to the peaceable Church: so farre forth, as is requisite for the creating, and for the well gouerning of the created ministery: though not for the gouerning of the people; which I hold as the rest of the Primitiue Gouernment, vnder a Christian king, to be altogether arbitrary. For there euer being a ministery to teach, though not to gouerne the people: I hold a necessitie of a Bishop to create, and to gouerne this ministery: which indeed was the principall office of Timothie, though I thinke that at the first, and in the persecuted church, he had a speciall stroke in the gouernment of the people, as our Bishops haue at this day: and my arguments for the p • ouing of the perpetuity of Timothies office are these.

list.item: 1. D A. Whatsoeuer is described and taught in the first Epistle to Timothie, is perpetuall.
R I. But the office of Timothie is there described, and taught.
I. Ergo, it is perpetuall.

div.p: The Maior of this sillogisme, may not bee denied by our brethren: for it is their owne, and it is grounded vpon those wordes to Timothie, 1. Tim. 6.14. I charge thee to keepe those things vnblameable to the day of the Lord, whence they cōclude that all things in that Epistle must be kept to the day of the Lord.
The Minor is appaernt by that description of Timothies office before described, and particularly set downe as it is gathered out of that Epistle.
The conclusion followeth vpon the praemises.

list.item: 2. D A. The principall subiect matter of the Epistle to Timothie is perpetuall.
R I. But the office of Timothie is the principall subiect matter of that Epistle.
I. Ergo, the office of Timothie is perpetuall.

div.p:
The Minor of this sillogisme is proued by these words to Timothie in that Epistle, 1. Tim. 3.14.15. These things haue I wrote vnto thee, that thou mightest know how to behaue thy selfe in the Church of God till I come: the which wordes plainely shew that it was the maine intent of Paul in that Epistle to teach Timothie
his duetie in the Church Gouernement.
The Maior is proued thus.

list.item: D A. Euery part of the word of God that is a parcell of the Gospell is perpetuall.
R I. But the principall subiect matter of that Epistle is a part of the word of the Gospell.
I. Ergo, the principall subiect matter of that Epistle is perpetuall.

div.p: 3. If that Epistle to Timothie, concerne onely Timothie, and bind not the Church after him, then some parts of the Gospell by their owne confession are particular, and concerne onely priuate persons, and bind not the after Church any thing at all.

Ergo, those words of Christ to his Disciples, they are called gratious Lords, but it shall not be so with you, may be particular, and concerne onely the Disciples of Christ, and bind not the after Church, any thing at all.

I alleage this reason to let them see how partiall they are, that can make at their pleasure some words, for their owne aduantage, particular, that are generall: and some againe of the same nature for their aduantage, generall, that are particular.

list.item: The offices that are alike and equally established in the same Epistle to Timothy, are of alike, and of the same continuance, and perpetuitie.
But the office of Timothie is a like, and equally established in that Epistle to Timothie, as is the office of the Minister, and the Church widdow.
Ergo, it is of the same continuance, and perpetuitie.

div.p: But they hold the office of the Minister, the Widdow, and Deacon to be perpetuall, ergo, so must they hold the office of Timothie, to be perpetuall.
Thus hauing proued the office of Timothie to be perpetuall, I inferre, that the office of Timothie in that Epistle put vpon him, was the office of the Bishop. I proue it thus.

list.item: The office there put vpon Timothy was the office of an Apostle or Euangelist, or Pastor, or Doctor, or Bishop.
But not the office of Apostle, Euangelist, Pastor, or Doctor.
Ergo, the office of a Bishop.

div.p:
That the office put thē vpon Timothie, was not the office of an Apostle, that I take as graunted: for it was too great. Againe, that it was not the office of an ordinary, and vnder-Pastor, or Docto • , that I take as graunted: For it was to abase him ouer much: but
whither it was the office of the Euangelist, is the maine question: but I will out of all question take away that question, by this argument.

list.item: The office put vpon Timothie there, was perpetuall.
But the office of the Euangelist was not perpetuall.
Ergo, the office there put vpon Timothie, was not the office of the Euangelist.

div.p: Thus my argument standeth firme, that concluded, that Timothies office, which was the Bishops office, is perpetuall: and from hence I inferre one thing farther, and that is this.

list.item: Such a Bishop as Timothie was, were the Bishops of the Primitiue Church.
But Timothie was not a bare Titular Bishop.
Ergo, The Bishops of the Primitiue Church were not bare Titular Bishops.

div.p:
The king therefore, as he found the Discipline of the Church by hand deliuered vnto him: so hee againe, dealing with all faithfulnesse, del • uereth the same; without maime, and without all courtailing thereof, to this age, and Church of ours: and those whom God gaue ouerseers to his Church: euen of those hath the king made choice, and hath giuen them ouerseers for himselfe: whom God once chose, the king hath chosen: whom God set to ouersee the Church; them hath the king set, to ouersee the Church, and to gouerne it for him; and them whom God gaue in the want of Kings, to raigne as Kings, and to rule his Church: euen them hath the king giuen to raigne, vnder, and for him, in and ouer the ancient Church, of Iesus our Lord, and king. So that the Bishops had their first place of God: but now they haue it of the king also; & so there is some thing of the Bishop, that was of God: and that is their first institution, and creation: and something that is of the king; and that is their Baronies, and their power also, to rule in steed of the king, ouer the Church of England. We therefore, that haue subscribed to the booke of the ordination of Bishops and Deacons haue subscribed only to the ordinance, and to the institution of God, and the king: and so we haue committed no euill, nor done any sinne at all, in that out of so good grounds of the word of God, we haue subscribed first to the ordination of Bishops: and by consequent, to the established Gouernment of this our Church: which we haue shewed to come more neare to the Primitiue Gouernement, which was in
the Apostles dayes, then that of the reformed Churches: and which differeth euen from that which followed immediately, nohing at all: or else in no materiall point, but onely in a necessarie circumstance. And thus much for our answere touching subscription to the booke of ordination of Bishops, and Deacons.

And now, in a word to answere for our subscription to the Booke of Common Prayer, reformed: I confesse, that I see many cauels brought against it but no obiection of any weight, or any worth; or that deserueth an answere: and yet hath bin already sufficiently answered, by men of farre more excellent gifts, then my selfe am: vpon whose answere, vnanswered, I repose my selfe contentedly, and therunto I wish for answere, all others to referre themselues: onely I admonish all men of this, that as in reading of the Scriptures, there must be a construction had, of the places that seeme to differ, answerable, and agreeing, to the proportion of faith: least there be a place left for the Atheists, and Heretiques, to cauill there against: so in reading all other Authors, and Bookes; especially that of Common Prayer, there must bee vsed the like, and a gentle construction: which being in loue, and duty afforded thereunto, they shall find therein nothing disagreeing, or differing one iot from the proportion of faith: and let them remember, that Atheistes and Heretiques, haue picked quarrels, and found matters of cauil, euen against the holy booke of the Bible: and therefore no maruaile, if a cauilling spirit, may find some matter of cauill, against the Booke of Common Prayer: the prouerbe is true, it is an easie matter to find a staffe to beat a dogge. And thus much concerning subscription.
